   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Pakistan</h1>

    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country in South Asia. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Pakistan (disambiguation)">Pakistan (disambiguation)</a>.

         <td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a> (39%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Pashto_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashto language">Pashto</a> (18%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a> (15%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Saraiki_language" title="Saraiki language">Saraiki</a> (12%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">Balochi</a> (3%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Hindko_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindko language">Hindko</a> (2%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Brahui_language" title="Brahui language">Brahui</a> (1%) â¢ <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_language" title="Kashmiri language">Kashmiri</a> (0.17%)<br><br> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Balti_language" title="Balti language">Balti</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Burushaski" title="Burushaski">Burushaski</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Dameli_language" title="Dameli language">Dameli</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Domaaki_language" title="Domaaki language">Domaaki</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Gawar-Bati_language" title="Gawar-Bati language">Gawar-Bati</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Kalasha-mun" title="Kalasha-mun">Kalasha</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Khowar_language" title="Khowar language">Khowar</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Kohistani_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Kohistani language">Kohistani</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Kutchi_language" title="Kutchi language">Kutchi</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Memoni_language" title="Memoni language">Memoni</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Pahari-Pothwari" title="Pahari-Pothwari">Pahari-Pothwari</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Shina_language" title="Shina language">Shina</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Wakhi_language" title="Wakhi language">Wakhi</a> â¢ <a href="/wiki/Yidgha_language" title="Yidgha language">Yidgha</a></td>

        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table role="presentation" class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Urdu_example.svg/40px-Urdu_example.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Urdu_example.svg/60px-Urdu_example.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Urdu_example.svg/80px-Urdu_example.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="859" data-file-height="857"></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">You may need <a href="/wiki/Help:Arabic" title="Help:Arabic">rendering support</a> to display the <a href="/wiki/Urdu_alphabet" title="Urdu alphabet">Urdu text</a> in this article correctly.</td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Pakistan</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[c]</a></sup> officially the <b>Islamic Republic of Pakistan</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[d]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>. It is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population">fifth-most populous</a> country with a population exceeding 212.2&nbsp;million, and has the world's <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country#Countries" title="Islam by country">second-largest Muslim population</a>. Pakistan is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by area">33rd-largest country</a> by area, spanning 881,913 square kilometres (340,509 square miles). It has a 1,046-kilometre (650-mile) <a href="/wiki/Coastline" class="mw-redirect" title="Coastline">coastline</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman" title="Gulf of Oman">Gulf of Oman</a> in the south, being bordered by India to <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Pakistan_border" title="IndiaâPakistan border">the east</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> to <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">the west</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> to <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Pakistan_border" title="IranâPakistan border">the southwest</a>, and China to <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_border" title="ChinaâPakistan border">the northeast</a>. It is separated narrowly from <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a> by Afghanistan's <a href="/wiki/Wakhan_Corridor" title="Wakhan Corridor">Wakhan Corridor</a> in the northwest, and also shares a <a href="/wiki/Maritime_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Maritime border">maritime border</a> with <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>. </p>
      <p>Pakistan is the site of several <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Prehistory of Pakistan">ancient cultures</a>, most notably the 8,500-year-old <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> site of <a href="/wiki/Mehrgarh" title="Mehrgarh">Mehrgarh</a>, the oldest in South Asia,<sup id="cite_ref-coningham-young-1_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coningham-young-1-18">[14]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a>, the most extensive of the civilisations of the Old World.<sup id="cite_ref-Wright2009_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wright2009-19">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AllchinAllchin1982_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AllchinAllchin1982-20">[16]</a></sup> The region of Pakistan was the realm of empires and dynasties, including the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Archaemenid</a>; briefly that of <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Alexander_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Empire of Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-:Gupta2_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:Gupta2-21">[17]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> in its southern regions, the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Shahi" title="Hindu Shahi">Hindu Shahi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavids</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughals</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[18]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Durrani_Empire" title="Durrani Empire">Durrani Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a> (in the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a>), <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">East India Company rule</a>, and, most recently, the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Indian Empire</a> from 1858 to 1947. </p>
      <p>Spurred by the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movement</a>, which sought a homeland for the Muslims of <a href="/wiki/British_India" class="mw-redirect" title="British India">British India</a>, and election victories in 1946 by the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">Muslim League</a>, Pakistan won independence in 1947 after the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of the British Indian Empire</a>, which awarded separate statehood to its Muslim-majority regions and was accompanied by an unparalleled migration and loss of life.<sup id="cite_ref-Copland2001_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Copland2001-23">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2006_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2006-24">[20]</a></sup> Initially a <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">dominion</a> of the <a href="/wiki/British_Commonwealth" class="mw-redirect" title="British Commonwealth">British Commonwealth</a>, Pakistan adopted a <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">constitution</a> in 1956, becoming an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic republic</a>. In 1971, <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> seceded as the new country of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> after a <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">civil war</a>. During the following four decades, Pakistan was ruled by governments whose descriptions, although complex, commonly alternated between civilian and military, democratic and authoritarian, relatively secular and Islamicist.<sup id="cite_ref-Talbot2016-1_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Talbot2016-1-25">[21]</a></sup> Pakistan elected a civilian government in 2008, and in 2010 adopted a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary">parliamentary</a> system with periodic elections.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[23]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan is a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>, and has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by number of troops">sixth-largest standing armed forces</a>. It is a declared <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear-weapons state</a>, and is ranked among the <a href="/wiki/Emerging_and_growth-leading_economies" title="Emerging and growth-leading economies">emerging and growth-leading economies</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[25]</a></sup> and has a large and fast-growing middle class.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[27]</a></sup> Pakistan's political history since independence has been characterized by periods of significant economic and military growth as well those of political and economic instability. It is an <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Pakistan" title="Ethnic groups in Pakistan">ethnically</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Pakistan" title="Languages of Pakistan">linguistically</a> diverse country, with similarly diverse <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Pakistan" title="Geography of Pakistan">geography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Pakistan" title="Fauna of Pakistan">wildlife</a>. However, the country faces challenges including <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Pakistan" title="Poverty in Pakistan">poverty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Pakistan#Literacy_rate" title="Education in Pakistan">illiteracy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Pakistan" title="Corruption in Pakistan">corruption</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[30]</a></sup> Pakistan is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/SAARC" class="mw-redirect" title="SAARC">SAARC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Military_Counter_Terrorism_Coalition" title="Islamic Military Counter Terrorism Coalition">Islamic Military Counter Terrorism Coalition</a>, and is a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>. </p>

      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <p>The name <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Pakistan" class="extiw" title="wikt:Pakistan">Pakistan</a></i> means literally "a land abounding in the pure" or "a land in which the pure abound", in <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>. It references the word <span lang="fa"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%BE%D8%A7%DA%A9#Persian" class="extiw" title="wikt:Ù¾Ø§Ú©">Ù¾Ø§Ú©</a></span> (<i>pÄk</i>), meaning "pure" in <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pashto_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Pashto language">Pashto</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[31]</a></sup> The suffix <span lang="fa"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%80%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86#Persian" class="extiw" title="wikt:ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù">ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù</a></span> (transliterated in English as <a href="/wiki/-stan" title="-stan"><b>stÃ¢n</b> after stem word ending in a vowel; <b>estÃ¢n</b> or <b>istÃ¢n</b> after a stem ending in a consonant</a>) is from Persian, and means "a place abounding in" <sup id="cite_ref-hayyim-dictionary_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hayyim-dictionary-36">[32]</a></sup> or "a place where anything abounds".<sup id="cite_ref-steingass-dictionary_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-steingass-dictionary-37">[33]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The name of the country was coined in 1933 by <a href="/wiki/Choudhry_Rahmat_Ali" title="Choudhry Rahmat Ali">Choudhry Rahmat Ali</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movement</a> activist, who published it in a pamphlet <i><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Declaration" title="Pakistan Declaration">Now or Never</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-nowornever_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nowornever-38">[34]</a></sup> using it as an <a href="/wiki/Acronym" title="Acronym">acronym</a> ("thirty million Muslim brethren who live in PAKISTAN"), and referring to the names of the five northern regions of the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>: <a href="/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India)" title="Punjab Province (British India)"><i>P</i>unjab</a>, <a href="/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province_(1901%E2%80%932010)" class="mw-redirect" title="North-West Frontier Province (1901â2010)"><i>A</i>fghania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(princely_state)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)"><i>K</i>ashmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sind_Province_(1936%E2%80%9355)" title="Sind Province (1936â55)"><i>S</i>indh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baluchistan_(Chief_Commissioner%27s_Province)" title="Baluchistan (Chief Commissioner's Province)">Baluchis<i>tan</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nowornever_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nowornever-38">[34]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan" title="History of Pakistan">History of Pakistan</a>
      </div>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_South_Asian_history" title="Outline of South Asian history">Outline of South Asian history</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_and_medieval_age">Early and medieval age</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vedic_Period" class="mw-redirect" title="Vedic Period">Vedic Period</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauryan_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Mauryan Empire">Mauryan Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek_Kingdom" title="Indo-Greek Kingdom">Indo-Greek Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg/170px-Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg" decoding="async" width="170" height="219" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg/255px-Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg/340px-Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="584" data-file-height="754"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mohenjo-daro_Priesterk%C3%B6nig.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Indus Priest King Statue from <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-Daro" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohenjo-Daro">Mohenjo-Daro</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Some of the earliest ancient human civilisations in South Asia originated from areas encompassing present-day Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup> The earliest known inhabitants in the region were <a href="/wiki/Soanian" title="Soanian">Soanian</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a>, of whom stone tools have been found in the <a href="/wiki/Soan_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Soan Valley">Soan Valley</a> of <a href="/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus region</a>, which covers most of present day Pakistan, was the site of several successive ancient cultures including the Neolithic Mehrgarh<sup id="cite_ref-vipul_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vipul-41">[37]</a></sup> and the Bronze Age <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWright2010_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright2010-42">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-feuerstein_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-feuerstein-43">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup> (2,800â1,800&nbsp;BCE) at <a href="/wiki/Harappa" title="Harappa">Harappa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-Daro" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohenjo-Daro">Mohenjo-Daro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Arnett2006_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arnett2006-47">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gandhara_Buddha_(tnm).jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/170px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg" decoding="async" width="170" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/255px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/340px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1746" data-file-height="2894"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gandhara_Buddha_(tnm).jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Standing_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Standing Buddha">Standing Buddha</a> from <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhist_art" title="Greco-Buddhist art">Greco-Buddhist art</a>, 1stâ2nd century AD.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> (1500â500&nbsp;BCE) was characterised by an <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryan</a> culture; during this period the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, the oldest scriptures associated with <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, were composed, and this culture later became well established in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-guide_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guide-49">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Multan" title="Multan">Multan</a> was an important Hindu pilgrimage centre.<sup id="cite_ref-taxila_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taxila-51">[47]</a></sup> The Vedic civilisation flourished in the ancient <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">GandhÄran</a> city of Taká¹£aÅilÄ, now <a href="/wiki/Taxila" title="Taxila">Taxila</a> in the Punjab, which was founded around 1000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAllchinAllchin1988314_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAllchinAllchin1988314-52">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vipul_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vipul-41">[37]</a></sup> Successive ancient empires and kingdoms ruled the region: the Persian <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> (around 519&nbsp;BCE), <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>'s empire in 326&nbsp;BCE<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya Empire</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Chandragupta_Maurya" title="Chandragupta Maurya">Chandragupta Maurya</a> and extended by <a href="/wiki/Ashoka_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Ashoka the Great">Ashoka the Great</a>, until 185&nbsp;BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-vipul_41-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vipul-41">[37]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek_Kingdom" title="Indo-Greek Kingdom">Indo-Greek Kingdom</a> founded by <a href="/wiki/Demetrius_I_of_Bactria" title="Demetrius I of Bactria">Demetrius of Bactria</a> (180â165&nbsp;BCE) included Gandhara and Punjab and reached its greatest extent under <a href="/wiki/Menander_I" title="Menander I">Menander</a> (165â150&nbsp;BCE), prospering the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhism" title="Greco-Buddhism">Greco-Buddhist</a> culture in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-vipul_41-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vipul-41">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup> Taxila had one of the earliest universities and centres of higher education in the world, which was established during the late Vedic period in 6th century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_Education_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica_Education-55">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-56">[52]</a></sup> The school consisted of several monasteries without large dormitories or lecture halls where the religious instruction was provided on an individualistic basis.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-56">[52]</a></sup> The ancient university was documented by the invading forces of Alexander the Great and was also recorded by Chinese pilgrims in the 4th or 5th century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At its zenith, the <a href="/wiki/Rai_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Rai Dynasty">Rai Dynasty</a> (489â632&nbsp;CE) of <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a> ruled this region and the surrounding territories.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pala_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Pala Dynasty">Pala Dynasty</a> was the last Buddhist empire, which, under <a href="/wiki/Dharmapala_(emperor)" title="Dharmapala (emperor)">Dharmapala</a> and <a href="/wiki/Devapala_(Pala_dynasty)" title="Devapala (Pala dynasty)">Devapala</a>, stretched across South Asia from what is now <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> through <a href="/wiki/Northern_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern India">Northern India</a> to Pakistan. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_conquest">Islamic conquest</span></h3> 
      <p>The Arab conqueror <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_bin_Qasim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muhammad bin Qasim">Muhammad bin Qasim</a> conquered Sindh in 711&nbsp;CE.<sup id="cite_ref-Information_of_Pakistan_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Information_of_Pakistan-62">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> The Pakistan government's official chronology claims this as the time when the foundation of Pakistan was laid<sup id="cite_ref-Information_of_Pakistan_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Information_of_Pakistan-62">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup> but the concept of <i>Pakistan</i> arrived in the 19th century. The Early Medieval period (642â1219&nbsp;CE) witnessed the spread of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> in the region. During this period, <a href="/wiki/Sufi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> <a href="/wiki/Dawah" title="Dawah">missionaries</a> played a pivotal role in converting a majority of the regional Buddhist and Hindu population to Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[65]</a></sup> Upon the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Turk_Shahis" title="Turk Shahis">Turk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Shahi" title="Hindu Shahi">Hindu Shahi</a> dynasties which governed the <a href="/wiki/Kabul_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Kabul Valley">Kabul Valley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a> (present-day Khyber Pakhtunkwa), and western Punjab in the 7th to 11th centuries CE, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim conquest in the Indian subcontinent">several successive Muslim empires</a> ruled over the region, including the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavid Empire</a> (975â1187&nbsp;CE), the <a href="/wiki/Ghorid" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghorid">Ghorid</a> Kingdom, and the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> (1206â1526&nbsp;CE). The <a href="/wiki/Lodi_dynasty" title="Lodi dynasty">Lodi dynasty</a>, the last of the Delhi Sultanate, was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> (1526â1857&nbsp;CE). </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg/280px-Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="187" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg/420px-Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg/560px-Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5078" data-file-height="3385"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Badshahi_Masjid_-_Side_View.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Badshahi_Mosque" title="Badshahi Mosque">Badshahi Mosque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Mughals introduced Persian literature and high culture, establishing the roots of <a href="/wiki/Indo-Persian_culture" title="Indo-Persian culture">Indo-Persian culture</a> in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[66]</a></sup> In the region of modern-day Pakistan, key cities during the Mughal period were <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thatta" title="Thatta">Thatta</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[67]</a></sup> both of which were chosen as the site of impressive <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal buildings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[68]</a></sup> In the early 16th century, the region remained under the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> ruled by <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Emperor" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughal Emperor">Muslim emperors</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> By the early 18th century, increasing European influence contributed to the slow disintegration of the Mughal Empire as the lines between commercial and political dominance became increasingly blurred.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During this time, the English <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> had established coastal outposts.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> Control over the seas, greater resources, technology, and <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British military protection</a> led the Company to increasingly flex its military muscle, allowing the <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company to gain control</a> over the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Subcontinent" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Subcontinent">subcontinent</a> by 1765 and sideline European competitors.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[70]</a></sup> Expanding access beyond <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> and the subsequent increased strength and size of its <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">army</a> enabled it to annex or subdue most of region by the 1820s.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> Many historians see this as the start of the region's colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> By this time, with its economic power severely curtailed by the <a href="/wiki/British_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="British parliament">British parliament</a> and itself effectively made an arm of British administration, the <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company</a> began more deliberately to enter non-economic arenas such as education, social reform, and culture.<sup id="cite_ref-Cambridge_University_Press_73-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cambridge_University_Press-73">[69]</a></sup> Such reforms included the enforcement of the <a href="/wiki/English_Education_Act_1835" title="English Education Act 1835">English Education Act</a> in 1835 and the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Civil_Service_(British_India)" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Civil Service (British India)">Indian Civil Service</a> (ICS).<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[71]</a></sup> Traditional <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa"><i>madrasahs</i></a>âprimary institutions of higher learning for <a href="/wiki/Indian_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Muslims">Muslims</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Subcontinent" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Subcontinent">subcontinent</a>âwere no longer supported by the <a href="/wiki/English_rule_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="English rule of India">English Crown</a>, and nearly all of the <i>madrasahs</i> lost their financial endowment.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[72]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_period">Colonial period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Colonial_India" title="Colonial India">Colonial India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Aligarh movement">Aligarh movement</a>, and <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:308px;max-width:308px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Sir_Syed1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Sir Syed Ahmad Khan (1817â1898), whose vision (Two-nation theory) formed the basis of Pakistan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Sir_Syed1.jpg/150px-Sir_Syed1.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="229" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Sir_Syed1.jpg/225px-Sir_Syed1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1a/Sir_Syed1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="236" data-file-height="360"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Sir <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmad_Khan" title="Syed Ahmad Khan">Syed Ahmad Khan</a> (1817â1898), whose <a href="/wiki/Two-nation_theory" title="Two-nation theory">vision</a> formed the basis of Pakistan
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Jinnah1945b.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Muhammad Ali Jinnah (1876â1948) served as Pakistan's first Governor-General and the leader of the Pakistan Movement" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Jinnah1945b.jpg/150px-Jinnah1945b.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="197" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Jinnah1945b.jpg/225px-Jinnah1945b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Jinnah1945b.jpg/300px-Jinnah1945b.jpg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="853"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> (1876â1948) served as Pakistan's first Governor-General and the leader of the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movement</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The gradual decline of the Mughal Empire in the early 18th century enabled the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a> to control larger areas until the British <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">East India Company</a> gained ascendancy over <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-77">[73]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">rebellion</a> in 1857 called the <a href="/wiki/Sepoy_mutiny" class="mw-redirect" title="Sepoy mutiny">Sepoy mutiny</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> was the region's major armed struggle against the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_Victoria" title="Queen Victoria">Queen Victoria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[74]</a></sup> Divergence in the <a href="/wiki/Hindu%E2%80%93Islamic_relations" title="HinduâIslamic relations">relationship</a> between Hinduism and Islam created a major rift in <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="British Indian Empire">British India</a> that led to motivated <a href="/wiki/Violence_against_Muslims_in_India" title="Violence against Muslims in India">religious violence in British India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Online_Encyclopedia_of_Mass_Violence_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Online_Encyclopedia_of_Mass_Violence-79">[75]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hindi%E2%80%93Urdu_controversy" title="HindiâUrdu controversy">language controversy</a> further escalated the tensions between Hindus and Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-Sang-i_MÄ«l_Pablikeshanz_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sang-i_MÄ«l_Pablikeshanz-80">[76]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Hindu renaissance</a> witnessed an awakening of intellectualism in traditional <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> and saw the emergence of more assertive influence in the social and political spheres in British India.<sup id="cite_ref-State_University_of_New_York_Press_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State_University_of_New_York_Press-81">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sarup_&amp;_Sons_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sarup_&amp;_Sons-82">[78]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Aligarh_Movement" title="Aligarh Movement">Muslim intellectual movement</a>, founded by Sir <a href="/wiki/Syed_Ahmed_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Syed Ahmed Khan">Syed Ahmed Khan</a> to counter the Hindu renaissance, envisioned, as well as advocated for the <a href="/wiki/Two-nation_theory" title="Two-nation theory">two-nation theory</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-congress_77-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-77">[73]</a></sup> and led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">All-India Muslim League</a> in 1906. In contrast to the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Anti-British_sentiment" title="Anti-British sentiment">anti-British</a> efforts, the Muslim League was a <a href="/wiki/Anglomania" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglomania">pro-British</a> movement whose political program <a href="/wiki/British_heritage_of_Pakistan" title="British heritage of Pakistan">inherited the British values</a> that would shape Pakistan's future <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_society" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani society">civil society</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[79]</a></sup> In events during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Intelligence" class="mw-redirect" title="British Intelligence">British Intelligence</a> foiled an <a href="/wiki/Anti-English" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-English">anti-English</a> <a href="/wiki/Hindu%E2%80%93German_Conspiracy" title="HinduâGerman Conspiracy">conspiracy</a> involving the nexus of Congress and the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="Your explanation here (August 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The largely non-violent independence struggle led by the Indian Congress engaged millions of protesters in mass campaigns of <a href="/wiki/Quit_India_Movement" title="Quit India Movement">civil disobedience</a> in the 1920s and 1930s against the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lak2008_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lak2008-85">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_Institution_Press-86">[82]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg/220px-Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg/330px-Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg/440px-Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4920" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Clock_Tower_Faisalabad_by_Usman_Nadeem.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Clock_Tower,_Faisalabad" title="Clock Tower, Faisalabad">Clock Tower, Faisalabad</a>, built by the British government in the 19th century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Muslim League slowly rose to mass popularity in the 1930s amid fears of under-representation and neglect of British <a href="/wiki/Indian_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Muslims">Muslims</a> in <a href="/wiki/Indian_politics" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian politics">politics</a>. In his presidential address of 29 December 1930, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Iqbal" title="Muhammad Iqbal">Allama Iqbal</a> called for "the amalgamation of <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Northwestern India">North-West</a> Muslim-majority Indian states" consisting of <a href="/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India)" title="Punjab Province (British India)">Punjab</a>, <a href="/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province_(1901%E2%80%9355)" class="mw-redirect" title="North-West Frontier Province (1901â55)">North-West Frontier Province</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sind_Province_(1936%E2%80%9355)" title="Sind Province (1936â55)">Sind</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baluchistan_(Chief_Commissioner%27s_Province)" title="Baluchistan (Chief Commissioner's Province)">Baluchistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-iqbal1_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iqbal1-87">[83]</a></sup> The perceived neglect of Muslim interests by Congress led British <a href="/wiki/1937_Indian_provincial_elections" title="1937 Indian provincial elections">provincial governments</a> during the period of 1937â39 convinced <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>, the founder of Pakistan to espouse the two-nation theory and led the Muslim League to adopt the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Resolution" title="Lahore Resolution">Lahore Resolution</a> of 1940 presented by <a href="/wiki/Sher-e-Bangla" class="mw-redirect" title="Sher-e-Bangla">Sher-e-Bangla</a> <a href="/wiki/A.K._Fazlul_Haque" class="mw-redirect" title="A.K. Fazlul Haque">A.K. Fazlul Haque</a>, popularly known as the Pakistan Resolution.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_77-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-77">[73]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Jinnah and <a href="/wiki/British_education" class="mw-redirect" title="British education">British-educated</a> <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Founding Fathers of Pakistan">founding fathers</a> in the Muslim League supported the United Kingdom's <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_in_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="United Kingdom in World War II">war efforts</a>, countering opposition against it whilst working towards Sir Syed's <a href="/wiki/Two-nation_theory" title="Two-nation theory">vision</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Politact_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Politact-88">[84]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pakistan_Movement">Pakistan Movement</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Movement" title="Pakistan Movement">Pakistan Movement</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan">History of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence movement</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_British_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Partition of British India">Partition of British India</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/1946_Indian_provincial_elections" title="1946 Indian provincial elections">1946 elections</a> resulted in the Muslim League winning 90&nbsp;percent of the seats reserved for Muslims. Thus, the 1946 election was effectively a plebiscite in which the Indian Muslims were to vote on the creation of Pakistan, a plebiscite won by the Muslim League.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-89">[85]</a></sup> This victory was assisted by the support given to the Muslim League by the support of the landowners of Sindh and Punjab. The <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Congress</a>, which initially denied the Muslim League's claim of being the sole representative of Indian Muslims, was now forced to recognise the fact.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-89">[85]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Rule" class="mw-redirect" title="British Rule">British</a> had no alternative except to take Jinnah's views into account as he had emerged as the sole spokesperson of the entirety of British India's Muslims. However, the British <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_the_partition_of_India" title="Opposition to the partition of India">did not want colonial India to be partitioned</a>, and in one last effort to prevent it, they devised the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_Mission_Plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Cabinet Mission Plan">Cabinet Mission plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As the cabinet mission failed, the British government announced its intention to end the <a href="/wiki/British_Rule" class="mw-redirect" title="British Rule">British Rule</a> in 1946â47.<sup id="cite_ref-Academia_Edu_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Academia_Edu-91">[87]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indian_nationalism" title="Indian nationalism">Nationalists</a> in British Indiaâincluding <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abul_Kalam_Azad" title="Abul Kalam Azad">Abul Kalam Azad</a> of Congress, Jinnah of the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">All-India Muslim League</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Master_Tara_Singh" class="mw-redirect" title="Master Tara Singh">Master Tara Singh</a> representing the Sikhsâagreed to the proposed terms of transfer of power and independence in June 1947 with the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_India" title="Governor-General of India">Viceroy of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Lord Mountbatten of Burma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-jinnah_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jinnah-92">[88]</a></sup> As the United Kingdom agreed to the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partitioning of India</a> in 1947, the modern state of Pakistan was established on <a href="/wiki/Fourteenth_of_August" class="mw-redirect" title="Fourteenth of August">14 August 1947</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(27th of <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a> in 1366 of the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic Calendar">Islamic Calendar</a>)</span>, amalgamating the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_India" title="Islam in India">Muslim-majority</a> eastern and northwestern regions of <a href="/wiki/British_India" class="mw-redirect" title="British India">British India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_Institution_Press-86">[82]</a></sup> It comprised the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Balochistan_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Balochistan (Pakistan)">Balochistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Bengal" title="East Bengal">East Bengal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province_(1901%E2%80%931955)" class="mw-redirect" title="North-West Frontier Province (1901â1955)">North-West Frontier Province</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Punjab, Pakistan">West Punjab</a>, and Sindh.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_77-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-77">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jinnah_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jinnah-92">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the riots that accompanied the partition in Punjab Province, it is believed that between 200,000 and 2,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-D'Costa_2011_53_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-D'Costa_2011_53-96">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Butalia_2000_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Butalia_2000-97">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[94]</a></sup> people were killed in what some have described as a retributive genocide between the religions<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[96]</a></sup> while 50,000 Muslim women were <a href="/wiki/Violence_against_women_during_the_partition_of_India" title="Violence against women during the partition of India">abducted and raped</a> by Hindu and Sikh men and 33,000 Hindu and Sikh women also experienced the same fate at the hands of Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[100]</a></sup> Around 6.5&nbsp;million Muslims moved from India to West Pakistan and 4.7&nbsp;million Hindus and Sikhs moved from West Pakistan to India.<sup id="cite_ref-ECM_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECM-105">[101]</a></sup> It was the largest mass migration in human history.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[104]</a></sup> A subsequent dispute over the <a href="/wiki/Princely_state" title="Princely state">princely state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(princely_state)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)">Jammu and Kashmir</a> eventually sparked the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947%E2%80%931948" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1947â1948">Indo-Pakistani War of 1947â1948</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bhaumik1996_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bhaumik1996-109">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[106]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_modern_Pakistan">Independence and modern Pakistan</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan" title="History of Pakistan">History of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">

      </div> 
      <div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; border-width: 1px; background-color: #c6dbf7;">
       <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1012376600">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{margin:0.5em auto 0.8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft p,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright p{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:larger;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" â ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" â ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 0.8em!important;float:none!important}}</style> 
       <div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
        "You are free; you are free to go to your temples, you are free to go to your mosques or to any other place or worship in this State of Pakistan. You may belong to any religion or caste or creed&nbsp;â that has nothing to do with the business of the State."
       </div> 
       <p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">â<a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a>'s first speech to the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[107]</a></sup></cite> </p> 
      </div> 
      <p>After <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Creation of Pakistan">independence</a> in 1947, Jinnah, the <a href="/wiki/Party_chair" title="Party chair">President</a> of the Muslim League, became the nation's first <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Pakistan" title="Governor-General of Pakistan">Governor-General</a> as well as the first <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="Speaker of the National Assembly of Pakistan">President-Speaker</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Pakistan" title="Parliament of Pakistan">Parliament</a>,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> but he died of tuberculosis on 11 September 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[108]</a></sup> Meanwhile, Pakistan's founding fathers agreed to appoint <a href="/wiki/Liaquat_Ali_Khan" title="Liaquat Ali Khan">Liaquat Ali Khan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_General" class="mw-redirect" title="Secretary General">secretary-general</a> of the <a href="/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League" title="All-India Muslim League">party</a>, the nation's <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Pakistan">first</a> <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a>. With <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">dominion status</a> in the Commonwealth of Nations, independent Pakistan had two <a href="/wiki/British_Monarchy" class="mw-redirect" title="British Monarchy">British monarchs</a> before it became a republic.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The creation of Pakistan was never fully accepted by many British leaders, among them <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Lord Mountbatten</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[109]</a></sup> Mountbatten clearly expressed his lack of support and faith in the Muslim League's idea of Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[110]</a></sup> Jinnah refused Mountbatten's offer to serve as <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Pakistan" title="Governor-General of Pakistan">Governor-General of Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup> When Mountbatten was asked by Collins and Lapierre if he would have sabotaged Pakistan had he known that Jinnah was dying of tuberculosis, he replied 'most probably'.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[112]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Maulana <a href="/wiki/Shabbir_Ahmad_Usmani" title="Shabbir Ahmad Usmani">Shabbir Ahmad Usmani</a>, a respected Deobandi <i>alim</i> (scholar) who occupied the position of Shaykh al-Islam in Pakistan in 1949, and <a href="/wiki/Abul_A%27la_Maududi" title="Abul A'la Maududi">Maulana Mawdudi</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-e-Islami" title="Jamaat-e-Islami">Jamaat-i-Islami</a> played a pivotal role in the demand for an Islamic constitution. <a href="/wiki/Abul_A%27la_Maududi" title="Abul A'la Maududi">Mawdudi</a> demanded that the Constituent Assembly make an explicit declaration affirming the "supreme sovereignty of God" and the supremacy of the <i>shariah</i> in Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[113]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A significant result of the efforts of the Jamaat-i-Islami and the <i><a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulama</a></i> was the passage of the <a href="/wiki/Objectives_Resolution" title="Objectives Resolution">Objectives Resolution</a> in March 1949. The Objectives Resolution, which <a href="/wiki/Liaquat_Ali_Khan" title="Liaquat Ali Khan">Liaquat Ali Khan</a> called the second most important step in Pakistan's history, declared that "sovereignty over the entire universe belongs to God Almighty alone and the authority which He has delegated to the State of Pakistan through its people for being exercised within the limits prescribed by Him is a sacred trust". The Objectives Resolution has been incorporated as a preamble to the constitutions of 1956, 1962, and 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-118">[114]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Democracy_in_Pakistan" title="Democracy in Pakistan">Democracy</a> was stalled by the <a href="/wiki/1958_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1958 Pakistani coup d'Ã©tat">martial law</a> that had been enforced by President <a href="/wiki/Iskander_Mirza" title="Iskander Mirza">Iskander Mirza</a>, who was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Army_Chief_of_Staff_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)">army chief</a>, General <a href="/wiki/Ayub_Khan_(President_of_Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)">Ayub Khan</a>. After adopting a <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan_of_1962" title="Constitution of Pakistan of 1962">presidential system</a> in 1962, the country experienced exceptional growth until a <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">second war</a> with India in 1965 that led to an economic downturn and wide-scale <a href="/wiki/Tashkent_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Tashkent Agreement">public disapproval</a> in 1967.<sup id="cite_ref-Wynbrandt2009_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wynbrandt2009-119">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ChowdhuryMahmud2008_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChowdhuryMahmud2008-120">[116]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Legal_Framework_Order,_1970" title="Legal Framework Order, 1970">Consolidating</a> control from Ayub Khan in 1969, President <a href="/wiki/Yahya_Khan" title="Yahya Khan">Yahya Khan</a> had to deal with a devastating <a href="/wiki/1970_Bhola_cyclone" title="1970 Bhola cyclone">cyclone</a> that caused 500,000 deaths in <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mission_with_a_Difference_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mission_with_a_Difference-121">[117]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg/170px-Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="263" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg/255px-Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg/340px-Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="774"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ayubkhanandbhutto.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Signing of the <a href="/wiki/Tashkent_Declaration" title="Tashkent Declaration">Tashkent Declaration</a> to end <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">hostilities</a> with India in 1965 in <a href="/wiki/Tashkent" title="Tashkent">Tashkent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Soviet_Socialist_Republics_(USSR)" class="mw-redirect" title="Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)">USSR</a>, by President <a href="/wiki/Field_Marshal_Ayub_Khan" class="mw-redirect" title="Field Marshal Ayub Khan">Ayub</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto" title="Zulfikar Ali Bhutto">Bhutto</a> (centre) and <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Ahmed" title="Aziz Ahmed">Aziz Ahmed</a> (left)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1970 Pakistan held its <a href="/wiki/1970_Pakistani_general_election" title="1970 Pakistani general election">first democratic elections</a> since independence, meant to mark a transition from <a href="/wiki/Legal_Framework_Order,_1970" title="Legal Framework Order, 1970">military rule</a> to democracy, but after the East Pakistani <a href="/wiki/Awami_League" title="Awami League">Awami League</a> won against the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party" title="Pakistan Peoples Party">Pakistan Peoples Party</a> (PPP), Yahya Khan and the military establishment refused to hand over power.<sup id="cite_ref-Jones_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jones-122">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jahan_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahan-123">[119]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Operation_Searchlight" title="Operation Searchlight">Operation Searchlight</a>, a military crackdown on the Bengali nationalist movement, led to a declaration of independence and the waging of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">a war of liberation</a> by the Bengali <a href="/wiki/Mukti_Bahini" title="Mukti Bahini">Mukti Bahini</a> forces in East Pakistan,<sup id="cite_ref-Jahan_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahan-123">[119]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1971war_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1971war-124">[120]</a></sup> which in West Pakistan was described as a civil war as opposed to a war of liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[121]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Independent researchers estimate that between 300,000 and 500,000 civilians died during this period while the Bangladesh government puts the number of dead at three million,<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[122]</a></sup> a figure that is now nearly universally regarded as excessively inflated.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[123]</a></sup> Some academics such as <a href="/wiki/Rudolph_Rummel" title="Rudolph Rummel">Rudolph Rummel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rounaq_Jahan" title="Rounaq Jahan">Rounaq Jahan</a> say both sides<sup id="cite_ref-:5_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-128">[124]</a></sup> committed genocide; others such as <a href="/wiki/John_Richard_Sisson" title="John Richard Sisson">Richard Sisson</a> and Leo E. Rose believe there was no genocide.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[125]</a></sup> In response to India's support for the insurgency in East Pakistan, <a href="/wiki/Preemptive_strikes" class="mw-redirect" title="Preemptive strikes">preemptive strikes</a> on India by Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force" title="Pakistan Air Force">air force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Navy" title="Pakistan Navy">navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Marines" title="Pakistan Marines">marines</a> sparked a <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">conventional war</a> in 1971 that resulted in an Indian victory and <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a> gaining <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Bangladesh">independence</a> as <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jahan_123-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahan-123">[119]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With Pakistan <a href="/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_(1971)" class="mw-redirect" title="Instrument of Surrender (1971)">surrendering</a> in the war, Yahya Khan was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto" title="Zulfikar Ali Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a> as president; the country worked towards promulgating its <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">constitution</a> and putting the country on the road to democracy. Democratic rule resumed from 1972 to 1977âan era of self-<a href="/wiki/Consciousness" title="Consciousness">consciousness</a>, intellectual <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan" title="Socialism in Pakistan">leftism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalism_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalism in Pakistan">nationalism</a>, and nationwide reconstruction.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[126]</a></sup> In 1972 Pakistan embarked on an ambitious plan to develop its <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_its_Nuclear_Deterrent_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program">nuclear deterrence</a> capability with <a href="/wiki/Mutually_assured_destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutually assured destruction">the goal of preventing</a> any <a href="/wiki/Foreign_interventionism" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign interventionism">foreign invasion</a>; the country's <a href="/wiki/KANUPP" class="mw-redirect" title="KANUPP">first</a> <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a> was inaugurated in that same year.<sup id="cite_ref-Strategic_Studies_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Strategic_Studies-131">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hoodbhoy_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hoodbhoy-132">[128]</a></sup> Accelerated in response to India's <a href="/wiki/Smiling_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Smiling Buddha">first nuclear test</a> in 1974, this <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_Nuclear_Weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan and Nuclear Weapons">crash program</a> was completed in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-Hoodbhoy_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hoodbhoy-132">[128]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Democracy ended with a <a href="/wiki/Operation_Fair_Play" title="Operation Fair Play">military coup</a> in 1977 against the <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan" title="Socialism in Pakistan">leftist</a> PPP, which saw <a href="/wiki/General_Zia-ul-Haq" class="mw-redirect" title="General Zia-ul-Haq">General Zia-ul-Haq</a> become the president in 1978. From 1977 to 1988, President Zia's <a href="/wiki/Corporate_sector_of_Pakistan" title="Corporate sector of Pakistan">corporatisation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamization of Economy">economic Islamisation</a> initiatives led to Pakistan becoming one of the fastest-growing economies in South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-Sushil_Khanna_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sushil_Khanna-133">[129]</a></sup> While building up the country's <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_its_Nuclear_Deterrent_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program">nuclear program</a>, increasing <a href="/wiki/Zia-ul-Haq%27s_Islamization" class="mw-redirect" title="Zia-ul-Haq's Islamization">Islamisation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-World_Scientific_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Scientific-134">[130]</a></sup> and the rise of a homegrown <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_Pakistan" title="Conservatism in Pakistan">conservative</a> philosophy, Pakistan helped subsidise and distribute US <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">resources to factions</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_mujahideen" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan mujahideen">mujahideen</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">USSR</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">intervention</a> in <a href="/wiki/Communist_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist Afghanistan">communist Afghanistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Steve_Coll:_Ghost_Wars_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steve_Coll:_Ghost_Wars-135">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Westad2005_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Westad2005-136">[132]</a></sup> Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">North-West Frontier Province</a> became a base for the anti-Soviet Afghan fighters, with the province's influential <a href="/wiki/Deobandi" title="Deobandi">Deobandi</a> ulama playing a significant role in encouraging and organising the 'jihad'.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[133]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Death_of_Muhammad_Zia-ul-Haq" class="mw-redirect" title="Death of Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq">President Zia died</a> in a plane crash in 1988, and <a href="/wiki/Benazir_Bhutto" title="Benazir Bhutto">Benazir Bhutto</a>, daughter of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was elected as the country's <a href="/wiki/Women_in_Muslim_societies" class="mw-redirect" title="Women in Muslim societies">first female</a> Prime Minister. The PPP was followed by conservative <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_(N)" title="Pakistan Muslim League (N)">Pakistan Muslim League (N)</a>, and over the next decade the leaders of the two parties fought for power, alternating in office while the country's situation worsened; economic indicators fell sharply, in contrast to the 1980s. This period is marked by prolonged <a href="/wiki/Periods_of_stagflation_in_Pakistan" title="Periods of stagflation in Pakistan">stagflation</a>, instability, <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Pakistan" title="Corruption in Pakistan">corruption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalism_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalism in Pakistan">nationalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geostrategy" title="Geostrategy">geopolitical</a> rivalry with India, and the clash of <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan" title="Socialism in Pakistan">left wing</a>-<a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_Pakistan" title="Conservatism in Pakistan">right wing</a> ideologies.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[135]</a></sup> As <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_(N)" title="Pakistan Muslim League (N)">PML (N)</a> secured a <a href="/wiki/Supermajority" title="Supermajority">supermajority</a> in <a href="/wiki/1997_Pakistani_general_election" title="1997 Pakistani general election">elections</a> in 1997, Sharif authorised <a href="/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_Pakistan" title="List of nuclear weapons tests of Pakistan">nuclear testings</a> (See:<i><a href="/wiki/Chagai-I" title="Chagai-I">Chagai-I</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chagai-II" title="Chagai-II">Chagai-II</a></i>), as a <a href="/wiki/Tit-for-tat" class="mw-redirect" title="Tit-for-tat">retaliation</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Pokhran-II" title="Pokhran-II">second nuclear tests</a> ordered by India, led by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee" title="Atal Bihari Vajpayee">Atal Bihari Vajpayee</a> in May 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-Stanford_University_Press_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stanford_University_Press-140">[136]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg/220px-Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg/330px-Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg/440px-Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="514" data-file-height="351"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Musharaff_and_Bush_in_Islamabad.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>President <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> meets with President <a href="/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf" title="Pervez Musharraf">Musharraf</a> in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> during his 2006 visit to Pakistan.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Military tension between the two countries in the <a href="/wiki/Kargil_district" title="Kargil district">Kargil district</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Kargil_War" title="Kargil War">Kargil War</a> of 1999, and turmoil in <a href="/wiki/Civil-military_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil-military relations">civic-military relations</a> allowed General <a href="/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf" title="Pervez Musharraf">Pervez Musharraf</a> to take over through a <a href="/wiki/1999_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1999 Pakistani coup d'Ã©tat">bloodless coup d'Ã©tat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kargil_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kargil-141">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1999coup_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1999coup-142">[138]</a></sup> Musharraf governed Pakistan as <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">chief executive</a> from 1999 to 2001 and as President from 2001 to 2008âa period of <a href="/wiki/Enlightened_moderation" title="Enlightened moderation">enlightenment</a>, social <a href="/wiki/Liberal_islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberal islam">liberalism</a>, extensive <a href="/wiki/Economic_reforms_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic reforms in Pakistan">economic reforms</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[139]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan%27s_role_in_the_War_on_Terror" title="Pakistan's role in the War on Terror">direct involvement in the US-led war on terrorism</a>. When the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly (Pakistan)">National Assembly</a> historically completed its first full five-year term on 15 November 2007, the new elections were called by the <a href="/wiki/Election_Commission_of_Pakistan" title="Election Commission of Pakistan">Election Commission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[140]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Benazir_Bhutto" title="Assassination of Benazir Bhutto">assassination of Benazir Bhutto</a> in 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party" title="Pakistan Peoples Party">PPP</a> secured the <a href="/wiki/Majority" title="Majority">most votes</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2008_Pakistani_general_election" title="2008 Pakistani general election">elections</a> of 2008, appointing party member <a href="/wiki/Yousaf_Raza_Gillani" title="Yousaf Raza Gillani">Yousaf Raza Gillani</a> as Prime Minister.<sup id="cite_ref-145"
