class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[141]</a></sup> Threatened with <a href="/wiki/Movement_to_impeach_Pervez_Musharraf" title="Movement to impeach Pervez Musharraf">impeachment</a>, President Musharraf resigned on 18 August 2008, and was succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Asif_Ali_Zardari" title="Asif Ali Zardari">Asif Ali Zardari</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NEWSMUSH_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NEWSMUSH-148">[144]</a></sup> Clashes with the <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Pakistan" title="Judiciary of Pakistan">judicature</a> prompted <a href="/wiki/Yousaf_Raza_Gillani" title="Yousaf Raza Gillani">Gillani</a>'s disqualification from the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Pakistan" title="Parliament of Pakistan">Parliament</a> and as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> in June 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-thenews.com_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thenews.com-149">[145]</a></sup> By its own financial calculations, Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Pakistan%27s_role_in_the_War_on_Terror" title="Pakistan's role in the War on Terror">involvement in the war on terrorism</a> has cost up to $118&nbsp;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[146]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_terrorist_incidents_in_Pakistan_since_2001" title="List of terrorist incidents in Pakistan since 2001">sixty thousand casualties</a> and more than 1.8&nbsp;million displaced civilians.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[147]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2013_Pakistani_general_election" title="2013 Pakistani general election">general election</a> held in 2013 saw the PML (N) almost achieve a <a href="/wiki/Supermajority" title="Supermajority">supermajority</a>, following which <a href="/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif" title="Nawaz Sharif">Nawaz Sharif</a> was elected as the Prime Minister, returning to the post for the third time in fourteen years, in a democratic transition.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[148]</a></sup> In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Imran_Khan" title="Imran Khan">Imran Khan</a> (the chairman of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Tehreek-e-Insaf" title="Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf">PTI</a>) won the <a href="/wiki/2018_Pakistan_general_election" class="mw-redirect" title="2018 Pakistan general election">2018 Pakistan general election</a> with 116 general seats and became the 22nd <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister of Pakistan</a> in election of <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="National Assembly of Pakistan">National Assembly of Pakistan</a> for <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime Minister">Prime Minister</a> by getting 176 votes against <a href="/wiki/Shehbaz_Sharif" title="Shehbaz Sharif">Shehbaz Sharif</a> (the chairman of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_(N)" title="Pakistan Muslim League (N)">PML (N)</a>) who got 96 votes.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[149]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Role_of_Islam">Role of Islam</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Secularism_in_Pakistan" title="Secularism in Pakistan">Secularism in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan is the only country to have been created in the name of Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-154">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:113_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:113-155">[151]</a></sup> The idea of Pakistan, which had received overwhelming popular support among Indian Muslims, especially those in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/British_India" class="mw-redirect" title="British India">British India</a> where Muslims were in a minority such as the <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_(1937%E2%80%9350)" title="United Provinces (1937â50)">United Provinces</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup> was articulated in terms of an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_state" title="Islamic state">Islamic state</a> by the Muslim League leadership, the <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulama</a> (Islamic clergy) and Jinnah.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[153]</a></sup> Jinnah had developed a close association with the <i>ulama</i> and upon his death was described by one such <i>alim</i>, <a href="/wiki/Maulana_Shabbir_Ahmad_Usmani" class="mw-redirect" title="Maulana Shabbir Ahmad Usmani">Maulana Shabbir Ahmad Usmani</a>, as the greatest Muslim after <a href="/wiki/Aurangzeb" title="Aurangzeb">Aurangzeb</a> and as someone who desired to unite the Muslims of the world under the banner of Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-158">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Objectives Resolution in March 1949, which declared God as the sole sovereign over the entire universe, represented the first formal step to transform Pakistan into an Islamic state.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:13_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-118">[114]</a></sup> Muslim League leader <a href="/wiki/Chaudhry_Khaliquzzaman" title="Chaudhry Khaliquzzaman">Chaudhry Khaliquzzaman</a> asserted that Pakistan could only truly become an Islamic state after bringing all believers of Islam into a single political unit.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[157]</a></sup> Keith Callard, one of the earliest scholars on Pakistani politics, observed that Pakistanis believed in the essential unity of purpose and outlook in the Muslim world and assumed that Muslim from other countries would share their views on the relationship between religion and nationality.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg/200px-Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="298" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg/300px-Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/41/Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg 2x" data-file-width="322" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Friday_prayes_at_b.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Friday Prayers at the <a href="/wiki/Badshahi_Mosque" title="Badshahi Mosque">Badshahi Mosque</a> in Lahore
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>However, Pakistan's pan-Islamist sentiments for a united Islamic bloc called Islamistan were not shared by other Muslim governments,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup> although Islamists such as the Grand Mufti of Palestine, Al-Haj Amin al-Husseini, and leaders of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>, became drawn to the country. Pakistan's desire for an international organization of Muslim countries was fulfilled in the 1970s when the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organization of Islamic Conference</a> (OIC) was formed.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[160]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The strongest opposition to the Islamist ideological paradigm being imposed on the state came from the Bengali Muslims of East Pakistan<sup id="cite_ref-Haqqani2010_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haqqani2010-165">[161]</a></sup> whose educated class, according to a survey by social scientist Nasim Ahmad Jawed, preferred secularism and focused on ethnic identity unlike educated West Pakistanis who tended to prefer an Islamic identity.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> The Islamist party <a href="/wiki/Jamaat-e-Islami" title="Jamaat-e-Islami">Jamaat-e-Islami</a> considered Pakistan to be an Islamic state and believed Bengali nationalism to be unacceptable. In the 1971 conflict over East Pakistan, the Jamaat-e-Islami fought the Bengali nationalists on the Pakistan Army's side.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After Pakistan's first ever general elections, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1973_constitution_of_Pakistan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1973 constitution of Pakistan (page does not exist)">1973 Constitution</a> was created by an elected Parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup> The Constitution declared Pakistan an Islamic Republic and Islam as the state religion. It also stated that all laws would have to be brought into accordance with the injunctions of Islam as laid down in the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sunnah" title="Sunnah">Sunnah</a> and that no law repugnant to such injunctions could be enacted.<sup id="cite_ref-:8_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-169">[165]</a></sup> The 1973 Constitution also created certain institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Shariat</a> Court and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Islamic_Ideology" title="Council of Islamic Ideology">Council of Islamic Ideology</a> to channel the interpretation and application of Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-:9_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:9-170">[166]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan's leftist Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto" title="Zulfikar Ali Bhutto">Zulfikar Ali Bhutto</a> faced vigorous opposition which coalesced into a movement united under the revivalist banner of <i>Nizam-e-Mustafa</i> ("Rule of the <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Prophet</a>")<sup id="cite_ref-nasr-45_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nasr-45-171">[167]</a></sup> which aimed to establish an Islamic state based on Sharia laws. Bhutto agreed to some Islamist demands before being overthrown in a coup.<sup id="cite_ref-Kepel-1002_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kepel-1002-172">[168]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1977, after taking power from Bhutto in a coup d'Ã©tat, General <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Zia-ul-Haq" title="Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq">Zia-ul-Haq</a>, who came from a religious background,<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup> committed himself to establishing an Islamic state and enforcing <i><a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">sharia</a></i> law.<sup id="cite_ref-Kepel-1002_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kepel-1002-172">[168]</a></sup> Zia established separate Shariat judicial courts<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> and court benches<sup id="cite_ref-HRWdouble-19_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRWdouble-19-175">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-United_Book_Press_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_Book_Press-176">[172]</a></sup> to judge legal cases using Islamic doctrine.<sup id="cite_ref-wynbr-2009_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wynbr-2009-177">[173]</a></sup> Zia bolstered the influence of the <i><a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulama</a></i> (Islamic clergy) and the Islamic parties.<sup id="cite_ref-wynbr-2009_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wynbr-2009-177">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Zia-ul-Haq" title="Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq">Zia-ul-Haq</a> forged a strong alliance between the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_army" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan army">military</a> and Deobandi institutions<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> and even though most Barelvi ulama<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[175]</a></sup> and only a few Deobandi scholars had supported Pakistan's creation, Islamic state politics came to be mostly in favour of <a href="/wiki/Deobandi" title="Deobandi">Deobandi</a> (and later Ahl-e-Hadith/<a href="/wiki/Salafi" class="mw-redirect" title="Salafi">Salafi</a>) institutions instead of Barelvi.<sup id="cite_ref-:10_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:10-180">[176]</a></sup> Sectarian tensions increased with Zia's anti-Shia policies.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[177]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a> (PEW) opinion poll, a majority of Pakistanis support making Sharia the official law of the land.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[178]</a></sup> In a survey of several Muslim countries, PEW also found that Pakistanis tend to identify with their religion more than their nationality in contrast to Muslims in other nations such as <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[179]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span id="Geography.2C_environment.2C_and_climate"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography,_environment,_and_climate">Geography, environment, and climate</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_extreme_weather_records_in_Pakistan" title="List of extreme weather records in Pakistan">Extreme weather records in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Pakistan" title="Geography of Pakistan">Geography of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Pakistan" title="Environment of Pakistan">Environment of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Pakistan" title="Climate of Pakistan">Climate of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclones_and_tornadoes_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical cyclones and tornadoes in Pakistan">Tropical cyclones and tornadoes in Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_beaches_in_Pakistan" title="List of beaches in Pakistan">List of beaches in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg/200px-Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="262" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg/300px-Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg/400px-Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="1700"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Indus.A2002274.0610.1km.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A satellite image showing the topography of Pakistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg/290px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg/435px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg/580px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1448" data-file-height="850"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_PAK_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a> of Pakistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Pakistan" title="Geography of Pakistan">geography</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Pakistan" title="Climate of Pakistan">climate</a> of Pakistan are extremely diverse, and the country is home to a wide variety of <a href="/wiki/Wildlife" title="Wildlife">wildlife</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ministry_of_Information,_Broadcasting,_and_National_Heritage_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ministry_of_Information,_Broadcasting,_and_National_Heritage-184">[180]</a></sup> Pakistan covers an area of 881,913&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (340,509&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), approximately equal to the combined land areas of France and the United Kingdom. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by area">33rd-largest nation by total area</a>, although this ranking varies depending on how the disputed territory of Kashmir is counted. Pakistan has a 1,046&nbsp;km (650&nbsp;mi) coastline along the Arabian Sea and the Gulf of Oman in the south<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> and land borders of 6,774&nbsp;km (4,209&nbsp;mi) in total: 2,430&nbsp;km (1,510&nbsp;mi) with Afghanistan, 523&nbsp;km (325&nbsp;mi) with <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic of China">China</a>, 2,912&nbsp;km (1,809&nbsp;mi) with India and 909&nbsp;km (565&nbsp;mi) with <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup> It shares a marine border with Oman,<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[183]</a></sup> and is separated from Tajikistan by the cold, narrow <a href="/wiki/Wakhan_Corridor" title="Wakhan Corridor">Wakhan Corridor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[184]</a></sup> Pakistan occupies a geopolitically important location at the crossroads of South Asia, the Middle East, and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-yasmeen_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yasmeen-189">[185]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Geologically, Pakistan is located in the IndusâTsangpo Suture Zone and overlaps the <a href="/wiki/Indian_plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian plate">Indian tectonic plate</a> in its Sindh and Punjab provinces; Balochistan and most of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are within the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_plate" class="mw-redirect" title="Eurasian plate">Eurasian plate</a>, mainly on the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_plateau" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian plateau">Iranian plateau</a>. GilgitâBaltistan and Azad Kashmir lie along the edge of the Indian plate and hence are <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Pakistan" title="List of earthquakes in Pakistan">prone to violent earthquakes</a>. This region has the highest rates of <a href="/wiki/Seismicity" title="Seismicity">seismicity</a> and the largest earthquakes in the Himalaya region.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[186]</a></sup> Ranging from the coastal areas of the south to the glaciated mountains of the north, Pakistan's landscapes vary from plains to deserts, forests, hills, and plateaus.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan is divided into three major geographic areas: the northern highlands, the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> plain, and the Balochistan Plateau.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> The northern highlands contain the <a href="/wiki/Karakoram" title="Karakoram">Karakoram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir</a> mountain ranges (see <a href="/wiki/Mountains_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountains of Pakistan">mountains of Pakistan</a>), which contain some of the world's highest peaks, including five of the fourteen <a href="/wiki/Eight-thousanders" class="mw-redirect" title="Eight-thousanders">eight-thousanders</a> (mountain peaks over 8,000 metres or 26,250 feet), which attract adventurers and mountaineers from all over the world, notably <a href="/wiki/K2" title="K2">K2</a> (8,611&nbsp;m or 28,251&nbsp;ft) and <a href="/wiki/Nanga_Parbat" title="Nanga Parbat">Nanga Parbat</a> (8,126&nbsp;m or 26,660&nbsp;ft).<sup id="cite_ref-mountains_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mountains-193">[189]</a></sup> The Balochistan Plateau lies in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Thar_Desert" title="Thar Desert">Thar Desert</a> in the east. The 1,609&nbsp;km (1,000&nbsp;mi) Indus River and its tributaries flow through the country from the Kashmir region to the Arabian Sea. There is an expanse of alluvial plains along it in the Punjab and Sindh.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The climate varies from tropical to temperate, with arid conditions in the coastal south. There is a <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> season with frequent flooding due to heavy rainfall, and a dry season with significantly less rainfall or none at all. There are four distinct seasons in Pakistan: a cool, dry winter from December through February; a hot, dry spring from March through May; the summer rainy season, or southwest monsoon period, from June through September; and the retreating monsoon period of October and November.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_77-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-77">[73]</a></sup> Rainfall varies greatly from year to year, and patterns of alternate flooding and drought are common.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora_and_fauna">Flora and fauna</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Pakistan" title="Flora of Pakistan">Flora of Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Pakistan" title="Fauna of Pakistan">Fauna of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The diversity of the landscape and climate in Pakistan allows a wide variety of trees and plants to flourish. The forests range from coniferous <a href="/wiki/Alpine_plant" title="Alpine plant">alpine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Subalpine" class="mw-redirect" title="Subalpine">subalpine</a> trees such as <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">spruce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Deodar_cedar" class="mw-redirect" title="Deodar cedar">deodar cedar</a> in the extreme northern mountains to <a href="/wiki/Deciduous" title="Deciduous">deciduous</a> trees in most of the country (for example, the mulberry-like <a href="/wiki/Dalbergia_sissoo" title="Dalbergia sissoo">shisham</a> found in the <a href="/wiki/Sulaiman_Mountains" title="Sulaiman Mountains">Sulaiman Mountains</a>), to palms such as <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconut</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phoenix_dactylifera" class="mw-redirect" title="Phoenix dactylifera">date</a> in the southern Punjab, southern Balochistan, and all of Sindh. The western hills are home to <a href="/wiki/Juniper" title="Juniper">juniper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamarisk" class="mw-redirect" title="Tamarisk">tamarisk</a>, coarse grasses, and scrub plants. <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">Mangrove</a> forests form much of the coastal wetlands along the coast in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[192]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:179px;max-width:179px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_(Ursus_arctos_isabellinus).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg/175px-Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg/263px-Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg/350px-Medv%C4%9Bd_plav%C3%BD_%28Ursus_arctos_isabellinus%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Bear
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tibetan_Wolf.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Tibetan_Wolf.JPG/175px-Tibetan_Wolf.JPG" decoding="async" width="175" height="140" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Tibetan_Wolf.JPG/263px-Tibetan_Wolf.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Tibetan_Wolf.JPG/350px-Tibetan_Wolf.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3150" data-file-height="2513"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Tibetan wolf
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Coniferous forests are found at altitudes ranging from 1,000 to 4,000 metres (3,300 to 13,100 feet) in most of the northern and northwestern highlands. In the <a href="/wiki/Xeric" class="mw-redirect" title="Xeric">xeric</a> regions of Balochistan, date palm and <i><a href="/wiki/Ephedra_(genus)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ephedra (genus)">Ephedra</a></i> are common. In most of the Punjab and Sindh, the Indus plains support tropical and subtropical dry and moist broadleaf forest as well as tropical and xeric shrublands. These forests are mostly of <a href="/wiki/Mulberry" class="mw-redirect" title="Mulberry">mulberry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acacia" title="Acacia">acacia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eucalyptus" title="Eucalyptus">eucalyptus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> About 2.2% or 1,687,000 hectares (16,870&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>) of Pakistan was forested in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[194]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The fauna of Pakistan also reflects the country's varied climate. Around 668 bird species are found there,<sup id="cite_ref-wwf11_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf11-199">[195]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bio_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bio-200">[196]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Crow" title="Crow">crows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_World_sparrow" title="Old World sparrow">sparrows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acridotheres" title="Acridotheres">mynas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawk" title="Hawk">hawks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Falcon" title="Falcon">falcons</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eagle" title="Eagle">eagles</a>. <a href="/wiki/Palas,_Kohistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Palas, Kohistan">Palas, Kohistan</a>, has a significant population of <a href="/wiki/Western_tragopan" title="Western tragopan">western tragopan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup> Many birds sighted in Pakistan are migratory, coming from Europe, Central Asia, and India.<sup id="cite_ref-GrimmettRoberts2009_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GrimmettRoberts2009-202">[198]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The southern plains are home to <a href="/wiki/Mongoose" title="Mongoose">mongooses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Small_Indian_civet" title="Small Indian civet">small Indian civet</a>, hares, the <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_jackal" class="mw-redirect" title="Asiatic jackal">Asiatic jackal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indian_pangolin" title="Indian pangolin">Indian pangolin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Jungle_cat" title="Jungle cat">jungle cat</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Desert_cat" class="mw-redirect" title="Desert cat">desert cat</a>. There are <a href="/wiki/Mugger_crocodile" title="Mugger crocodile">mugger crocodiles</a> in the Indus, and <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a>, deer, <a href="/wiki/Indian_porcupine" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian porcupine">porcupines</a>, and small rodents in the surrounding areas. The sandy scrublands of central Pakistan are home to Asiatic jackals, <a href="/wiki/Striped_hyena" title="Striped hyena">striped hyenas</a>, wildcats, and <a href="/wiki/Leopards" class="mw-redirect" title="Leopards">leopards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sheet_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheet-203">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-animal_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-animal-204">[200]</a></sup> The lack of vegetative cover, the severe climate, and the impact of grazing on the deserts have left wild animals in a precarious position. The <a href="/wiki/Chinkara" title="Chinkara">chinkara</a> is the only animal that can still be found in significant numbers in <a href="/wiki/Cholistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Cholistan">Cholistan</a>. A small number of <a href="/wiki/Nilgai" title="Nilgai">nilgai</a> are found along the PakistanâIndia border and in some parts of Cholistan.<sup id="cite_ref-sheet_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheet-203">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ShackletonGroup1997_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ShackletonGroup1997-205">[201]</a></sup> A wide variety of animals live in the mountainous north, including the <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_sheep" title="Marco Polo sheep">Marco Polo sheep</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Urial" title="Urial">urial</a> (a subspecies of wild sheep), the <a href="/wiki/Markhor" title="Markhor">markhor</a> goat, the <a href="/wiki/Ibex" title="Ibex">ibex</a> goat, the <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Himalayan_brown_bear" title="Himalayan brown bear">Himalayan brown bear</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sheet_203-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sheet-203">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wwf_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf-206">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wes_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wes-207">[203]</a></sup> Among the rare animals found in the area are the <a href="/wiki/Snow_leopard" title="Snow leopard">snow leopard</a><sup id="cite_ref-wwf_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf-206">[202]</a></sup> and the blind <a href="/wiki/Indus_river_dolphin" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus river dolphin">Indus river dolphin</a>, of which there are believed to be about 1,100 remaining, protected at the Indus River Dolphin Reserve in Sindh.<sup id="cite_ref-wwf_206-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf-206">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Heiden_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heiden-208">[204]</a></sup> In total, 174 mammals, 177 reptiles, 22 amphibians, 198 freshwater fish species and 5,000 species of invertebrates (including insects) have been recorded in Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-wwf11_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf11-199">[195]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bio_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bio-200">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The flora and fauna of Pakistan suffer from a number of problems. Pakistan has the second-highest rate of deforestation in the world, which, along with hunting and pollution, has had adverse effects on the ecosystem. It had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.42/10, ranking it 41st globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-209">[205]</a></sup> The government has established a large number of protected areas, wildlife sanctuaries, and game reserves to address these issues.<sup id="cite_ref-wwf11_199-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wwf11-199">[195]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bio_200-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bio-200">[196]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Pakistan" title="Politics of Pakistan">Politics of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_history_of_Pakistan" title="Political history of Pakistan">Political history of Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Pakistan" title="Human rights in Pakistan">Human rights in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Parliament_House,_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/220px-Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/330px-Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/440px-Parliament_House%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1746" data-file-height="1164"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Parliament_House,_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Pakistan" title="Parliament of Pakistan">Parliament House</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan's political experience is essentially related to the struggle of Indian Muslims to regain the power they lost to British colonisation.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[206]</a></sup> Pakistan is a democratic <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_parliamentary_republic" title="Federal parliamentary republic">federal republic</a>, with Islam as the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Article_2_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Article_2-4">[4]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan_of_1956" title="Constitution of Pakistan of 1956">first constitution</a> was adopted in 1956 but suspended by Ayub Khan in 1958, who replaced it with the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan_of_1962" title="Constitution of Pakistan of 1962">second constitution</a> in 1962.<sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_Institution_Press-86">[82]</a></sup> A complete and comprehensive <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">constitution</a> was adopted in 1973, it was suspended by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Zia-ul-Haq" title="Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq">Zia-ul-Haq</a> in 1977 but reinstated in 1985. This constitution is the country's most important document, laying the foundations of the current government.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup> The Pakistani military establishment has played an influential role in mainstream politics throughout <a href="/wiki/Political_history_of_Pakistan" title="Political history of Pakistan">Pakistan's political history</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_Institution_Press-86">[82]</a></sup> The periods 1958â1971, <a href="/wiki/1977_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" class="mw-redirect" title="1977 Pakistani coup d'Ã©tat">1977â1988</a>, and 1999â2008 saw <a href="/wiki/Military_coups_in_Pakistan" title="Military coups in Pakistan">military coups</a> that resulted in the imposition of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Martial law in Pakistan">martial law</a> and military commanders who governed as de&nbsp;facto presidents.<sup id="cite_ref-military_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-military-211">[207]</a></sup> Today Pakistan has a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> with clear <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">division of powers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Check_and_balance" class="mw-redirect" title="Check and balance">checks and balances</a> among the branches of government. The first successful <a href="/wiki/2013_Pakistani_general_election" title="2013 Pakistani general election">democratic transition</a> occurred in May 2013. <a href="/wiki/Politics_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Politics in Pakistan">Politics in Pakistan</a> is centred on, and dominated by, a homegrown <a href="/wiki/Social_philosophy" title="Social philosophy">social philosophy</a> comprising a blend of ideas from <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan" title="Socialism in Pakistan">socialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_Pakistan" title="Conservatism in Pakistan">conservatism</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Third_Way" title="Third Way">third way</a>. As of the <a href="/wiki/2013_Pakistani_general_election" title="2013 Pakistani general election">general elections</a> held in 2013, the three main political parties in the country are: the <a href="/wiki/Centre-right_politics" title="Centre-right politics">centre-right</a> <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_Pakistan" title="Conservatism in Pakistan">conservative</a> <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Muslim_League_(N)" title="Pakistan Muslim League (N)">Pakistan Muslim League-N</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Centre-left_politics" title="Centre-left politics">centre-left</a> <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan" title="Socialism in Pakistan">socialist</a> PPP; and the <a href="/wiki/Centre_politics" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre politics">centrist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_way_politics" class="mw-redirect" title="Third way politics">third-way</a> <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Tehreek-e-Insaf" title="Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf">Pakistan Movement for Justice</a> (PTI). </p> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Head_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Head of State">Head of State</a>: The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Pakistan" title="President of Pakistan">President</a>, who is elected by an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_College_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Electoral College of Pakistan">Electoral College</a> is the ceremonial head of the state and is the civilian <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces" title="Pakistan Armed Forces">Pakistan Armed Forces</a> (with the <a href="/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee</a> as principal military adviser), but military appointments and key confirmations in the armed forces are made by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_minister_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> after reviewing the reports on candidates' merit and performance. Almost all appointed officers in the <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Pakistan" title="Judiciary of Pakistan">judicature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_military" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani military">military</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">chairman joint chiefs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">joint staff</a>, and legislature require the executive confirmation from the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a>, whom the President must consult by law. However, the powers to pardon and grant clemency lie with the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Pakistan" title="President of Pakistan">President of Pakistan</a>.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Legislative" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative">Legislative</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> legislature comprises a 104-member <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Pakistan" title="Senate of Pakistan">Senate</a> (<a href="/wiki/Upper_House" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper House">upper house</a>) and a 342-member <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" title="National Assembly of Pakistan">National Assembly</a> (<a href="/wiki/Lower_House" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower House">lower house</a>). <a href="/wiki/Member_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Member of the National Assembly of Pakistan">Members</a> of the National Assembly are elected through the <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post" class="mw-redirect" title="First-past-the-post">first-past-the-post</a> system under <a href="/wiki/Universal_adult_suffrage" class="mw-redirect" title="Universal adult suffrage">universal adult suffrage</a>, representing electoral districts known as National Assembly <a href="/wiki/Constituencies_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Constituencies of Pakistan">constituencies</a>. According to the constitution, the 70 seats reserved for women and religious minorities are allocated to the political parties according to their proportional representation. Senate members are elected by provincial legislators, with all the provinces having equal representation.</li>
      </ul> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg/220px-A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg/330px-A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg/440px-A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:A_night_side_view_of_Prime_Minister%27s_Secretariat_Building.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Pakistan)" title="Prime Minister's Office (Pakistan)">Prime Minister's Office</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>Executive: The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> is usually the leader of the <a href="/wiki/Majority_rule" title="Majority rule">majority rule</a> party or a coalition in the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly (Pakistan)">National Assembly</a>â the <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> serves as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and is designated to exercise as the country's chief executive. The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a> is responsible for appointing a <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Pakistan" title="Cabinet of Pakistan">cabinet</a> consisting of ministers and advisers as well as running the government operations, taking and authorising executive decisions, appointments and recommendations of <a href="/wiki/Central_Superior_Services" title="Central Superior Services">senior civil servants</a> that require executive confirmation of the Prime Minister.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_provincial_governments_of_Pakistan" title="List of provincial governments of Pakistan">Provincial governments</a>: Each of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Provinces_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Four Provinces (Pakistan)">four provinces</a> has a similar <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chief_Ministers_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Chief Ministers in Pakistan">system of government</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Pakistan" title="Elections in Pakistan">directly elected</a> <a href="/wiki/Category:Provincial_Assemblies_of_Pakistan" title="Category:Provincial Assemblies of Pakistan">Provincial Assembly</a> in which the leader of the largest party or coalition is elected <a href="/wiki/Chief_Minister_(Pakistan)" title="Chief Minister (Pakistan)">Chief Minister</a>. Chief Ministers oversee the <a href="/wiki/List_of_provincial_governments_of_Pakistan" title="List of provincial governments of Pakistan">provincial governments</a> and head the provincial cabinet. It is common in Pakistan to have different ruling parties or coalitions in each of the provinces. The provincial bureaucracy is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Secretary_(Pakistan)" title="Chief Secretary (Pakistan)">Chief Secretary</a>, who is appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister</a>. The provincial assemblies have power to make laws and approve the provincial budget which is commonly presented by the provincial finance minister every fiscal year. <a href="/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Governors of Pakistan">Provincial governors</a> who are the ceremonial heads of the provinces are appointed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Pakistan" title="President of Pakistan">President</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan,_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/220px-Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/330px-Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg/440px-Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan%2C_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1840" data-file-height="1232"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan,_Islamabad_by_Usman_Ghani.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan" title="Supreme Court of Pakistan">Supreme Court of Pakistan</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Pakistan" title="Judiciary of Pakistan">Judicature</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Court_system_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Court system of Pakistan">judiciary</a> of Pakistan is a hierarchical system with two classes of courts: the superior (or higher) judiciary and the subordinate (or lower) judiciary. The <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Pakistan" title="Chief Justice of Pakistan">Chief Justice of Pakistan</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Chief_judge" title="Chief judge">chief judge</a> who oversees the judicature's <a href="/wiki/Court_system_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Court system of Pakistan">court system</a> at all levels of command. The superior judiciary is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan" title="Supreme Court of Pakistan">Supreme Court of Pakistan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Shariat_Court" title="Federal Shariat Court">Federal Shariat Court</a> and five <a href="/wiki/High_Courts_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="High Courts of Pakistan">High Courts</a>, with the Supreme Court at the apex. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">Constitution of Pakistan</a> entrusts the superior judiciary with the obligation to preserve, protect and defend the constitution.Other regions of <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a> have separate court systems.</li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Pakistan" title="Foreign relations of Pakistan">Foreign relations of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan,_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg" class="image"><img alt="(LâR) English: Motorcade for President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan. In open car (Lincoln-Mercury Continental with bubble top): Secret Service agent William Greer (driving); Military Aide to the President General Chester V. Clifton (front seat, centre); Secret Service Agent Gerald &quot;Jerry&quot; Behn (front seat, right, partially hidden); President Mohammad Ayub Khan (standing); President John F. Kennedy (standing). Crowd watching. 14th Street, Washington, D.C." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg/200px-Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="308" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg/300px-Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg/400px-Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan%2C_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg 2x" data-file-width="445" data-file-height="685"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Motorcade_in_Arrival_Ceremonies_for_Muhammad_Ayub_Khan,_President_of_Pakistan_use.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ayub_Khan_(President_of_Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)">Ayub Khan (President of Pakistan)</a> with U.S. President <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> in 1961.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since Independence, Pakistan has attempted to balance its relations with foreign nations.<sup id="cite_ref-Deep_&amp;_Deep_Publ._212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deep_&amp;_Deep_Publ.-212">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lancer_Publ._213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancer_Publ.-213">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DND_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DND-214">[210]</a></sup> Pakistan is a strong ally of China, with both countries placing considerable importance on the maintenance of an extremely close and supportive <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations" title="ChinaâPakistan relations">special relationship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcnews_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews-215">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nyt_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-216">[212]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[213]</a></sup> It is also a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a> of the United States in the <a href="/wiki/War_against_terrorism" class="mw-redirect" title="War against terrorism">war against terrorism</a>âa status achieved in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-Oxford_University_Press,_Shahi_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_University_Press,_Shahi-218">[214]</a></sup> Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign policy of Pakistan">foreign policy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_geostrategy" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani geostrategy">geostrategy</a> mainly focus on the economy and security against threats to its <a href="/wiki/Nationalism_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalism in Pakistan">national identity</a> and territorial integrity, and on the cultivation of close relations with other Muslim countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Govt_of_Pakistan_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Govt_of_Pakistan-219">[215]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_conflict" title="Kashmir conflict">Kashmir conflict</a> remains the major point of contention between Pakistan and India; three of their <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts" title="Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts">four wars</a> were fought over this territory.<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir1_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir1-220">[216]</a></sup> Due partly to difficulties in relations with its geopolitical rival India, Pakistan maintains close political relations with Turkey and Iran,<sup id="cite_ref-AuthorHouse._2006_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AuthorHouse._2006-221">[217]</a></sup> and both countries have been a focal point in Pakistan's foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-AuthorHouse._2006_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AuthorHouse._2006-221">[217]</a></sup> Saudi Arabia also maintains a respected position in Pakistan's foreign policy. </p>
      <p>A non-signatory party of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on Nuclear Non-Proliferation</a>, Pakistan is an influential member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">IAEA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Routledge,_UK_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Routledge,_UK-222">[218]</a></sup> In recent events, Pakistan has blocked an <a href="/wiki/Fissile_Material_Cut-off_Treaty" title="Fissile Material Cut-off Treaty">international treaty</a> to limit <a href="/wiki/Fissile_material" title="Fissile material">fissile material</a>, arguing that the "treaty would target Pakistan specifically".<sup id="cite_ref-NPT_News_Directorate_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPT_News_Directorate-223">[219]</a></sup> In the 20th century, Pakistan's nuclear deterrence program focused on countering India's nuclear ambitions in the <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">region</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pokhran-II" title="Pokhran-II">nuclear tests</a> by India eventually led Pakistan to <a href="/wiki/Pakistan%27s_nuclear_testing_series" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan's nuclear testing series">reciprocate</a> to maintain a geopolitical balance as becoming a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Pakistan" title="Nuclear power in Pakistan">nuclear power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[220]</a></sup> Currently, Pakistan maintains a policy of <a href="/wiki/N-deterrence" title="N-deterrence">credible minimum deterrence</a>, calling its program vital <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_its_Nuclear_Deterrent_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program">nuclear deterrence</a> against foreign aggression.<sup id="cite_ref-United_Book_Press._225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_Book_Press.-225">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Located in the strategic and geopolitical corridor of the world's major maritime oil supply lines and communication fibre optics, Pakistan has proximity to the natural resources of Central Asian countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Tauris_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tauris-227">[223]</a></sup> Briefing on the country's foreign policy in 2004, a <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Senate" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Senate">Pakistani senator</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2017)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> reportedly explained: "Pakistan highlights sovereign equality of states, bilateralism, mutuality of interests, and non-interference in each other's domestic affairs as the cardinal features of its foreign policy."<sup id="cite_ref-rizvi_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rizvi-228">[224]</a></sup> Pakistan is an active member of the United Nations and has a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Representative_of_Pakistan_to_the_United_Nations" title="Permanent Representative of Pakistan to the United Nations">Permanent Representative</a> to represent Pakistan's positions in international politics.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup> Pakistan has lobbied for the concept of "<a href="/wiki/Enlightened_moderation" title="Enlightened moderation">enlightened moderation</a>" in the Muslim world.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup> Pakistan is also a member of Commonwealth of Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation" title="South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation">South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation</a> (SAARC), the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">Economic Cooperation Organization</a> (ECO),<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[230]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/G20_developing_nations" title="G20 developing nations">G20 developing nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg/220px-Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg/330px-Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg/440px-Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Meeting_of_SCO_leaders_-_20190614_-_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pakistani Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Imran_Khan" title="Imran Khan">Imran Khan</a> at the 2019 <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation</a> summit
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Due to ideological differences, Pakistan opposed the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> in the 1950s. During the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a> in the 1980s, Pakistan was one of the closest allies of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-rizvi_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rizvi-228">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mostallied_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mostallied-236">[232]</a></sup> Relations between Pakistan and Russia have greatly improved since 1999, and co-operation in various sectors has increased.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn,_2015_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn,_2015-237">[233]</a></sup> Pakistan has had an "on-and-off" relationship with the United States. A close ally of the United States during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Cold war">Cold war</a>, Pakistan's relationship with the United States soured in the 1990s when the US <a href="/wiki/Pressler_amendment" class="mw-redirect" title="Pressler amendment">imposed sanctions</a> because of Pakistan's secretive nuclear development.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[234]</a></sup> Since <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">9/11</a>, Pakistan has been a close ally of the United States on the issue of <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> in the regions of the Middle East and South Asia, with the US supporting Pakistan with aid money and weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup> Initially, the United States-led war on terrorism led to an improvement in the relationship, but it was strained by a divergence of interests and resulting mistrust during the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)">war in Afghanistan</a> and by issues related to terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-mondediplo2007_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mondediplo2007-241">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[238]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan does not have <a href="/wiki/Pakistan-Israel_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan-Israel relations">diplomatic relations</a> with <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Washington_Post,_Pakistan_Bureau_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Washington_Post,_Pakistan_Bureau-245">[241]</a></sup> nonetheless, some Israeli citizens have visited the country on tourist visas.<sup id="cite_ref-Haaretz_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haaretz-246">[242]</a></sup> However, an exchange took place between the two countries using Turkey as a communication conduit.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[243]</a></sup> Despite Pakistan being the only country in the world that has not established <a href="/wiki/Armenia%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations" title="ArmeniaâPakistan relations">diplomatic relations</a> with <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Pakistan" title="Armenians in Pakistan">Armenian community</a> still resides in Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-Armenian_Times_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Armenian_Times-248">[244]</a></sup> Pakistan had warm relations with Bangladesh, despite some initial strains in their relationship. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Relations_with_China">Relations with China</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations" title="ChinaâPakistan relations">ChinaâPakistan relations</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg/200px-Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="285" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg/300px-Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg/400px-Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="911"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy_and_Zhou_Enlai_signing_the_Treaty_of_Friendship_Between_China_and_Pakistan_in_Beijing.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pakistan Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Huseyn_Shaheed_Suhrawardy" title="Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy">Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy</a> with Chinese Premier <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a> signing the Treaty of Friendship Between China and Pakistan. Pakistan is host to China's largest embassy.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan was one of the first countries to establish formal diplomatic relations with the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a>, and the relationship continues to be strong since China's <a href="/wiki/Sino-Indian_War" title="Sino-Indian War">war</a> with India in 1962, forming a special relationship.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan-250">[246]</a></sup> From the 1960s to 1980s, Pakistan greatly helped China in reaching out to the world's major countries and helped facilitate US President <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Nixon</a>'s <a href="/wiki/1972_Nixon_visit_to_China" class="mw-redirect" title="1972 Nixon visit to China">state visit</a> to China.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan_250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan-250">[246]</a></sup> Despite the change of <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">governments</a> in Pakistan and fluctuations in the regional and global situation, China's policy in Pakistan continues to be a dominant factor at all times.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan_250-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_on_Foreign_Relations,_China_Pakistan-250">[246]</a></sup> In return, China is Pakistan's largest trading partner, and economic co-operation has flourished, with substantial Chinese investment in Pakistan's infrastructural expansion such as the Pakistani deep-water port at <a href="/wiki/Gwadar" title="Gwadar">Gwadar</a>. Friendly Sino-Pakistani relations reached new heights as both countries signed 51 agreements and Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) in 2015 for co-operation in different areas.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-china_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china-252">[248]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup> Both countries signed a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="ChinaâPakistan Free Trade Agreement">Free Trade Agreement</a> in the 2000s, and Pakistan continues to serve as China's communication bridge to the Muslim world.<sup id="cite_ref-Stanford_University_Press,_California,_[u.s]_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stanford_University_Press,_California,_[u.s]-255">[251]</a></sup> In 2016, China announced that it will set up an anti-terrorism alliance with Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Tajikistan.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup> In December 2018, Pakistan's government defended China's <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_re-education_camps" class="mw-redirect" title="Xinjiang re-education camps">re-education camps</a> for a million <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghur</a> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[254]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Emphasis_on_relations_with_Muslim_world">Emphasis on relations with Muslim world</span></h4> 
      <p>After Independence, Pakistan vigorously pursued bilateral relations with other Muslim countries<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> and made an active bid for leadership of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a>, or at least for leadership in efforts to achieve unity.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[256]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Maulana_Muhammad_Ali_Jauhar" class="mw-redirect" title="Maulana Muhammad Ali Jauhar">Ali</a> brothers had sought to project Pakistan as the natural leader of the Islamic world, in part due to its large manpower and military strength.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup> A top-ranking <a href="/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League" class="mw-redirect" title="All India Muslim League">Muslim League</a> leader, <a href="/wiki/Chaudhry_Khaliquzzaman" title="Chaudhry Khaliquzzaman">Khaliquzzaman</a>, declared that Pakistan would bring together all Muslim countries into <a href="/wiki/Islamistan" title="Islamistan">Islamistan</a>âa pan-Islamic entity.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[258]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Such developments (along with Pakistan's creation) did not get American approval, and British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Clement_Attlee" title="Clement Attlee">Clement Attlee</a> voiced international opinion at the time by stating that he wished that India and Pakistan would re-unite.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[259]</a></sup> Since most of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> was undergoing a nationalist awakening at the time, there was little attraction to Pakistan's Pan-Islamic aspirations.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> Some of the Arab countries saw the 'Islamistan' project as a Pakistani attempt to dominate other Muslim states.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[261]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan vigorously championed the right of self-determination for Muslims around the world. Pakistan's efforts for the independence movements of Indonesia, Algeria, Tunisia, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, and Eritrea were significant and initially led to close ties between these countries and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup> However, Pakistan also masterminded an attack on the Afghan city of <a href="/wiki/Jalalabad" title="Jalalabad">Jalalabad</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Civil_War_(1989%E2%80%9392)" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan Civil War (1989â92)">Afghan Civil War</a> to establish an Islamic government there. Pakistan had wished to foment an 'Islamic Revolution' that would transcend national borders, covering Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On the other hand, Pakistan's relations with Iran have been strained at times due to sectarian tensions.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[264]</a></sup> Iran and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> used Pakistan as a battleground for their proxy sectarian war, and by the 1990s Pakistan's support for the Sunni <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> organisation in Afghanistan became a problem for <a href="/wiki/Shia" class="mw-redirect" title="Shia">Shia</a> Iran, which opposed a Taliban-controlled Afghanistan.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup> Tensions between Iran and Pakistan intensified in 1998 when Iran accused Pakistan of war crimes after Pakistani warplanes had bombarded Afghanistan's last Shia stronghold in support of the Taliban.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan is an influential and founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a> (OIC). Maintaining cultural, political, social, and economic relations with the <a href="/wiki/Arab_World" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab World">Arab world</a> and other countries in the Muslim world is a vital factor in Pakistan's foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_&amp;_Francis._272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor_&amp;_Francis.-272">[268]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_units_of_Pakistan" title="Administrative units of Pakistan">Administrative units of Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Pakistan" title="Districts of Pakistan">Districts of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="sortable wikitable"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="width:200px;">Administrative division </th> 
         <th style="width:100px;">Capital </th> 
         <th style="width:100px; text-align:right;">Population </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Flag_of_Balochistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Balochistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Flag_of_Balochistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Balochistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Flag_of_Balochistan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Balochistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1728" data-file-height="1152">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan" title="Balochistan, Pakistan">Balochistan</a></td>
