         <td style="text-align:right;">12,344,408 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="datasortkey" data-sort-value="Punjab"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_Punjab.svg/23px-Flag_of_Punjab.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_Punjab.svg/35px-Flag_of_Punjab.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_Punjab.svg/45px-Flag_of_Punjab.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="793" data-file-height="528">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab</a></span></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">110,126,285 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_Sindh.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sindh.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_Sindh.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sindh.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_Sindh.svg/45px-Flag_of_Sindh.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1200">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">47,886,051 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg/23px-Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg/35px-Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg/45px-Flag_of_Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="793" data-file-height="528">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber Pakhtunkhwa</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">40,525,047 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg/22px-Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="22" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg/33px-Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg/43px-Flag_of_Gilgit-Baltistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1129" data-file-height="785">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Gilgit-Baltistan" title="Gilgit-Baltistan">Gilgit-Baltistan</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Gilgit" title="Gilgit">Gilgit</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1,800,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg/23px-Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg/35px-Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg/45px-Flag_of_Azad_Kashmir.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="648" data-file-height="432">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Muzaffarabad" title="Muzaffarabad">Muzaffarabad</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">4,567,982 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Islamabad_Capital_Territory" title="Islamabad Capital Territory">Islamabad Capital Territory</a></td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">2,851,868 </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Federal_parliamentary_republic" title="Federal parliamentary republic">federal parliamentary republic</a> state, Pakistan is a federation that comprises <a href="/wiki/Four_Provinces_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Four Provinces (Pakistan)">four provinces</a>: <a href="/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab</a>, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Sindh and Balochistan,<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[269]</a></sup> and three <a href="/wiki/Administrative_units_of_Pakistan" title="Administrative units of Pakistan">territories</a>: <a href="/wiki/Islamabad_Capital_Territory" title="Islamabad Capital Territory">Islamabad Capital Territory</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a> exercises the <a href="/wiki/De_facto_standard" title="De facto standard"><i>de facto</i></a> jurisdiction over the <a href="/wiki/Frontier_Regions" title="Frontier Regions">Frontier Regions</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Kashmir">western parts</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir Region">Kashmir Regions</a>, which are organised into the separate political entities <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a> (formerly Northern Areas). In 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">constitutional assignment</a> (<span style="font-size:85%;">the <i>GilgitâBaltistan Empowerment and Self-Governance Order</i></span>) awarded the <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a> a <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Provinces of Pakistan">semi-provincial status</a>, giving it self-government.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[270]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Pakistan" title="Local government in Pakistan">local government</a> system consists of a three-tier system of <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Districts of pakistan">districts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tehsil" title="Tehsil">tehsils</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Union_Councils_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Union Councils of Pakistan">union councils</a>, with an elected body at each tier.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> There are about 130 districts altogether, of which Azad Kashmir has ten<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[272]</a></sup> and GilgitâBaltistan seven.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[273]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="center">
       <small>Clickable map of the four provinces and three federal territories of Pakistan.</small>
      </div> 
      <div class="center">
       <div class="floatnone">
        <div class="noresize" style="height: 280px; width: 350px; ">
         <map name="ImageMap_43b31873bfc523f9"><area href="/wiki/Balochistan_(Pakistan)" shape="rect" coords="11,141,114,257" alt="Balochistan (Pakistan)" title="Balochistan (Pakistan)"><area href="/wiki/Punjab_(Pakistan)" shape="rect" coords="170,124,240,189" alt="Punjab (Pakistan)" title="Punjab (Pakistan)"><area href="/wiki/Sindh" shape="rect" coords="109,192,187,266" alt="Sindh" title="Sindh"><area href="/wiki/Islamabad_Capital_Territory" shape="rect" coords="214,72,223,77" alt="Islamabad Capital Territory" title="Islamabad Capital Territory"><area href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" shape="rect" coords="152,50,179,119" alt="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa"><area href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" shape="rect" coords="174,14,223,81" alt="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa"><area href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" shape="rect" coords="224,43,242,91" alt="Azad Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir"><area href="/wiki/Gilgit-Baltistan" shape="rect" coords="216,3,288,44" alt="Gilgit-Baltistan" title="Gilgit-Baltistan"></map>
         <img alt="A clickable map of Pakistan exhibiting its administrative units." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/PAK_AU_T1.svg/350px-PAK_AU_T1.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="280" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/PAK_AU_T1.svg/525px-PAK_AU_T1.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/PAK_AU_T1.svg/700px-PAK_AU_T1.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="800" usemap="#ImageMap_43b31873bfc523f9">
         <div style="margin-left: 0px; margin-top: -20px; text-align: left;">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PAK_AU_T1.svg" title="About this image"><img alt="About this image" src="/w/extensions/ImageMap/resources/desc-20.png?15600" style="border: none;"></a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><br> <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Pakistan" title="Law enforcement in Pakistan">Law enforcement</a> is carried out by a joint network of the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Intelligence_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Intelligence Community">intelligence community</a> with jurisdiction limited to the relevant province or territory. The <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Directorate_(Pakistan)" title="National Intelligence Directorate (Pakistan)">National Intelligence Directorate</a> coordinates the information intelligence at both federal and provincial levels; including the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Investigation_Agency" title="Federal Investigation Agency">FIA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(Pakistan)" title="Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)">IB</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_and_Motorway_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="National Highways and Motorway Police">Motorway Police</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_Pakistan" title="Paramilitary forces of Pakistan">paramilitary forces</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Rangers" title="Pakistan Rangers">Pakistan Rangers</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Frontier_Corps" title="Frontier Corps">Frontier Corps</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-law_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-law-278">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan's "premier" intelligence agency, the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Services_Intelligence" title="Inter-Services Intelligence">Inter-Services Intelligence</a> (ISI), was formed just within a year after the Independence of Pakistan in 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup> ABC News Point in 2014 reported that the ISI was ranked as the top intelligence agency in the world<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Zee_News" title="Zee News">Zee News</a> reported the ISI as ranking fifth among the world's most powerful intelligence agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[277]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Court_system_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Court system of Pakistan">court system</a> is organised as a hierarchy, with the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan" title="Supreme Court of Pakistan">Supreme Court</a> at the apex, below which are <a href="/wiki/High_Courts_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="High Courts of Pakistan">High Courts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_Shariat_Court" title="Federal Shariat Court">Federal Shariat Courts</a> (one in each province and one in the federal capital), <a href="/wiki/District_Courts_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="District Courts of Pakistan">District Courts</a> (one in each district), Judicial Magistrate Courts (in every town and city), Executive Magistrate Courts, and civil courts. The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_penal_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan penal code">Penal code</a> has limited jurisdiction in the Tribal Areas, where law is largely derived from tribal customs.<sup id="cite_ref-law_278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-law-278">[274]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[278]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kashmir_conflict">Kashmir conflict</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_conflict" title="Kashmir conflict">Kashmir conflict</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kashmir_map.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Kashmir_map.jpg/200px-Kashmir_map.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="230" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Kashmir_map.jpg/300px-Kashmir_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Kashmir_map.jpg/400px-Kashmir_map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="974" data-file-height="1120"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kashmir_map.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The areas shown in green are the Pakistani-controlled areas.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir region">Kashmir</a>âthe most northwesterly region of South Asiaâis a major <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_problem" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir problem">territorial dispute</a> that has hindered <a href="/wiki/India_Pakistan_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="India Pakistan relations">relations</a> between India and Pakistan. The <a href="/wiki/India_and_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="India and Pakistan">two nations</a> have fought at least <a href="/wiki/India_Pakistan_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="India Pakistan Wars">three large-scale</a> conventional wars in successive years in <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1947">1947</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1965">1965</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">1971</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">conflict</a> in 1971 witnessed Pakistan's unconditional <a href="/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_(1971)" class="mw-redirect" title="Instrument of Surrender (1971)">surrender</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Simla_Agreement" title="Simla Agreement">treaty</a> that subsequently led to the <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="Independence of Bangladesh">independence of Bangladesh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lancer_Publishers,_1996_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lancer_Publishers,_1996-283">[279]</a></sup> Other serious military engagements and skirmishes have included the armed contacts in <a href="/wiki/Siachen_conflict" title="Siachen conflict">Siachen Glacier</a> (1984) and <a href="/wiki/Kargil_War" title="Kargil War">Kargil</a> (1999).<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir1_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir1-220">[216]</a></sup> Approximately 45.1% of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir region">Kashmir region</a> is <a href="/wiki/Indian_controlled_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian controlled Kashmir">controlled</a> by India, which also claims the entire state of Jammu and Kashmir, including most of Jammu, the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_Valley" title="Kashmir Valley">Kashmir Valley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ladakh" title="Ladakh">Ladakh</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Siachen_Glacier" title="Siachen Glacier">Siachen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir1_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir1-220">[216]</a></sup> The claim is contested by Pakistan, which <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">controls</a> approximately 38.2% of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir region">Kashmir region</a>, an area known as the <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir1_220-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir1-220">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[280]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kashmir_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Kashmir_3.jpg/220px-Kashmir_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Kashmir_3.jpg/330px-Kashmir_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Kashmir_3.jpg/440px-Kashmir_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4161" data-file-height="2774"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kashmir_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> is part of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>India claims the Kashmir on the basis of the <a href="/wiki/Instrument_of_Accession_(Jammu_and_Kashmir)" title="Instrument of Accession (Jammu and Kashmir)">Instrument of Accession</a>âa legal agreement with Kashmir's leaders executed by <a href="/wiki/Ruler_of_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Ruler of Kashmir"><i>Maharaja</i></a> <a href="/wiki/Maharaja_Hari_Singh" class="mw-redirect" title="Maharaja Hari Singh">Hari Singh</a>, who agreed to cede the area to India.<sup id="cite_ref-Commons_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Commons-285">[281]</a></sup> Pakistan claims Kashmir on the basis of a Muslim majority and of geography, the same principles that were applied for the creation of the two independent states.<sup id="cite_ref-Amita_Shastri_South_Asia_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amita_Shastri_South_Asia-286">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Joseph_Regional_Geography_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joseph_Regional_Geography-287">[283]</a></sup> India referred the dispute to the United Nations on 1 January 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[284]</a></sup> In a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_38" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 38">resolution</a> passed in 1948, the UN's <a href="/wiki/Un_security_council" class="mw-redirect" title="Un security council">General Assembly</a> asked Pakistan to remove most of its troops as a <a href="/wiki/Plebiscite_in_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Plebiscite in Kashmir"><i>plebiscite</i></a> would then be held. However, Pakistan failed to vacate the region and a <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Agreement" title="Karachi Agreement">ceasefire</a> was reached in 1949 establishing a <a href="/wiki/Line_of_Control" title="Line of Control">Line of Control</a> (LoC) that divided Kashmir between the <a href="/wiki/India_and_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="India and Pakistan">two nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kash_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kash-289">[285]</a></sup> India, fearful that the Muslim majority populace of Kashmir would secede from India, did not allow a plebiscite to take place in the region. This was confirmed in a statement by India's Defense Minister, <a href="/wiki/Krishna_Menon" class="mw-redirect" title="Krishna Menon">Krishna Menon</a>, who said: "Kashmir would vote to join Pakistan and no Indian Government responsible for agreeing to plebiscite would survive."<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[286]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan claims that its position is for the right of the <a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmiri people">people</a> of Jammu and Kashmir to determine their future through impartial elections as mandated by the United Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[287]</a></sup> while India has stated that Kashmir is an <a href="/wiki/Akhand_Bharat" title="Akhand Bharat">integral part</a> of India, referring to the <a href="/wiki/Simla_Agreement" title="Simla Agreement">Simla Agreement</a> (1972) and to the fact that <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir" title="Elections in Jammu and Kashmir">elections</a> take place regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-unhcr2009in_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unhcr2009in-292">[288]</a></sup> In recent developments, certain Kashmiri <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_independence_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashmir independence movement">independence groups</a> believe that Kashmir should be independent of both India and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir1_220-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir1-220">[216]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Pakistan" title="Law enforcement in Pakistan">Law enforcement in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Intelligence_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Intelligence Community">Pakistan Intelligence Community</a>, and <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Directorate_(Pakistan)" title="National Intelligence Directorate (Pakistan)">National Intelligence Directorate (Pakistan)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Pakistan" title="Law enforcement in Pakistan">law enforcement in Pakistan</a> is carried out by joint network of several federal and provincial police agencies. The <a href="/wiki/Administrative_units_of_Pakistan" title="Administrative units of Pakistan">four provinces</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Islamabad_Capital_Territory" title="Islamabad Capital Territory">Islamabad Capital Territory</a> (ICT) each have a civilian police force with jurisdiction extending only to the relevant province or territory.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup> At the federal level, there are a number of civilian <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Intelligence_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Intelligence Community">intelligence agencies</a> with nationwide jurisdictions including the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Investigation_Agency" title="Federal Investigation Agency">Federal Investigation Agency</a> (FIA), <a href="/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(Pakistan)" title="Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)">Intelligence Bureau</a> (IB), and the <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_and_Motorway_Police" class="mw-redirect" title="National Highways and Motorway Police">Motorway Patrol</a>, as well as several <a href="/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_Pakistan" title="Paramilitary forces of Pakistan">paramilitary forces</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_of_Pakistan" title="National Guard of Pakistan">National Guards</a> (<a href="/wiki/Northern_Areas_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Areas of Pakistan">Northern Areas</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Rangers" title="Pakistan Rangers">Rangers</a> (Punjab and Sindh), and the <a href="/wiki/Frontier_Corps" title="Frontier Corps">Frontier Corps</a> (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan). </p>
      <p>The most senior officers of all the civilian police forces also form part of the <a href="/wiki/Police_Service_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Police Service of Pakistan">Police Service</a>, which is a component of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Superior_Services_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Superior Services of Pakistan">civil service</a> of Pakistan. Namely, there is four provincial <a href="/wiki/Police_Service_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Police Service of Pakistan">police service</a> including the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_Police_(Pakistan)" title="Punjab Police (Pakistan)">Punjab Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sindh_Police" title="Sindh Police">Sindh Police</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa_Police" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Police">Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Police</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Balochistan_Police" title="Balochistan Police">Balochistan Police</a>; all headed by the appointed senior <a href="/wiki/Inspector_general" title="Inspector general">Inspector-Generals</a>. The ICT has its own police component, the <a href="/wiki/Capital_Territory_Police" title="Capital Territory Police">Capital Police</a>, to maintain <a href="/wiki/Law_and_order_(politics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Law and order (politics)">law and order</a> in the capital. The <a href="/wiki/Crime_Investigation_Department_(Pakistan)" title="Crime Investigation Department (Pakistan)">CID</a> bureaus are the <a href="/wiki/Crime_investigation" class="mw-redirect" title="Crime investigation">crime investigation</a> unit and form a vital part in each provincial <a href="/wiki/Police_Service_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Police Service of Pakistan">police service</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Pakistan" title="Law enforcement in Pakistan">law enforcement in Pakistan</a> also has a <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_%26_Motorway_Police" title="National Highways &amp; Motorway Police">Motorway Patrol</a> which is responsible for enforcement of traffic and safety laws, security and recovery on Pakistan's inter-provincial <a href="/wiki/Motorways_of_Pakistan" title="Motorways of Pakistan">motorway network</a>. In each of provincial <a href="/wiki/Police_Service_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Police Service of Pakistan">Police Service</a>, it also maintains a respective <a href="/wiki/Elite_Police" title="Elite Police">Elite Police</a> units led by the <a href="/wiki/National_Counter_Terrorism_Authority" title="National Counter Terrorism Authority">NACTA</a>âa counter-terrorism police unit as well as providing VIP escorts. In the Punjab and Sindh, the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Rangers" title="Pakistan Rangers">Pakistan Rangers</a> are an internal security force with the prime objective to provide and maintain security in war zones and areas of conflict as well as maintaining law and order which includes providing assistance to the police.<sup id="cite_ref-npb1_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npb1-293">[289]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Frontier_Corps" title="Frontier Corps">Frontier Corps</a> serves the similar purpose in <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa</a>, and the Balochistan.<sup id="cite_ref-npb1_293-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npb1-293">[289]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Pakistan" title="Human rights in Pakistan">Human rights in Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Pakistan" title="LGBT rights in Pakistan">LGBT rights in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Male <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">homosexuality</a> is illegal in Pakistan and punishable with up to life in prison.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[291]</a></sup> In its 2018 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_without_borders" class="mw-redirect" title="Reporters without borders">Reporters without borders</a> ranked Pakistan number 139 out of 180 countries based on <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[292]</a></sup> Television stations and newspapers are routinely shut down for publishing any reports critical of the government or the military.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[294]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[295]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces" title="Pakistan Armed Forces">Pakistan Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26,660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg/220px-Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg/330px-Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg/440px-Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26%2C660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pakistan_Air_Force_JF-17_Thunder_flies_in_front_of_the_26,660_ft_high_Nanga_Parbat.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force" title="Pakistan Air Force">Pakistan Air Force</a>'s <a href="/wiki/JF-17_Thunder" class="mw-redirect" title="JF-17 Thunder">JF-17 Thunder</a> flying in front of the 8,130-metre-high (26,660-foot) <a href="/wiki/Nanga_Parbat" title="Nanga Parbat">Nanga Parbat</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The armed forces of Pakistan are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by number of troops">sixth largest</a> in the world in terms of numbers in full-time service, with about 651,800 personnel on active duty and 291,000 paramilitary personnel, as of tentative estimates in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-Hackett_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hackett-300">[296]</a></sup> They <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Pakistan" title="Military history of Pakistan">came into existence</a> after independence in 1947, and the military establishment has frequently influenced the <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Pakistan" title="Politics of Pakistan">national politics</a> ever since.<sup id="cite_ref-military_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-military-211">[207]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chain_of_command" class="mw-redirect" title="Chain of command">Chain of command</a> of the military is kept under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee</a>; all of the branches joint works, co-ordination, military logistics, and joint missions are under the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Staff_Headquarters_(Pakistan)" title="Joint Staff Headquarters (Pakistan)">Joint Staff HQ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diane_Publishing_Co.-301">[297]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Joint_Staff_Headquarters_(Pakistan)" title="Joint Staff Headquarters (Pakistan)">Joint Staff HQ</a> is composed of the <a href="/wiki/AHQ_(PAF)" class="mw-redirect" title="AHQ (PAF)">Air HQ</a>, <a href="/wiki/NHQ_(PN)" class="mw-redirect" title="NHQ (PN)">Navy HQ</a>, and <a href="/wiki/General_Headquarters_(Pakistan_Army)" title="General Headquarters (Pakistan Army)">Army GHQ</a> in the vicinity of the <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi_Cantonment" title="Rawalpindi Cantonment">Rawalpindi Military District</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Frankfort,_IL_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frankfort,_IL-302">[298]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee</a> is the highest <a href="/wiki/Staff_Officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Staff Officer">principle staff officer</a> in the armed forces, and the chief military adviser to the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">civilian government</a> though the chairman has no authority over the three branches of armed forces.<sup id="cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diane_Publishing_Co.-301">[297]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">Chairman joint chiefs</a> controls the military from the <a href="/wiki/Joint_Staff_Headquarters_(Pakistan)" title="Joint Staff Headquarters (Pakistan)">JS HQ</a> and maintains strategic communications between the military and the civilian government.<sup id="cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diane_Publishing_Co.-301">[297]</a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the <a href="/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee" title="Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee">CJCSC</a> is General <a href="/wiki/Zubair_Hayat" class="mw-redirect" title="Zubair Hayat">Zubair Hayat</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_Army_Staff_(Pakistan)" title="Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)">chief of army staff</a> General <a href="/wiki/Qamar_Javed_Bajwa" title="Qamar Javed Bajwa">Qamar Javed Bajwa</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_Naval_Staff_(Pakistan)" title="Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)">chief of naval staff</a> <a href="/wiki/Admiral" title="Admiral">Admiral</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Zakaullah" title="Muhammad Zakaullah">Muhammad Zaka</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ISPR_(Navy_Division)_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISPR_(Navy_Division)-304">[300]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_Air_Staff_(Pakistan)" title="Chief of Air Staff (Pakistan)">chief of air staff</a> <a href="/wiki/Air_Chief_Marshal" class="mw-redirect" title="Air Chief Marshal">Air Chief Marshal</a> <a href="/wiki/Mujahid_Anwar_Khan" title="Mujahid Anwar Khan">Mujahid Anwar Khan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ISPR_(Air_Force)_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISPR_(Air_Force)-305">[301]</a></sup> The main branches are the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Army" title="Pakistan Army">Army</a>â<a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force" title="Pakistan Air Force">Air Force</a>â<a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Navy" title="Pakistan Navy">Navy</a>â<a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Marines" title="Pakistan Marines">Marines</a>, which are supported by the number of <a href="/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_Pakistan" title="Paramilitary forces of Pakistan">paramilitary forces</a> in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-china22_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china22-306">[302]</a></sup> Control over the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan%27s_nuclear_testing_series" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan's nuclear testing series">strategic arsenals</a>, deployment, employment, development, <a href="/wiki/Command,_Control,_Communications,_Computers,_Intelligence,_Surveillance,_and_Reconnaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Command, Control, Communications, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance">military computers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_command_and_control" title="Nuclear command and control">command and control</a> is a responsibility vested under the <a href="/wiki/National_Command_Authority_(Pakistan)" title="National Command Authority (Pakistan)">National Command Authority</a> which oversaw the work on the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Doctrine_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Doctrine of Pakistan">nuclear policy</a> as part of the credible <a href="/wiki/N-deterrence" title="N-deterrence">minimum deterrence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Stanford_University_Press_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stanford_University_Press-140">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The United States, Turkey, and China maintain close military relations and regularly export military equipment and <a href="/wiki/Technology_transfer" title="Technology transfer">technology transfer</a> to Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup> Joint logistics and major <a href="/wiki/Military_exercise" title="Military exercise">war games</a> are occasionally carried out by the militaries of China and Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-china22_306-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-china22-306">[302]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[304]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[305]</a></sup> Philosophical basis for the <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">military draft</a> is introduced by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">Constitution</a> in times of emergency, but it has never been imposed.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[306]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_history">Military history</span></h3> 
      <p>Since 1947 Pakistan has been involved in <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts" title="Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts">four</a> <a href="/wiki/Conventional_warfare" title="Conventional warfare">conventional wars</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1947" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani war of 1947">first war</a> occurred in Kashmir with Pakistan gaining control of <a href="/wiki/Western_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Kashmir">Western Kashmir</a>, (<a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a>), and India retaining <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Kashmir">Eastern Kashmir</a> (Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh). Territorial problems eventually led to another <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1965" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani war of 1965">conventional war</a> in 1965; over the issue of <a href="/wiki/East_Bengali_refugees" title="East Bengali refugees">Bengali refugees</a> that led to <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1971" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani war of 1971">another war</a> in 1971 which resulted in Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_(1971)" class="mw-redirect" title="Instrument of Surrender (1971)">unconditional surrender</a> in <a href="/wiki/East_Pakistan" title="East Pakistan">East Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[307]</a></sup> Tensions in Kargil brought the two countries at the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1999" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1999">brink of war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-kargil_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kargil-141">[137]</a></sup> Since 1947 the unresolved <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">territorial problems</a> with <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> saw <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan%E2%80%93Pakistan_skirmishes" title="AfghanistanâPakistan skirmishes">border skirmishes</a> which were kept mostly at the <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan_Pakistan_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghanistan Pakistan border">mountainous border</a>. In 1961, the military and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_intelligence_community" title="Pakistani intelligence community">intelligence community</a> repelled the <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Pakistan#Pakistan-Afghanistan_border_clash_of_1961" title="Military history of Pakistan">Afghan incursion</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Bajaur_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Bajaur Agency">Bajaur Agency</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Durand_Line" title="Durand Line">Durand Line</a> border.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[308]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Rising tensions with neighbouring USSR in <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">their involvement</a> in Afghanistan, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_intelligence_community" title="Pakistani intelligence community">Pakistani intelligence community</a>, mostly the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Services_Intelligence" title="Inter-Services Intelligence">ISI</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Cyclone" title="Operation Cyclone">systematically coordinated</a> the <a href="/wiki/United_States_involvement_in_regime_change" title="United States involvement in regime change">US resources</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_mujahideen" class="mw-redirect" title="Afghan mujahideen">Afghan mujahideen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Arabs" title="Afghan Arabs">foreign fighters</a> against the Soviet Union's presence in the region. Military reports indicated that the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force" title="Pakistan Air Force">PAF</a> was in engagement with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Air_Forces" title="Soviet Air Forces">Soviet Air Force</a>, supported by the <a href="/wiki/Afghan_Air_Force" title="Afghan Air Force">Afghan Air Force</a> during the course of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_war_in_afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian war in afghanistan">conflict</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-PAF-History_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAF-History-314">[310]</a></sup> one of which belonged to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Rutskoy" title="Alexander Rutskoy">Alexander Rutskoy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PAF-History_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAF-History-314">[310]</a></sup> Apart from its own conflicts, Pakistan has been an active <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping_missions_involving_Pakistan" title="United Nations peacekeeping missions involving Pakistan">participant in United Nations peacekeeping missions</a>. It played a major role in rescuing trapped American soldiers from <a href="/wiki/Mogadishu" title="Mogadishu">Mogadishu</a>, Somalia, in 1993 in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Gothic_Serpent" title="Operation Gothic Serpent">Operation Gothic Serpent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-israel_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-israel-315">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[313]</a></sup> According to UN reports, the Pakistani military is the third largest troop contributor to UN <a href="/wiki/UN_peacekeeping_missions_involving_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="UN peacekeeping missions involving Pakistan">peacekeeping missions</a> after <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> and India.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan has <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces_deployments" title="Pakistan Armed Forces deployments">deployed its military</a> in some <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab countries</a>, providing defence, training, and playing advisory roles.<sup id="cite_ref-Cordesman:_Pakistani_Toops_at_Tabuk_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cordesman:_Pakistani_Toops_at_Tabuk-320">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Chengappa:_Military_adviser_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chengappa:_Military_adviser-321">[317]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force" title="Pakistan Air Force">PAF</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Navy" title="Pakistan Navy">Navy</a>'s fighter pilots have voluntarily served in Arab nations' militaries against Israel in <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">the Six-Day War</a> (1967) and in the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a> (1973). Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Fighter_pilot" title="Fighter pilot">fighter pilots</a> shot down ten Israeli planes in the Six-Day War.<sup id="cite_ref-israel_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-israel-315">[311]</a></sup> In the 1973 war one of the PAF pilots, Flt. Lt. <a href="/wiki/Sattar_Alvi" title="Sattar Alvi">Sattar Alvi</a> (flying a MiG-21), shot down an Israeli Air Force Mirage and was honoured by the Syrian government.<sup id="cite_ref-Chengappa2004_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chengappa2004-322">[318]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dunstan2003_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dunstan2003-323">[319]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kumaraswamy2013_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kumaraswamy2013-324">[320]</a></sup> Requested by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Saudi_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Saudi Arabia">Saudi monarchy</a> in 1979, Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/Special_Service_Group" title="Special Service Group">special forces</a> units, operatives, and commandos were rushed to assist <a href="/wiki/Saudi_forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Saudi forces">Saudi forces</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a> to <a href="/wiki/Grand_Mosque_Seizure" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Mosque Seizure">lead the operation</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Masjid_al-Haram" title="Masjid al-Haram">Grand Mosque</a>. For almost two weeks Saudi Special Forces and Pakistani commandos fought the insurgents who had occupied the <a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Mecca" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Mosque of Mecca">Grand Mosque</a>'s compound.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup> In 1991 Pakistan got involved with the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> and sent 5,000 troops as part of a US-led coalition, specifically for the defence of <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gulf_war_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gulf_war-328">[324]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite the UN arms embargo on <a href="/wiki/Bosnia" class="mw-redirect" title="Bosnia">Bosnia</a>, General <a href="/wiki/Javed_Nasir" title="Javed Nasir">Javed Nasir</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Services_Intelligence" title="Inter-Services Intelligence">ISI</a> airlifted anti-tank weapons and missiles to Bosnian mujahideen which turned the tide in favour of Bosnian Muslims and forced the Serbs to lift the siege. Under Nasir's leadership the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Services_Intelligence" title="Inter-Services Intelligence">ISI</a> was also involved in supporting Chinese Muslims in <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> Province, rebel Muslim groups in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, and some religious groups in Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Abbas_2015_148_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abbas_2015_148-330">[326]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2004, the military has been engaged in an <a href="/wiki/War_in_North-West_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="War in North-West Pakistan">insurgency</a> in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, mainly against the <a href="/wiki/Tehrik-i-Taliban_Pakistan" title="Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan">Tehrik-i-Taliban factions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[328]</a></sup> Major operations undertaken by the army include <a href="/wiki/Operation_Black_Thunderstorm" title="Operation Black Thunderstorm">Operation Black Thunderstorm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Rah-e-Nijat" title="Operation Rah-e-Nijat">Operation Rah-e-Nijat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Zarb-e-Azb" title="Operation Zarb-e-Azb">Operation Zarb-e-Azb</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ashfaq_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ashfaq-333">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[330]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/SIPRI" class="mw-redirect" title="SIPRI">SIPRI</a>, Pakistan was the 9th-largest recipient and importer of arms between 2012â2016.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[331]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2020</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Pakistan" title="Economy of Pakistan">Economy of Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Pakistan" title="Economic history of Pakistan">Economic history of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_the_International_Monetary_Fund" title="Pakistan and the International Monetary Fund">Pakistan and the International Monetary Fund</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="infobox" style="font-size: 90%; border: 1px solid #999; float: right; margin-left: 1em; width:325px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr style="background:#f5f5f5"> 
         <th colspan="3">Economic indicators </th>
        </tr>

         <td>$1.254&nbsp;trillion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-imf2_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-11">[10]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> (nominal)</td> 
         <td>$284.2&nbsp;billion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>

         <td>Real GDP growth</td> 
         <td>3.29% <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> </td>

         <td>10.3% <small>(2019)</small></td>

         <td><a href="/wiki/Unemployment_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Unemployment in Pakistan">Unemployment</a></td> 
         <td>5.7% <small>(2018)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[335]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>

         <td>Labor force participation rate</td> 
         <td>48.9% <small>(2018)</small></td>

        </tr>

         <td><a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_Pakistan" title="National debt of Pakistan">Total public debt</a></td> 
         <td>$106&nbsp;billion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/National_wealth" class="mw-redirect" title="National wealth">National wealth</a></td> 
         <td>$465&nbsp;billion <small>(2019)</small></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;"><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[337]</a></sup> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The <b>Economy of Pakistan</b> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">23rd-largest</a> in the world in terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP), and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">42nd-largest</a> in terms of nominal <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a>. Economists estimate that Pakistan was part of the wealthiest <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">region</a> of the world throughout the first millennium CE, with the largest economy by GDP. This advantage was lost in the 18th century as other regions such as China and Western Europe edged forward.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup> Pakistan is considered a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a><sup id="cite_ref-gulfmedia_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gulfmedia-343">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[340]</a></sup> and is one of the <a href="/wiki/Jim_O%27Neill,_Baron_O%27Neill_of_Gatley#Next_Eleven" title="Jim O'Neill, Baron O'Neill of Gatley">Next Eleven</a>, a group of eleven countries that, along with the <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRICs</a>, have a high potential to become the world's largest economies in the 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[341]</a></sup> In recent years, after decades of social instability, as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, serious deficiencies in <a href="/wiki/Macromanagement" title="Macromanagement">macromanagement</a> and unbalanced <a href="/wiki/Macroeconomics" title="Macroeconomics">macroeconomics</a> in basic services such as <a href="/wiki/Railways_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Railways in Pakistan">rail transportation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electricity_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Electricity in Pakistan">electrical energy</a> generation have developed.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT51813_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT51813-346">[342]</a></sup> The economy is considered to be semi-industrialized, with centres of growth along the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[343]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-siteresources.worldbank.org_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-siteresources.worldbank.org-348">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-raid_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-raid-349">[345]</a></sup> The diversified economies of <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Karachi" title="Economy of Karachi">Karachi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Punjab,_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Economy of Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab's urban centres</a> coexist with less-developed areas in other parts of the country, particularly in Balochistan.<sup id="cite_ref-siteresources.worldbank.org_348-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-siteresources.worldbank.org-348">[344]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Economic_complexity_index" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic complexity index">Economic complexity index</a>, Pakistan is the 67th-largest export economy in the world and the 106th most complex economy.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup> During the fiscal year 2015â16, Pakistan's exports stood at US$20.81&nbsp;billion and imports at US$44.76&nbsp;billion, resulting in a negative trade balance of US$23.96&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG/220px-Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG/330px-Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG/440px-Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Islamabad_Stock_Exchange_Bull.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Statue of a bull outside the Pakistan Stock Exchange, Islamabad, Pakistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Pakistan's estimated <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> is US$284.2&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_11-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-11">[10]</a></sup> The GDP by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a> is <a href="/wiki/US_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="US dollar">US$</a>1.254&nbsp;trillion.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_11-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-11">[10]</a></sup> The estimated nominal <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Per capita GDP">per capita GDP</a> is <a href="/wiki/US_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="US dollar">US$</a>1,388,<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_11-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-11">[10]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP (PPP)/capita</a> is <a href="/wiki/US_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="US dollar">US$</a>6,016 (<a href="/wiki/International_dollar" title="International dollar">international dollars</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_11-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-11">[10]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, Pakistan has important strategic endowments and development potential. The increasing proportion of Pakistan's youth provides the country with both a potential demographic dividend and a challenge to provide adequate services and employment.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-352">[348]</a></sup> 21.04% of the population live below the international poverty line of US$1.25 a day. The unemployment rate among the aged 15 and over population is 5.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-poor_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poor-353">[349]</a></sup> Pakistan has an estimated 40&nbsp;million middle class citizens, projected to increase to 100&nbsp;million by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup> A 2015 report published by the World Bank ranked Pakistan's economy at 24th-largest<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[351]</a></sup> in the world by purchasing power and 41st-largest<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup> in absolute terms. It is South Asia's second-largest economy, representing about 15.0% of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">regional GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Recent_developments_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Recent_developments-357">[353]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg.com_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg.com-358">[354]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable sortable infobox"> 
       <tbody>

        </tr>

        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2017â18 </td> 
         <td><img alt="Increase" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Increase" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">5.79% </td> 
         <td><img alt="10" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/11px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png" decoding="async" title="10" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/17px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Decrease_Positive.svg/22px-Decrease_Positive.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="300">3.8% </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Pakistan's economic growth since its inception has been varied. It has been slow during periods of democratic transition, but robust during the three periods of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Martial law in Pakistan">martial law</a>, although the foundation for sustainable and equitable growth was not formed.<sup id="cite_ref-ChowdhuryMahmud2008_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChowdhuryMahmud2008-120">[116]</a></sup> The early to middle 2000s was a period of <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_Pakistan" title="Economic liberalisation in Pakistan">rapid economic reforms</a>; the government raised development spending, which reduced poverty levels by 10% and increased GDP by 3%.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JohnWall2006_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JohnWall2006-361">[357]</a></sup> The economy cooled again from 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-ciafactbook_186-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciafactbook-186">[182]</a></sup> Inflation reached 25.0% in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[358]</a></sup> and Pakistan had to depend on a fiscal policy backed by the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> to avoid possible bankruptcy.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[360]</a></sup> A year later, the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a> reported that Pakistan's economic crisis was easing.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[361]</a></sup> The inflation rate for the fiscal year <span class="nowrap">2010â11</span> was 14.1%.<sup id="cite_ref-edu_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-366">[362]</a></sup> Since 2013, as part of an <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> program, Pakistan's economic growth has picked up. In 2014 <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> predicted that Pakistan's economy would grow 15 times in the next 35 years to become the 18th-largest economy in the world by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[363]</a></sup> In his 2016 book, <i>The Rise and Fall of Nations</i>, <a href="/wiki/Ruchir_Sharma" title="Ruchir Sharma">Ruchir Sharma</a> termed Pakistan's economy as at a 'take-off' stage and the future outlook until 2020 has been termed 'Very Good'. Sharma termed it possible to transform Pakistan from a "low-income to a middle-income country during the next five years".<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[364]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;" colspan="2">Share of world GDP (PPP)<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Share </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1980</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.54% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">1990</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.72% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2000 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.74% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2010 </td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.79% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:left;">2017</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.83% </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Pakistan is one of the largest producers of natural commodities, and its <a href="/wiki/Labour_force_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Labour force of Pakistan">labour market</a> is the 10th-largest in the world. The 7-millionâstrong <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_diaspora" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani diaspora">Pakistani diaspora</a> contributed US$19.9&nbsp;billion to the economy in 2015â16.<sup id="cite_ref-remit_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-remit-370">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup> The major source countries of remittances to Pakistan are: the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">UAE</a>; the United States; Saudi Arabia; the Gulf states (Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, and Oman); Australia; Canada; Japan; the United Kingdom; Norway; and Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-young_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-young-373">[369]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, Pakistan's share of overall world exports is declining; it contributed only 0.13% in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[370]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture_and_primary_sector">Agriculture and primary sector</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg/200px-Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg/300px-Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg/400px-Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1156" data-file-height="810"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pakistan_Chrome_Mines20120126_16100237_0003.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Surface_mining" title="Surface mining">Surface mining</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sindh" title="Sindh">Sindh</a>. Pakistan has been termed the 'Saudi Arabia of Coal' by <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[371]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Pakistan" title="Agriculture in Pakistan">Agriculture in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fuel_extraction_in_Pakistan" title="Fuel extraction in Pakistan">Fuel extraction in Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Pakistan" title="Mining in Pakistan">Mining in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The structure of the Pakistani economy has changed from <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Pakistan" title="Agriculture in Pakistan">a mainly agricultural</a> to a strong service base. Agriculture as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> accounts for only 20.9% of the GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup> Even so, according to the United Nations <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a>, Pakistan produced 21,591,400 metric tons of wheat in 2005, more than all of Africa (20,304,585 metric tons) and nearly as much as all of South America (24,557,784 metric tons).<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup> Majority of the population, directly or indirectly, is dependent on this sector. It accounts for 43.5% of employed labour force and is the largest source of foreign exchange earnings.<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[374]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A large portion of the country's manufactured exports is dependent on raw materials such as cotton and hides that are part of the agriculture sector, while supply shortages and market disruptions in farm products do push up inflationary pressures. The country is also the fifth-largest producer of cotton, with cotton production of 14&nbsp;million bales from a modest beginning of 1.7&nbsp;million bales in the early 1950s; is self-sufficient in sugarcane; and is the fourth-largest producer in the world of milk. Land and water resources have not risen proportionately, but the increases have taken place mainly due to gains in labour and agriculture productivity. The major breakthrough in crop production took place in the late 1960s and 1970s due to the <a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution" title="Green Revolution">Green Revolution</a> that made a significant contribution to land and yield increases of wheat and rice. Private tube wells led to a 50 percent increase in the cropping intensity which was augmented by tractor cultivation. While the tube wells raised crop yields by 50 percent, the High Yielding Varieties (HYVs) of wheat and rice led to a 50â60 percent higher yield.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[375]</a></sup> Meat industry accounts for 1.4 percent of overall GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[376]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry">Industry</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Industry_of_Pakistan" title="Industry of Pakistan">Industry of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry_in_Pakistan" title="Textile industry in Pakistan">Textile industry in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg/200px-Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg/300px-Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="353" data-file-height="353"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tv_Assembly_Line_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Television assembly factory in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>. Pakistan's industrial sector accounts for about 20.3% of the GDP, and is dominated by <a href="/wiki/Small_and_medium-sized_enterprises" title="Small and medium-sized enterprises">small and medium-sized enterprises</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[377]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Industry is the second-largest sector of the economy, accounting for 19.74% of gross domestic product (GDP), and 24 percent of total employment. Large-scale manufacturing (LSM), at 12.2% of GDP, dominates the overall sector, accounting for 66% of the sectoral share, followed by small-scale manufacturing, which accounts for 4.9% of total GDP. Pakistan's cement industry is also fast growing mainly because of demand from <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> and from the domestic real estate sector. In 2013 Pakistan exported 7,708,557 <a href="/wiki/Metric_tons" class="mw-redirect" title="Metric tons">metric tons</a> of cement.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[378]</a></sup> Pakistan has an installed capacity of 44,768,250 metric tons of cement and 42,636,428 metric tons of clinker. In 2012 and 2013, the cement industry in Pakistan became the most profitable sector of the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry_in_Pakistan" title="Textile industry in Pakistan">textile industry</a> has a pivotal position in the manufacturing sector of Pakistan. In Asia, Pakistan is the eighth-largest exporter of textile products, contributing 9.5% to the GDP and providing employment to around 15&nbsp;million people (some 30% of the 49&nbsp;million people in the workforce). Pakistan is the fourth-largest producer of cotton with the third-largest spinning capacity in Asia after China and India, contributing 5% to the global spinning capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup> China is the second largest buyer of Pakistani textiles, importing US$1.527&nbsp;billion of textiles last fiscal. Unlike the US, where mostly value-added textiles are imported, China buys only cotton yarn and cotton fabric from Pakistan. In 2012, Pakistani textile products accounted for 3.3% or US$1.07bn of all UK textile imports, 12.4% or $4.61bn of total Chinese textile imports, 3.0% of all US textile imports ($2,980&nbsp;million), 1.6% of total German textile imports ($880&nbsp;million) and 0.7% of total Indian textile imports ($888&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Services">Services</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Real_estate_in_Pakistan" title="Real estate in Pakistan">Real estate in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Information_technology_in_Pakistan" title="Information technology in Pakistan">Information technology in Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Banking_in_Pakistan" title="Banking in Pakistan">Banking in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg/290px-KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg" decoding="async" width="290" height="100" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg/435px-KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg/580px-KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4904" data-file-height="1696"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KHIURBANSKYLINE.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Rising skyline of <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> with several under construction skyscrapers.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The services sector makes up 58.8% of GDP<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup> and has emerged as the main driver of economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> Pakistani society like other developing countries is a consumption oriented society, having a high marginal propensity to consume. The growth rate of services sector is higher than the growth rate of agriculture and industrial sector. Services sector accounts for 54 percent of GDP in 2014 and little over one-third of total employment. Services sector has strong linkages with other sectors of economy; it provides essential inputs to agriculture sector and manufacturing sector.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> Pakistan's I.T sector is regarded as among the fastest growing sector's in Pakistan. The <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>, assessing the development of Information and Communication Technology in the country ranked Pakistan 110th among 139 countries on the 'Networked Readiness Index 2016'.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> </p>
