      <p>As of May 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Pakistan has about 82&nbsp;million internet users, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">9th-largest population</a> of Internet users in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-PTD_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PTD-389">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-390">[386]</a></sup> The current growth rate and employment trend indicate that Pakistan's Information Communication Technology (ICT) industry will exceed the $10-billion mark by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[387]</a></sup> The sector employees 12,000 and count's among top five freelancing nations.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[388]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup> The country has also improved its export performance in telecom, computer and information services, as the share of their exports surged from 8.2pc in 2005â06 to 12.6pc in 2012â13. This growth is much better than that of China, whose share in services exports was 3pc and 7.7pc for the same period respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Pakistan" title="Tourism in Pakistan">Tourism in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg/220px-Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg/330px-Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg/440px-Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="614"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Lake-saif-ul-malook_Pakistan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Lake_Saiful_Muluk" title="Lake Saiful Muluk">Lake Saiful Muluk</a>, located at the northern end of the <a href="/wiki/Kaghan_Valley" title="Kaghan Valley">Kaghan Valley</a>, near the town of <a href="/wiki/Naran,_Kaghan_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Naran, Kaghan Valley">Naran</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Saiful_Muluk_National_Park" title="Saiful Muluk National Park">Saiful Muluk National Park</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg/220px-Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg/330px-Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg/440px-Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6700" data-file-height="4213"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Badshahi_Masjid_at_Sunset.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Badshahi_Mosque" title="Badshahi Mosque">Badshahi Mosque</a> was commissioned by the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_emperors" title="Mughal emperors">Mughals</a> in 1671. It is listed as a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With its diverse cultures, people, and landscapes, Pakistan attracted around 6.6&nbsp;million foreign tourists in 2018,<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[391]</a></sup> which represented a significant decline since the 1970s when the country received unprecedented numbers of foreign tourists due to the popular <a href="/wiki/Hippie_trail" title="Hippie trail">Hippie trail</a>. The trail attracted thousands of Europeans and Americans in the 1960s and 1970s who travelled via land through Turkey and Iran into India through Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[392]</a></sup> The main destinations of choice for these tourists were the <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pass" title="Khyber Pass">Khyber Pass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swat_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Swat (Pakistan)">Swat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi" title="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup> The numbers following the trail declined after the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Revolution</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Afghan_War" title="SovietâAfghan War">SovietâAfghan War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan's tourist attractions range from the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River_Delta-Arabian_Sea_mangroves" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves">mangroves</a> in the south to the Himalayan <a href="/wiki/List_of_hill_stations_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of hill stations of Pakistan">hill stations</a> in the north-east. The country's tourist destinations range from the Buddhist ruins of <a href="/wiki/Takht-i-Bahi" title="Takht-i-Bahi">Takht-i-Bahi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxila" title="Taxila">Taxila</a>, to the 5,000-year-old cities of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harappa" title="Harappa">Harappa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup> Pakistan is home to several <a href="/wiki/Mountain_ranges_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountain ranges of Pakistan">mountain peaks</a> over 7,000 metres (23,000 feet).<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> The northern part of Pakistan has many old fortresses, examples of ancient architecture, and the <a href="/wiki/Hunza_Valley" title="Hunza Valley">Hunza</a> and Chitral valleys, home to the small pre-Islamic <a href="/wiki/Kalash_people" title="Kalash people">Kalasha</a> community claiming descent from Alexander the Great.<sup id="cite_ref-Bezhan2017_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bezhan2017-401">[397]</a></sup> Pakistan's cultural capital, Lahore, contains many examples of <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal architecture</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Badshahi_Masjid" class="mw-redirect" title="Badshahi Masjid">Badshahi Masjid</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Shalimar_Gardens_(Lahore)" class="mw-redirect" title="Shalimar Gardens (Lahore)">Shalimar Gardens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Jahangir" title="Tomb of Jahangir">Tomb of Jahangir</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Fort" title="Lahore Fort">Lahore Fort</a>. </p>
      <p>In October 2006, just one year after the <a href="/wiki/2005_Kashmir_earthquake" title="2005 Kashmir earthquake">2005 Kashmir earthquake</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> released what it described as "The top five tourist sites in Pakistan" in order to help the country's tourism industry.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[398]</a></sup> The five sites included <a href="/wiki/Taxila" title="Taxila">Taxila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Karakoram_Highway" title="Karakoram Highway">Karakoram Highway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karimabad_(Hunza)" class="mw-redirect" title="Karimabad (Hunza)">Karimabad</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Saiful_Muluk" title="Lake Saiful Muluk">Lake Saiful Muluk</a>. To promote Pakistan's unique cultural heritage, the government organizes various festivals throughout the year.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup> In 2015 the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>'s Travel &amp; Tourism Competitiveness Report ranked Pakistan 125 out of 141 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Pakistan" title="Water supply and sanitation in Pakistan">Water supply and sanitation in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan was recognised as the best country for infrastructure development in South Asia during the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IWF</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> annual meetings in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_power_and_energy">Nuclear power and energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Pakistan" title="Nuclear power in Pakistan">Nuclear power in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy in Pakistan">Energy in Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Pakistan" title="Electricity sector in Pakistan">Electricity sector in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg/250px-Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg/375px-Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg/500px-Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg 2x" data-file-width="894" data-file-height="596"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tarbela_Dam_during_the_2010_floods.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tarbela_Dam" title="Tarbela Dam">Tarbela Dam</a>, the largest earth filled dam in the world, was constructed in 1968.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the end of 2016, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Pakistan" title="Nuclear power in Pakistan">nuclear power</a> was provided by four licensed commercial <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plants" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear power plants">nuclear power plants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission">Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission</a> (PAEC) is solely responsible for operating these power plants, while the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Nuclear_Regulatory_Authority" title="Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority">Pakistan Nuclear Regulatory Authority</a> regulates safe usage of the nuclear energy.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">electricity generated</a> by commercial nuclear power plants constitutes roughly 5.8% of Pakistan's electrical energy, compared to 64.2% from <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a> (<a href="/wiki/Crude_oil" class="mw-redirect" title="Crude oil">crude oil</a> and natural gas), 29.9% from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydroelectric power">hydroelectric power</a>, and 0.1% from <a href="/wiki/Coal_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Coal power plant">coal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Express_Tribune,_2014_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Express_Tribune,_2014-408">[404]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Directorate-General_for_Nuclear_Power_Generation_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Directorate-General_for_Nuclear_Power_Generation-409">[405]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pakistan_Observer_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pakistan_Observer-410">[406]</a></sup> Pakistan is one of the four <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear armed states</a> (along with India, Israel, and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>) that is not a party to the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a>, but it is a member in good standing of the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IAEA_Membership_states_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IAEA_Membership_states-411">[407]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dawn_Newspapers,_25th_April,_2011_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn_Newspapers,_25th_April,_2011-412">[408]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reuters,_Vienna_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters,_Vienna-413">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p> The <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Karachi Nuclear Power Plant">KANUPP-I</a>, a <a href="/wiki/CANDU_reactor" title="CANDU reactor">Candu-type</a> nuclear reactor, was supplied by Canada in 1971âthe country's first commercial <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a>. The Sino-Pakistani nuclear cooperation began in the early 1980s. After a Sino-Pakistani nuclear cooperation agreement in 1986,<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup> China provided Pakistan with a nuclear reactor dubbed <a href="/wiki/Chashma_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chashma Nuclear Power Plant">CHASNUPP-I</a> for energy and the industrial growth of the country. In 2005 both countries proposed working on a joint energy security plan, calling for a huge increase in generation capacity to more than 160,000&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MWe</a> by 2030. Under its Nuclear Energy Vision 2050, the Pakistani government plans to increase nuclear power generation capacity to 40,000&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MWe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> 8,900&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MWe</a> of it by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg/220px-Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg/330px-Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg/440px-Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3696" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jhimpir_Wind_Farm_2012.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pakistan produced 1,135&nbsp;megawatts of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> for the month of October 2016. Pakistan expects to produce 3,000&nbsp;megawatts of renewable energy by the beginning of 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>In June 2008 the nuclear <a href="/wiki/Chashma_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chashma Nuclear Power Plant">commercial complex</a> was expanded with the ground work of installing and operationalising the <a href="/wiki/Chashma_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chashma Nuclear Power Plant">Chashma-III</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chashma_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chashma Nuclear Power Plant">ChashmaâIV</a> reactors at <a href="/wiki/Chashma,_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Chashma, Pakistan">Chashma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punjab_(Pakistani_province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjab (Pakistani province)">Punjab Province</a>, each with 325â340&nbsp;MWe and costing <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_rupee" title="Pakistani rupee">â¨</a> 129&nbsp;billion; from which the <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_rupee" title="Pakistani rupee">â¨</a> 80&nbsp;billion came from international sources, principally China. A further agreement for China's help with the project was signed in October 2008, and given prominence as a counter to the <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_Civil_Nuclear_Agreement" title="IndiaâUnited States Civil Nuclear Agreement">USâIndia agreement</a> that shortly preceded it. The cost quoted then was US$1.7&nbsp;billion, with a foreign loan component of US$1.07&nbsp;billion. In 2013 Pakistan established a second commercial <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Nuclear_Power_Complex" title="Karachi Nuclear Power Complex">nuclear complex</a> in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> with plans of additional reactors, similar to the one in <a href="/wiki/Chashma_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chashma Nuclear Power Plant">Chashma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[415]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electricity_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Electricity in Pakistan">electrical energy</a> is generated by various <a href="/wiki/List_of_electric_supply_companies_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of electric supply companies in Pakistan">energy corporations</a> and evenly distributed by the <a href="/wiki/National_Electric_Power_Regulatory_Authority" title="National Electric Power Regulatory Authority">National Electric Power Regulatory Authority</a> (NEPRA) among the <a href="/wiki/Four_Provinces_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Four Provinces (Pakistan)">four provinces</a>. However, the <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>-based <a href="/wiki/K-Electric" title="K-Electric">K-Electric</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Water_and_Power_Development_Authority" class="mw-redirect" title="Water and Power Development Authority">Water and Power Development Authority</a> (WAPDA) generates much of the electrical energy used in Pakistan in addition to gathering revenue nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-energy_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-420">[416]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Pakistan has an installed <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">electricity generation</a> capacity of ~22,797<span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MWt</a></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Express_Tribune,_2014_408-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Express_Tribune,_2014-408">[404]</a></sup> </p>
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Pakistan" title="Transport in Pakistan">Transport in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Transportation in Pakistan">transport industry</a> accounts for ~10.5% of the nation's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Motorways">Motorways</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Motorways_of_Pakistan" title="Motorways of Pakistan">Motorways of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:M2-Motorway.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/M2-Motorway.jpg/220px-M2-Motorway.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/M2-Motorway.jpg/330px-M2-Motorway.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/M2-Motorway.jpg/440px-M2-Motorway.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:M2-Motorway.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The motorway passes through the <a href="/wiki/Salt_Range" title="Salt Range">Salt Range</a> mountains
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Motorways_of_Pakistan" title="Motorways of Pakistan">Motorways of Pakistan</a> are a network of multiple-lane, high-speed, <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">controlled-access highways</a> in Pakistan, which are owned, maintained, and operated federally by Pakistan's <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Authority_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Highway Authority (Pakistan)">National Highway Authority</a>. As of 20 February 2020, 1882&nbsp;km of motorways are operational, while an additional 1854&nbsp;km are under construction or planned. All motorways in Pakistan are pre-fixed with the letter 'M' (for "Motorway") followed by the unique numerical designation of the specific highway (with a hyphen in the middle), e.g. "M-1".<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan's motorways are an important part of Pakistan's "National Trade Corridor Project",<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[419]</a></sup> which aims to link Pakistan's three <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> ports (<a href="/wiki/Karachi_Port" class="mw-redirect" title="Karachi Port">Karachi Port</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_Bin_Qasim" class="mw-redirect" title="Port Bin Qasim">Port Bin Qasim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gwadar_Port" title="Gwadar Port">Gwadar Port</a>) to the rest of the country through its national highways and motorways network and further north with <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> and China. The project was planned in 1990. The <a href="/wiki/China_Pakistan_Economic_Corridor" class="mw-redirect" title="China Pakistan Economic Corridor">China Pakistan Economic Corridor</a> project aims to link <a href="/wiki/Gwadar_Port" title="Gwadar Port">Gwadar Port</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kashgar" title="Kashgar">Kashgar</a> (China) using Pakistani motorways, <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_of_Pakistan" title="National Highways of Pakistan">national highways</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_Pakistan" title="Expressways of Pakistan">expressways</a>. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Highways">Highways</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_of_Pakistan" title="National Highways of Pakistan">National Highways of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Highways form the backbone of Pakistan's transport system; a total road length of 263,942 kilometres (164,006 miles) accounts for 92% of passengers and 96% of inland freight traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup> Road transport services are largely in the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatization in Pakistan">private sector</a>. The <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Authority_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Highway Authority (Pakistan)">National Highway Authority</a> is responsible for the maintenance of national highways and motorways. The highway and motorway system depends mainly on northâsouth links connecting the southern ports to the populous provinces of Punjab and <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa</a>. Although this network only accounts for 4.6% of total road length,<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup> it carries 85% of the country's traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-pc_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc-424">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-unesep_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesep-425">[421]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Railways">Railways</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg/220px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg/330px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg/440px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7177" data-file-height="4037"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img54_Cantonment_Railway_Station.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Karachi_Cantonment_railway_station" title="Karachi Cantonment railway station">Karachi Cantonment railway station</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Railways" title="Pakistan Railways">Pakistan Railways</a>, under the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Railways_(Pakistan)" title="Ministry of Railways (Pakistan)">Ministry of Railways</a> (MoR), operates the railroad system. From 1947 until the 1970s the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Railways" title="Pakistan Railways">train system</a> was the primary means of transport until the nationwide constructions of the <a href="/wiki/National_Highways_of_Pakistan" title="National Highways of Pakistan">national highways</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Economic_boom" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic boom">economic boom</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Cars_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Cars in Pakistan">automotive industry</a>. Beginning in the 1990s there was a marked shift in traffic from rail to highways; dependence grew on roads after the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Pakistan" title="Automotive industry in Pakistan">vehicles</a> in the country. Now the railway's share of inland traffic is below 8% for passengers and 4% for freight traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-DSEC_376-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DSEC-376">[372]</a></sup> As personal transportation began to be dominated by the automobile, total rail track decreased from 8,775 kilometres (5,453 miles) in 1990â91 to 7,791 kilometres (4,841 miles) in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-pc_424-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc-424">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nation_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nation-426">[422]</a></sup> Pakistan expects to use the rail service to boost <a href="/wiki/Foreign_trade_of_Pakistan" title="Foreign trade of Pakistan">foreign trade</a> with China, Iran, and Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[424]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Airports">Airports</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Pakistan" title="List of airports in Pakistan">List of airports in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:New_Islamabad_International_Airport,.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg/220px-New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg/330px-New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg/440px-New_Islamabad_International_Airport%2C.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4396" data-file-height="2638"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:New_Islamabad_International_Airport,.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Islamabad_International_Airport" title="Islamabad International Airport">Islamabad International Airport</a> has a capacity of handling 18&nbsp;million passengers annually.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are an estimated 139 airports and airfields in Pakistanâincluding both the military and the mostly publicly owned <a href="/wiki/Civil_Aviation_Authority_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil Aviation Authority (Pakistan)">civilian</a> airports. Although <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_International_Airport" title="Jinnah International Airport">Jinnah International Airport</a> is the principal international gateway to Pakistan, the international airports in <a href="/wiki/Allama_Iqbal_International_Airport" title="Allama Iqbal International Airport">Lahore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamabad_International_Airport" title="Islamabad International Airport">Islamabad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peshawar_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Peshawar International Airport">Peshawar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quetta_International_Airport" title="Quetta International Airport">Quetta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faisalabad_International_Airport" title="Faisalabad International Airport">Faisalabad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sialkot_International_Airport" title="Sialkot International Airport">Sialkot</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Multan_International_Airport" title="Multan International Airport">Multan</a> also handle significant amounts of traffic. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_Pakistan" title="List of airlines of Pakistan">civil aviation industry</a> is mixed with <a href="/wiki/Nationalization_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalization in Pakistan">public</a> and <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatization in Pakistan">private</a> sectors, which was <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatization in Pakistan">deregulated</a> in 1993. While the <a href="/wiki/State_owned_enterprises" class="mw-redirect" title="State owned enterprises">state-owned</a> <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_International_Airlines" title="Pakistan International Airlines">Pakistan International Airlines</a> (PIA) is the major and dominant air carrier that carries about 73% of domestic passengers and all domestic freight, the private airlines such as <a href="/wiki/Airblue" title="Airblue">airBlue</a> and <a href="/wiki/Air_Indus" title="Air Indus">Air Indus</a>, also provide similar services at a <a href="/wiki/Low_cost_carrier" class="mw-redirect" title="Low cost carrier">low cost</a>. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Seaports">Seaports</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg/220px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg/330px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg/440px-PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7839" data-file-height="4409"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PK_Karachi_asv2020-02_img47_container_port.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">Port of Karachi</a> is one of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>'s largest and busiest deep-water <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">seaports</a>, handling about 60% of the nation's cargo (25&nbsp;million tons per annum).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Major seaports are in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>, Sindh (the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Karachi" title="Port of Karachi">Karachi port</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_Qasim" title="Port Qasim">Port Qasim</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-pc_424-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc-424">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nation_426-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nation-426">[422]</a></sup> Since the 1990s some seaport operations have been moved to <a href="/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan" title="Balochistan, Pakistan">Balochistan</a> with the construction of <a href="/wiki/Gwadar_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Gwadar port">Gwadar Port</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Pasni" title="Port of Pasni">Port of Pasni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gadani_ship-breaking_yard" title="Gadani ship-breaking yard">Gadani Port</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pc_424-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pc-424">[420]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nation_426-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nation-426">[422]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gwadar_Port" title="Gwadar Port">Gwadar Port</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Deep_water_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Deep water port">deepest sea port</a> of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-gwadarinfo_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gwadarinfo-429">[425]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">WEF's</a> Global Competitiveness Report, quality ratings of Pakistan's port infrastructure increased from 3.7 to 4.1 between 2007 and 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Metro">Metro</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_rapid_transit_systems_in_Pakistan" title="List of rapid transit systems in Pakistan">List of rapid transit systems in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Metro_Train">Metro Train</span></h5> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg/220px-CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg/330px-CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg/440px-CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1080"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:CNS_Orange_Line_of_Lahore_Metro_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Orange_Line_(Lahore_Metro)" title="Orange Line (Lahore Metro)">Orange Line Metro Train</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG/220px-Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG/330px-Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG/440px-Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="1961"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Islamabad_Metro_Bus.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Track of <a href="/wiki/Islamabad-Rawalpindi_Metrobus" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamabad-Rawalpindi Metrobus">Islamabad-Rawalpindi Metrobus</a> with adjoining station
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/Orange_Line_(Lahore_Metro)" title="Orange Line (Lahore Metro)">Orange Line Metro Train</a> is an automated <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> The Orange line is the first of the three proposed rail lines part for the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Metro" title="Lahore Metro">Lahore Metro</a>. The line spans 27.1&nbsp;km (16.8&nbsp;mi) with 25.4&nbsp;km (15.8&nbsp;mi) elevated and 1.72&nbsp;km (1.1&nbsp;mi) underground and has a cost of 251.06&nbsp;billion Rupees ($1.6&nbsp;billion).<sup id="cite_ref-Norinco_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norinco-433">[429]</a></sup> The line consists of 26 subway stations and is designed to carry over 250,000 passengers daily. The line became operational on 25 October 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-Lahore_Metro_Train_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lahore_Metro_Train-434">[430]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Metro_Bus_and_BRTs">Metro Bus and BRTs</span></h5> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Lahore_Metrobus" title="Lahore Metrobus">Lahore Metrobus</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> service operating in the city of <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[431]</a></sup> The Metrobus network's first phase was opened in February 2013. It was the first Metro bus system in Pakistan.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi-Islamabad_Metrobus" title="Rawalpindi-Islamabad Metrobus">Rawalpindi-Islamabad Metrobus</a> is a 22.5&nbsp;km (14.0&nbsp;mi) <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> system operating in the <a href="/wiki/Islamabad_Rawalpindi_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamabad Rawalpindi metropolitan area">Islamabad Rawalpindi metropolitan area</a>. The Metrobus network's first phase was opened on 4 June 2015, and stretches 22 kilometres between <a href="/wiki/Pak_Secretariat" class="mw-redirect" title="Pak Secretariat">Pak Secretariat</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Saddar,_Rawalpindi" title="Saddar, Rawalpindi">Saddar</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rawalpindi" title="Rawalpindi">Rawalpindi</a>. The system uses e-ticketing and an <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_Transportation_System" class="mw-redirect" title="Intelligent Transportation System">Intelligent Transportation System</a> and is managed by the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_Mass_Transit_Authority" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjab Mass Transit Authority">Punjab Mass Transit Authority</a>.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Multan_Metrobus" title="Multan Metrobus">Multan Metrobus</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> (BRT) system in <a href="/wiki/Multan" title="Multan">Multan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[432]</a></sup> Construction on the line began in May 2015, while operations commenced on 24 January 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[433]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Peshawar_Metrobus" class="mw-redirect" title="Peshawar Metrobus">Peshawar Bus Rapid Transit</a> (Peshawar BRT) is a <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> system in <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>, capital of <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa" title="Khyber Pakhtunkhwa">Khyber Pakhtunkhwa</a> province. The construction of the project was started in October 2017 and was inaugurated on 13 August 2020, it is the fourth BRT system in Pakistan.</li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Karachi_Metrobus" class="mw-redirect" title="Karachi Metrobus">Green Line Metrobus</a> is a first phase of <a href="/wiki/Karachi_Metrobus" class="mw-redirect" title="Karachi Metrobus">Karachi Metrobus</a> that is under construction in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a> is financing the majority of the project.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[434]</a></sup> Construction of the Green Line began on 26 February 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[435]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Faisalabad shuttle train service and <a href="/wiki/Faisalabad_Metrobus" class="mw-redirect" title="Faisalabad Metrobus">Faisalabad Metrobus</a> are the proposed rapid transit projects in the city of <a href="/wiki/Faisalabad" title="Faisalabad">Faisalabad</a>. These projects are the part of a mega-project of <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_Economic_Corridor" title="ChinaâPakistan Economic Corridor">ChinaâPakistan Economic Corridor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[436]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[437]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_Systems">Other Systems</span></h5> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Karachi_Circular_Railway" title="Karachi Circular Railway">Karachi Circular Railway</a> is a partially active regional <a href="/wiki/Public_transport" title="Public transport">public transit system</a> in Karachi, which serves the <a href="/wiki/Karachi_District" class="mw-redirect" title="Karachi District">Karachi metropolitan area</a>. KCR was fully operational between 1969 and 1999. Since 2001, restoration of the railway and restarting the system had been sought.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[438]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[439]</a></sup> In November 2020, the KCR partially revived operations.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[440]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>A <a href="/wiki/Mohamedali_Tramways_Company" title="Mohamedali Tramways Company">tramway service</a> service was started in 1884 in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> but was closed in 1975 due to various factors.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-445">[441]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto3_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-446">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sindh_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Sindh Government">Sindh Government</a> is planning to restart the tramway services in the city, collaborating with Austrian experts.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[443]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>In October 2019, a project for the construction of tramway service in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> has also been signed by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Government of Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab Government</a>. This project will be launched under public-private partnership in a joint venture of European and Chinese companies along with the Punjab transport department.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[444]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a> has planned to start a <a href="/wiki/Monorail" title="Monorail">monorail</a> system in the federal capital <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Flyovers_and_underpasses">Flyovers and underpasses</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_flyovers_in_Pakistan" title="List of flyovers in Pakistan">List of flyovers in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg/220px-Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg/330px-Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg/440px-Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="681"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nagan_Ch_Karachi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Nagan Chowrangi Flyover, <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Many flyovers and underpasses are located in major urban areas of the country to regulate the flow of traffic. The highest number of flyovers and under passes are located in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[445]</a></sup> Other cities having flyovers and underpasses for the regulation of flow of traffic includes <a href="/wiki/Islamabad-Rawalpindi_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamabad-Rawalpindi metropolitan area">Islamabad-Rawalpindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faisalabad" title="Faisalabad">Faisalabad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujranwala" title="Gujranwala">Gujranwala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multan" title="Multan">Multan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyderabad,_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Hyderabad, Pakistan">Hyderabad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quetta" title="Quetta">Quetta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sargodha" title="Sargodha">Sargodha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahawalpur" title="Bahawalpur">Bahawalpur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sukkur" title="Sukkur">Sukkur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Larkana" title="Larkana">Larkana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rahim_Yar_Khan" title="Rahim Yar Khan">Rahim Yar Khan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sahiwal" title="Sahiwal">Sahiwal</a> etc.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[447]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[448]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[449]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Beijing Underpass, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> is the longest underpass of Pakistan with a length of about 1.3&nbsp;km (0.81&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[450]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Town_Flyover" title="Muslim Town Flyover">Muslim Town Flyover</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> is the longest flyover of the country with a length of about 2.6&nbsp;km (1.6&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[451]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Pakistan" title="Science and technology in Pakistan">Science and technology in Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Pakistani_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Pakistani inventions and discoveries">List of Pakistani inventions and discoveries</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:315px;max-width:315px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg/100px-Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg" decoding="async" width="100" height="123" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg/150px-Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg/200px-Abdus_Salam_1987.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1520" data-file-height="1872"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Abdus_Salam" title="Abdus Salam">Abdus Salam</a> won the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> for his contribution to <a href="/wiki/Electroweak_interaction" title="Electroweak interaction">electroweak interaction</a>. He was the first Muslim to win a Nobel prize in science.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:85px;max-width:85px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Atta-Ur-Rahman_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg/83px-Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="83" height="124" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg/125px-Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg/166px-Atta-Ur-Rahman_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="729" data-file-height="1090"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Atta_ur_Rahman_(scientist)" class="mw-redirect" title="Atta ur Rahman (scientist)">Atta-ur-Rahman</a> won the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Science_Prize" title="UNESCO Science Prize">UNESCO Science Prize</a> for pioneering contributions in chemistry in 1999, the first Muslim to win it.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:122px;max-width:122px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg/120px-Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="122" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg/180px-Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg/240px-Mahbub-ul-Haq.jpg 2x" data-file-width="397" data-file-height="404"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mahbub_ul_Haq" title="Mahbub ul Haq">Mahbub ul Haq</a> was a Pakistani game theorist whose work led to the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. He had a profound effect on the field of <a href="/wiki/International_development" title="International development">international development</a>.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Developments in <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Pakistan" title="Science and technology in Pakistan">science and technology</a> have played an important role in Pakistan's infrastructure and helped the country connect to the rest of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Ministry_of_Science_and_Technology_456-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ministry_of_Science_and_Technology-456">[452]</a></sup> Every year, scientists from around the world are invited by the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Pakistan Academy of Sciences">Pakistan Academy of Sciences</a> and the Pakistan Government to participate in the <a href="/wiki/International_Nathiagali_Summer_College_on_Physics" title="International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics">International Nathiagali Summer College on Physics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[453]</a></sup> Pakistan hosted an international seminar on "Physics in Developing Countries" for the International Year of Physics 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-comsats_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comsats-458">[454]</a></sup> Pakistani theoretical physicist <a href="/wiki/Abdus_Salam" title="Abdus Salam">Abdus Salam</a> won a <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> for his work on the <a href="/wiki/Electroweak_interaction" title="Electroweak interaction">electroweak interaction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nobel_Prize_459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nobel_Prize-459">[455]</a></sup> Influential publications and critical scientific work in the advancement of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biology" title="Biology">biology</a>, economics, <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">computer science</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">genetics</a> have been produced by Pakistani scientists at both the domestic and international levels.<sup id="cite_ref-Zed,_2001_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zed,_2001-460">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salimuzzaman_Siddiqui" title="Salimuzzaman Siddiqui">Salimuzzaman Siddiqui</a> was the first Pakistani scientist to bring the therapeutic constituents of the <a href="/wiki/Neem" class="mw-redirect" title="Neem">neem</a> tree to the attention of natural products chemists.<sup id="cite_ref-TT-20110314_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TT-20110314-461">[457]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[459]</a></sup> Pakistani neurosurgeon <a href="/wiki/Ayub_K._Ommaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Ayub K. Ommaya">Ayub Ommaya</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Ommaya_reservoir" title="Ommaya reservoir">Ommaya reservoir</a>, a system for treatment of brain tumours and other brain conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[460]</a></sup> Scientific research and development play a pivotal role in <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_universities" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani universities">Pakistani universities</a>, government- sponsored national laboratories, <a href="/wiki/Science_park" title="Science park">science parks</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Industry_of_Pakistan" title="Industry of Pakistan">industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nature_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nature-465">[461]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Qadeer_Khan" title="Abdul Qadeer Khan">Abdul Qadeer Khan</a>, regarded as the founder of the <a href="/wiki/High-enriched_uranium" class="mw-redirect" title="High-enriched uranium">HEU</a>-based <a href="/wiki/Zippe-type_centrifuge" title="Zippe-type centrifuge">gas-centrifuge</a> <a href="/wiki/Uranium_enrichment" class="mw-redirect" title="Uranium enrichment">uranium enrichment</a> program for Pakistan's integrated <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction">atomic bomb project</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies-466">[462]</a></sup> He founded and established the <a href="/wiki/Kahuta_Research_Laboratories" class="mw-redirect" title="Kahuta Research Laboratories">Kahuta Research Laboratories</a> (KRL) in 1976, serving as both its senior scientist and the <a href="/wiki/Director-General" class="mw-redirect" title="Director-General">Director-General</a> until his retirement in 2001, and he was an early and vital figure in other <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Missile_Research_and_Development_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="Integrated Missile Research and Development Program">science projects</a>. Apart from participating in Pakistan's atomic bomb project, he made major contributions in <a href="/wiki/Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)">molecular morphology</a>, physical <a href="/wiki/Martensite" title="Martensite">martensite</a>, and its integrated applications in <a href="/wiki/Condensed_matter_physics" title="Condensed matter physics">condensed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Material_physics" class="mw-redirect" title="Material physics">material physics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[463]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[464]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010 Pakistan was ranked 43rd in the world in terms of published scientific papers.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn_news,_2010_469-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn_news,_2010-469">[465]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Pakistan Academy of Sciences">Pakistan Academy of Sciences</a>, a strong scientific community, plays an influential and vital role in formulating recommendations regarding science policies for the government.<sup id="cite_ref-Introduction_of_the_Academy_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Introduction_of_the_Academy-470">[466]</a></sup> </p>
      <p> The 1960s saw the emergence of an active <a href="/wiki/Asian_Space_Race" class="mw-redirect" title="Asian Space Race">space program</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Space_and_Upper_Atmosphere_Research_Commission" class="mw-redirect" title="Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission">SUPARCO</a> that produced advances in domestic <a href="/wiki/Rocket" title="Rocket">rocketry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronics_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Electronics Engineering">electronics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aeronomy" title="Aeronomy">aeronomy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SUPARCO_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SUPARCO-471">[467]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Space_and_Upper_Atmosphere_Research_Commission" class="mw-redirect" title="Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission">space program</a> recorded a few notable feats and achievements. The successful launch of its <a href="/wiki/Rehbar-I" title="Rehbar-I">first rocket</a> into space made Pakistan the first South Asian country to have achieved such a task.<sup id="cite_ref-SUPARCO_471-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SUPARCO-471">[467]</a></sup> Successfully producing and launching the nation's <a href="/wiki/Badr-I" class="mw-redirect" title="Badr-I">first space satellite</a> in 1990, Pakistan became the first Muslim country and second South Asian country to put a satellite into space.<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[469]</a></sup></p>
      <div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:25em; border-width: 1px; background-color: #c6dbf7;">
       <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"> 
       <div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
        Pakistan witnessed a fourfold increase in its scientific productivity in the past decade surging from approximately 2,000 articles per year in 2006 to more than 9,000 articles in 2015. Making Pakistan's cited article's higher than the <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRIC</a> countries put together.
       </div> 
       <p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">â<a href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters" title="Thomson Reuters">Thomson Reuters</a>'s Another BRIC in the Wall 2016 report<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[470]</a></sup></cite> </p> 
      </div>
      <p>As an aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971" title="Indo-Pakistani War of 1971">1971 war with India</a>, the clandestine <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction">crash program</a> developed <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">atomic weapons</a> partly motivated by fear and to prevent any <a href="/wiki/Foreign_interventionism" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign interventionism">foreign intervention</a>, while ushering in the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_Age" title="Atomic Age">atomic age</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Post_Cold_War_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Post Cold War era">post cold war era</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-United_Book_Press._225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-United_Book_Press.-225">[221]</a></sup> Competition with India and tensions eventually led to Pakistan's decision to <a href="/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons_tests_of_Pakistan" title="List of nuclear weapons tests of Pakistan">conduct underground</a> <a href="/wiki/Chagai-I" title="Chagai-I">nuclear tests</a> in 1998, thus becoming the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_club" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear club">seventh country</a> in the world to successfully develop <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Federation_of_American_Scientists_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Federation_of_American_Scientists-475">[471]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistan is the first and only Muslim country that maintains an <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Antarctic_Programme" title="Pakistan Antarctic Programme">active research presence</a> in Antarctica.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[472]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[474]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[475]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[476]</a></sup> Since 1991 Pakistan has maintained two summer research stations and one weather observatory on the continent and plans to open another full-fledged permanent base in Antarctica.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[477]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Energy consumption by computers and usage has grown since the 1990s when <a href="/wiki/Personal_computer" title="Personal computer">PCs</a> were introduced; Pakistan has about 82&nbsp;million Internet users and is ranked as one of the top countries that have registered a high growth rate in Internet penetration as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-PTD_389-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PTD-389">[385]</a></sup> Key publications have been produced by Pakistan, and domestic software development has gained considerable international praise.<sup id="cite_ref-Lahore_Tech_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lahore_Tech-482">[478]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of May 2020, Pakistan has about 82&nbsp;million internet users, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">9th-largest population</a> of Internet users in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-PTD_389-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PTD-389">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-auto2_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-390">[386]</a></sup> Since the 2000s Pakistan has made a significant amount of progress in <a href="/wiki/Supercomputing_in_Pakistan" title="Supercomputing in Pakistan">supercomputing</a>, and various institutions offer research opportunities in <a href="/wiki/Parallel_computing" title="Parallel computing">parallel computing</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Pakistan government</a> reportedly spends <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_rupee" title="Pakistani rupee">â¨</a> 4.6&nbsp;billion on <a href="/wiki/Information_technology_in_Pakistan" title="Information technology in Pakistan">information technology</a> projects, with emphasis on <a href="/wiki/E-Government_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="E-Government in Pakistan">e-government</a>, human resources, and infrastructure development.<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[479]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Pakistan" title="Education in Pakistan">Education in Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Higher_Education_Commission_(Pakistan)" title="Higher Education Commission (Pakistan)">Higher Education Commission (Pakistan)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_Pakistan" title="Rankings of universities in Pakistan">Rankings of universities in Pakistan</a>
      </div>
      <p> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">constitution of Pakistan</a> requires the state to provide <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free</a> primary and secondary education.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485">[481]</a></sup></p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg/220px-Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg/330px-Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg/440px-Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Central_Library_of_University_of_Sargodha.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Central Library of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Sargodha" title="University of Sargodha">University of Sargodha</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At the time of the <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Creation of Pakistan">establishment</a> of Pakistan as a state, the country had only one university, <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Punjab" title="University of the Punjab">Punjab University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[482]</a></sup> Very soon the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Pakistan government</a> established public universities in each of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Provinces_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Four Provinces (Pakistan)">four provinces</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Sindh_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Sindh University">Sindh University</a> (1949), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Peshawar" title="University of Peshawar">Peshawar University</a> (1950), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Karachi" title="University of Karachi">Karachi University</a> (1953), and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Balochistan" title="University of Balochistan">Balochistan University</a> (1970). Pakistan has a large network of both <a href="/wiki/Public_universities" class="mw-redirect" title="Public universities">public</a> and <a href="/wiki/Private_universities" class="mw-redirect" title="Private universities">private</a> universities, which includes collaboration between the <a href="/wiki/Universities_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities in Pakistan">universities</a> aimed at providing research and <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Higher education in Pakistan">higher education</a> opportunities in the country, although there is concern about the low quality of teaching in many of the newer schools.<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[483]</a></sup> It is estimated that there are 3,193 <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">technical and vocational institutions</a> in Pakistan,<sup id="cite_ref-edu2_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu2-488">[484]</a></sup> and there are also <i><a href="/wiki/Madrassas_in_Pakistan" title="Madrassas in Pakistan">madrassahs</a></i> that provide free Islamic education and offer free board and lodging to students, who come mainly from the poorer strata of society.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[485]</a></sup> Strong public pressure and popular criticism over <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Taleban" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Taleban">extremists</a>' usage of <i>madrassahs</i> for recruitment, the Pakistan government has made repeated efforts to <a href="/wiki/Education_reform" title="Education reform">regulate and monitor</a> the quality of education in the <i>madrassahs</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[486]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jinnah_Institute_of_Peace_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jinnah_Institute_of_Peace-491">[487]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png/300px-Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="198" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png/450px-Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png/600px-Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png 2x" data-file-width="674" data-file-height="444"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Literacy_rate_in_Pakistan_1951-2018.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Literacy rate in Pakistan 1951â2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Pakistan" title="Education in Pakistan">Education in Pakistan</a> is divided into six main levels: nursery (preparatory classes); primary (grades one through five); <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle</a> (grades six through eight); <a href="/wiki/High_school_(upper_secondary)" class="mw-redirect" title="High school (upper secondary)">matriculation</a> (grades nine and ten, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Secondary_School_Certificate" title="Secondary School Certificate">secondary certificate</a>); <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">intermediate</a> (grades eleven and twelve, leading to a <a href="/wiki/Higher_Secondary_(School)_Certificate" class="mw-redirect" title="Higher Secondary (School) Certificate">higher secondary certificate</a>); and university programmes leading to graduate and postgraduate degrees.<sup id="cite_ref-edu2_488-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu2-488">[484]</a></sup> There is a network of <a href="/wiki/Schools_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Schools in Pakistan">private schools</a> that constitutes a parallel secondary education system based on a curriculum set and administered by the <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_International_Examinations" class="mw-redirect" title="Cambridge International Examinations">Cambridge International Examinations</a> of the United Kingdom. Some students choose to take the <a href="/wiki/Ordinary_Level" class="mw-redirect" title="Ordinary Level">O-level</a> and <a href="/wiki/GCE_Advanced_Level" title="GCE Advanced Level">A level</a> exams conducted by the <a href="/wiki/British_Council" title="British Council">British Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britishcouncil_492-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britishcouncil-492">[488]</a></sup> According to the International Schools Consultancy, Pakistan has 439 international schools.<sup id="cite_ref-iscresearch.com_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iscresearch.com-493">[489]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Malala_Yousafzai.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Malala_Yousafzai.jpg/220px-Malala_Yousafzai.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Malala_Yousafzai.jpg/330px-Malala_Yousafzai.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Malala_Yousafzai.jpg/440px-Malala_Yousafzai.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Malala_Yousafzai.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Malala Yousafzai at the Women of the World festival in 2014.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a result of initiatives taken in 2007, the <a href="/wiki/English_medium_education" class="mw-redirect" title="English medium education">English medium education</a> has been made compulsory in all schools across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-British_Council_Pakistan_Bureau_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-British_Council_Pakistan_Bureau-494">[490]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-moe3_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moe3-495">[491]</a></sup> In 2012, <a href="/wiki/Malala_Yousafzai" title="Malala Yousafzai">Malala Yousafzai</a>, a campaigner for <a href="/wiki/Female_education" title="Female education">female education</a>, was shot by a <a href="/wiki/Tehrik-i_Taliban_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Tehrik-i Taliban Pakistan">Taliban</a> gunman in retaliation for her activism.<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[492]</a></sup> Yousafzai went on to become the youngest ever Nobel laureate for her global education-related advocacy.<sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[493]</a></sup> Additional reforms enacted in 2013 required all educational institutions in Sindh to begin offering Chinese language courses, reflecting China's growing role as a superpower and its <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic of ChinaâPakistan relations">increasing influence</a> in Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[494]</a></sup> The literacy rate of the population is 62.3% as of 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-Economic_Survey_2018-19_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economic_Survey_2018-19-499">[495]</a></sup> The rate of male literacy is 72.5% while the rate of female literacy is 51.8%.<sup id="cite_ref-Economic_Survey_2018-19_499-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economic_Survey_2018-19-499">[495]</a></sup> Literacy rates vary by region and particularly by sex; as one example, in tribal areas female literacy is 9.5%,<sup id="cite_ref-fata.gov.pk_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fata.gov.pk-500">[496]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Azad_Jammu_%26_Kashmir" class="mw-redirect" title="Azad Jammu &amp; Kashmir">Azad Jammu &amp; Kashmir</a> has a literacy rate of 74%.<sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[497]</a></sup> With the advent of computer literacy in 1995, the government launched a nationwide initiative in 1998 with the aim of eradicating <a href="/wiki/Illiteracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Illiteracy">illiteracy</a> and providing a basic education to all children.<sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[498]</a></sup> Through various educational reforms, by 2015 the <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_Education_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Minister for Education (Pakistan)">Ministry of Education</a> expected to attain 100% enrollment levels among children of primary school age and a literacy rate of ~86% among people aged over 10.<sup id="cite_ref-moe4_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moe4-503">[499]</a></sup> Pakistan is currently spending 2.3&nbsp;percent of its GDP on education;<sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[500]</a></sup> which according to the <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Social_and_Policy_Sciences" title="Institute of Social and Policy Sciences">Institute of Social and Policy Sciences</a> is one of the lowest in South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[501]</a></sup> </p>
