      <p><br> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Pakistan" title="Religion in Pakistan">Religion in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> <sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[544]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[545]</a></sup>
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Pakistan" title="Religion in Pakistan">Religions in Pakistan</a> (2017 Census)<sup id="cite_ref-2017_Census_521-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2017_Census-521">[517]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cia-rel_544-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-rel-544">[540]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-545">[541]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">[542]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">[543]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">Religions</td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">Percent</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:green; width:96.47%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">96.47%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:orange; width:2.14%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.14%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:1.27%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.27%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Pakistan#Demographics_of_religion_in_Pakistan" title="Religion in Pakistan">others/non-religious</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:purple; width:0.11%; overflow: hidden;">
             â
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.11%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The state religion in Pakistan is <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nazaria-e-Pakistan,_Part_IV_550-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nazaria-e-Pakistan,_Part_IV-550">[546]</a></sup> Freedom of religion is guaranteed by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">Constitution of Pakistan</a>, which provides all its citizens the right to profess, practice and propagate their religion subject to law, public order, and morality.<sup id="cite_ref-551" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-551">[547]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The population of Pakistan follow different religions. Most of Pakistanis are <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslims</a> (96.47%) followed by <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindus</a> (2.14%) and <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> (1.27%). There are also people in Pakistan who follow other religions, such as <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_Pakistan" title="Sikhism in Pakistan">Sikhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Pakistan" title="Buddhism in Pakistan">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jainism_in_Pakistan" title="Jainism in Pakistan">Jainism</a> and the minority of <a href="/wiki/Parsi" class="mw-redirect" title="Parsi">Parsi</a> (who follow <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Kalash_people" title="Kalash people">Kalash people</a> maintain a unique identity and religion within Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">[548]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In addition, some Pakistanis also do not profess any faith (such as <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostics</a>) in Pakistan. According to the 1998 census, people who did not state their religion accounted for 0.5% of the population. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">Islam</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Pakistan" title="Islam in Pakistan">Islam in Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sufism_in_Pakistan" title="Sufism in Pakistan">Sufism in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Faisal_Masjid.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Faisal_Masjid.jpg/180px-Faisal_Masjid.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="272" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Faisal_Masjid.jpg/270px-Faisal_Masjid.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Faisal_Masjid.jpg/360px-Faisal_Masjid.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="1510"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Faisal_Masjid.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Faisal_Mosque" title="Faisal Mosque">Faisal Mosque</a>, built in 1986 by Turkish architect <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Dalokay" title="Vedat Dalokay">Vedat Dalokay</a> on behalf of <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">King</a> <a href="/wiki/Faisal_bin_Abdul-Aziz" class="mw-redirect" title="Faisal bin Abdul-Aziz">Faisal bin Abdul-Aziz</a> of Saudi Arabia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Islam is the dominant religion.<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">[549]</a></sup> About 96.47% of <a href="/wiki/Pakistanis" title="Pakistanis">Pakistanis</a> are Muslim, according to the 2017 Census.<sup id="cite_ref-2017_Census_521-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2017_Census-521">[517]</a></sup> Pakistan has the second-largest number of <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslims</a> in the world after Indonesia.<sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[550]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">[551]</a></sup> and home for (10.5%) of the world's Muslim population.<sup id="cite_ref-PewDec2012_556-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-556">[552]</a></sup> The majority of them are <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> and mostly follows <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a> (estimated between 75 and 95%)<sup id="cite_ref-LoC2_557-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LoC2-557">[553]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_558-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-558">[554]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PRC_559-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRC-559">[555]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PRCPDF_560-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PRCPDF-560">[556]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-State2_561-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State2-561">[557]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shias</a> represent between 5â25%.<sup id="cite_ref-LoC2_557-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LoC2-557">[553]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_558-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-558">[554]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_562-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-562">[558]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIAr2_563-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAr2-563">[559]</a></sup> As of 2019, Shia population in Pakistan was estimated to be 42 million out of total population of 210 million.<sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564">[560]</a></sup> Pakistan also has the largest Muslim city in the world (<a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-565">[561]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya_in_Pakistan" title="Ahmadiyya in Pakistan">Ahmadis</a>, a small minority representing 0.22â2% of Pakistan's population,<sup id="cite_ref-ahmadi_566-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahmadi-566">[562]</a></sup> are officially considered non-Muslims by virtue of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Second Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan">constitutional amendment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-567" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-567">[563]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadis" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmadis">Ahmadis</a> are particularly persecuted, especially since 1974 when they were <a href="/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Second Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan">banned</a> from calling themselves Muslims. In 1984, Ahmadiyya places of worship were banned from being called "mosques".<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568">[564]</a></sup> As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 12% of Pakistani Muslims self-identify as <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-denominational Muslims">non-denominational Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569">[565]</a></sup> There are also several <a href="/wiki/Quraniyoon" class="mw-redirect" title="Quraniyoon">Quraniyoon</a> communities.<sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-570">[566]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-571" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-571">[567]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a>, a mystical Islamic tradition, has a long history and a large following among the Sunni Muslims in Pakistan, at both the academic and popular levels. Popular Sufi culture is centered around gatherings and celebrations at the shrines of saints and annual festivals that feature Sufi music and dance. Two Sufis whose shrines receive much national attention are <a href="/wiki/Ali_Hajweri" class="mw-redirect" title="Ali Hajweri">Ali Hajweri</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> (c.&nbsp;12th century)<sup id="cite_ref-Amer_Morgahi_572-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amer_Morgahi-572">[568]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shahbaz_Qalander" class="mw-redirect" title="Shahbaz Qalander">Shahbaz Qalander</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sehwan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sehwan">Sehwan</a>, Sindh (c.&nbsp;12th century).<sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573">[569]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are two levels of <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufism</a> in Pakistan. The first is the 'populist' Sufism of the rural population. This level of Sufism involves belief in intercession through saints, veneration of their shrines, and forming bonds (Mureed) with a <i>pir</i> (saint). Many rural Pakistani Muslims associate with <a href="/wiki/Pir_(Sufism)" title="Pir (Sufism)"><i>pirs</i></a> and seek their intercession.<sup id="cite_ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574">[570]</a></sup> The second level of Sufism in Pakistan is 'intellectual Sufism', which is growing among the urban and educated population. They are influenced by the writings of Sufis such as the medieval theologian <a href="/wiki/Al-Ghazali" title="Al-Ghazali">al-Ghazali</a>, the Sufi reformer <a href="/wiki/Shaykh_Ahmad_Sirhindi" class="mw-redirect" title="Shaykh Ahmad Sirhindi">Shaykh Aá¸¥mad Sirhindi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shah_Wali_Allah" class="mw-redirect" title="Shah Wali Allah">Shah Wali Allah</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575">[571]</a></sup> Contemporary Islamic fundamentalists criticise Sufism's popular character, which in their view does not accurately reflect the teachings and practice of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> and his companions.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTSufivideo_576-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTSufivideo-576">[572]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hinduism">Hinduism</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Pakistan" title="Hinduism in Pakistan">Hinduism in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg/220px-Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg/330px-Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg/440px-Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2576" data-file-height="1932"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nani_ki_Mandir2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Shri_Hinglaj_Mata_temple" class="mw-redirect" title="Shri Hinglaj Mata temple">Shri Hinglaj Mata temple</a> shakti peetha is the largest Hindu pilgrimage centre in Pakistan. The annual Hinglaj Yathra is attended by more than 250,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">[573]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Pakistan" title="Hinduism in Pakistan">Hinduism</a> is the second-largest religion in Pakistan after Islam, according to the 1998 census.<sup id="cite_ref-1998Census_578-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1998Census-578">[574]</a></sup> As of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Pakistan had the fifth-largest Hindu population in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579">[575]</a></sup> In the 1998 census, the Hindu (jati) population was found to be 2,111,271 while the Hindu (scheduled castes) numbered an additional 332,343.<sup id="cite_ref-1998Census_578-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1998Census-578">[574]</a></sup> Hindus are found in all provinces of Pakistan but are mostly concentrated in Sindh. They speak a variety of languages such as <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seraiki_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Seraiki language">Seraiki</a>, Aer, Dhatki, Gera, Goaria, Gurgula, Jandavra, Kabutra, Koli, Loarki, <a href="/wiki/Marwari_language" title="Marwari language">Marwari</a>, Sansi, Vaghri,<sup id="cite_ref-580" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-580">[576]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:72_526-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:72-526">[522]</a></sup> </p>
      <p> At the time of Pakistan's creation, the 'hostage theory' gained currency. According to this theory, the Hindu minority in Pakistan was to be given a fair deal in Pakistan in order to ensure the protection of the Muslim minority in India.<sup id="cite_ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581">[577]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-582" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-582">[578]</a></sup> However, Khawaja Nazimuddin, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Prime Ministers of Pakistan">second</a> <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan" title="Prime Minister of Pakistan">Prime Minister of Pakistan</a>, stated:<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style></p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>I do not agree that religion is a private affair of the individual nor do I agree that in an Islamic state every citizen has identical rights, no matter what his caste, creed or faith be.<sup id="cite_ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583">[579]</a></sup></p>
      </blockquote>
      <p> Some Hindus in Pakistan feel that they are treated as second-class citizens and many have continued to migrate to India.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc200703022_584-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc200703022-584">[580]</a></sup> Pakistani Hindus faced riots after the <a href="/wiki/Demolition_of_the_Babri_Masjid" title="Demolition of the Babri Masjid">Babri Masjid demolition</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-A_585-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A-585">[581]</a></sup> endured a massacre (in 2005) by security forces in Balochistan,<sup id="cite_ref-586" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-586">[582]</a></sup> and have experienced other attacks, forced conversions, and abductions.<sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587">[583]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588">[584]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589">[585]</a></sup> </p>
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity_and_other_religions">Christianity and other religions</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg/220px-Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="192" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg/330px-Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg/440px-Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3707" data-file-height="3238"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Church_Sacred_Heart.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sacred_Heart_Cathedral,_Lahore" title="Sacred Heart Cathedral, Lahore">Sacred Heart Cathedral, Lahore</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Christians formed the next largest religious minority, after Hindus, with 1.27% of the population following it.<sup id="cite_ref-2017_Census_521-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2017_Census-521">[517]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_590-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-590">[586]</a></sup> They were followed by the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="BahÃ¡'Ã­ Faith in Pakistan">BahÃ¡'Ã­ Faith</a>, which had a following of 30,000, then <a href="/wiki/Sikhism_in_Pakistan" title="Sikhism in Pakistan">Sikhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Pakistan" title="Buddhism in Pakistan">Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a>, each back then claiming 20,000 adherents,<sup id="cite_ref-State_591-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-State-591">[587]</a></sup> and a very small <a href="/wiki/Jainism_in_Pakistan" title="Jainism in Pakistan">community of Jains</a>. There is a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Pakistan">Roman Catholic</a> community in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> that was established by <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tamil_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tamil people">Tamil</a> migrants when Karachi's infrastructure was being developed by the British during the colonial administration between <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. The influence of <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Pakistan" title="Irreligion in Pakistan">atheism</a> is very small, with 1.0% of the population identifying as atheist in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn,_Irfan_592-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn,_Irfan-592">[588]</a></sup> However, the figure rose to 2.0% in 2012 according to <a href="/wiki/WIN/GIA" title="WIN/GIA">Gallup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn,_Irfan_592-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn,_Irfan-592">[588]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_society">Culture and society</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/British_heritage_of_Pakistan" title="British heritage of Pakistan">British heritage of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Pakistan" title="Culture of Pakistan">Culture of Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Pakistan" title="Public holidays in Pakistan">Public holidays in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg/220px-W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg/330px-W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg/440px-W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:W-P-AD20070217-16h21m13s-e.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Truck_art_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Truck art in Pakistan">Truck art</a> is a distinctive feature of Pakistani culture.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Pakistani_society" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani society">Civil society</a> in Pakistan is largely hierarchical, emphasising <a href="/wiki/Etiquette_in_Pakistan" title="Etiquette in Pakistan">local cultural etiquette</a> and traditional Islamic values that govern personal and political life. The basic family unit is the <a href="/wiki/Extended_family" title="Extended family">extended family</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-nuclear_593-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuclear-593">[589]</a></sup> although for socio-economic reasons there has been a growing trend towards <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_family" title="Nuclear family">nuclear families</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-594" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-594">[590]</a></sup> The traditional dress for both men and women is the <i><a href="/wiki/Shalwar_Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Shalwar Kameez">Shalwar Kameez</a></i>; trousers, <a href="/wiki/Jeans" title="Jeans">jeans</a>, and shirts are also popular among men.<sup id="cite_ref-taxila_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taxila-51">[47]</a></sup> In recent decades, the middle class has increased to around 35&nbsp;million and the upper and upper-middle classes to around 17&nbsp;million, and power is shifting from rural landowners to the urbanised elites.<sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595">[591]</a></sup> Pakistani festivals, including <a href="/wiki/Eid_ul-Fitr" class="mw-redirect" title="Eid ul-Fitr"><i>Eid-ul-Fitr</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha"><i>Eid-ul-Azha</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan"><i>Ramazan</i></a>, Christmas, Easter, <a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, are mostly religious in origin.<sup id="cite_ref-nuclear_593-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nuclear-593">[589]</a></sup> Increasing globalisation has resulted in Pakistan ranking 56th on the <a href="/wiki/A.T._Kearney" class="mw-redirect" title="A.T. Kearney">A.T. Kearney</a>/FP <a href="/wiki/Globalization_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Globalization Index">Globalization Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-596" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-596">[592]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Clothing.2C_arts.2C_and_fashion"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Clothing,_arts,_and_fashion">Clothing, arts, and fashion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_clothing" title="Pakistani clothing">Pakistani clothing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">Shalwar kameez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sherwani" title="Sherwani">Sherwani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jinnah_cap" class="mw-redirect" title="Jinnah cap">Jinnah cap</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Peshawari_chappal" title="Peshawari chappal">Peshawari chappal</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg/220px-Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg/330px-Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg/440px-Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kail_Neelum_Valley_AJK.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>People in traditional clothing in <a href="/wiki/Neelum_District" title="Neelum District">Neelum District</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez"><i>Shalwar Kameez</i></a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_dress" class="mw-redirect" title="National dress">national dress</a> of Pakistan and is worn by both men and women in all <a href="/wiki/Four_Provinces_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Four Provinces (Pakistan)">four provinces</a>: <a href="/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan" title="Punjab, Pakistan">Punjab</a>, Sindh, Balochistan, and <a href="/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtoonkhwa" class="mw-redirect" title="Khyber Pakhtoonkhwa">Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a>. Each province has its own style of <i>Shalwar Kameez</i>. Pakistanis wear clothes in a range of exquisite colours and designs and in type of fabric (silk, <a href="/wiki/Chiffon_(fabric)" title="Chiffon (fabric)">chiffon</a>, cotton, etc.).<sup id="cite_ref-Books.google.com_597-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Books.google.com-597">[593]</a></sup> Besides the national dress, domestically tailored <a href="/wiki/Suit_(clothing)" class="mw-redirect" title="Suit (clothing)">suits</a> and neckties are often worn by men, and are customary in offices, schools, and social gatherings.<sup id="cite_ref-Books.google.com_597-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Books.google.com-597">[593]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_fashion" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani fashion">fashion industry</a> has flourished in the changing environment of the fashion world. Since Pakistan came into being, its fashion has evolved in different phases and developed a unique identity. Today, Pakistani fashion is a combination of traditional and modern dress and has become a mark of Pakistani culture. Despite modern trends, regional and traditional forms of dress have developed their own significance as a symbol of native tradition. This regional fashion continues to evolve into both more modern and purer forms. The Pakistan Fashion Design Council based in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> organizes <a href="/wiki/PFDC_Sunsilk_Fashion_Week" title="PFDC Sunsilk Fashion Week">PFDC Fashion Week</a> and the Fashion Pakistan Council based in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> organizes <a href="/wiki/Fashion_Pakistan_Week" title="Fashion Pakistan Week">Fashion Pakistan Week</a>. Pakistan's first fashion week was held in November 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-598" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-598">[594]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_entertainment">Media and entertainment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Pakistan" title="Cinema of Pakistan">Cinema of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Pakistan">Media of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Pakistan" title="Music of Pakistan">Music of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistani_pop_music" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Pakistani pop music">History of Pakistani pop music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Pakistan" title="Theatre of Pakistan">Theatre of Pakistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_dramas" title="Pakistani dramas">Pakistani dramas</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The private <a href="/wiki/Newspapers_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Newspapers in Pakistan">print media</a>, state-owned <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Television_Corporation" title="Pakistan Television Corporation">Pakistan Television Corporation</a> (PTV), and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Broadcasting_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation">Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation</a> (PBC) for <a href="/wiki/Radio_Pakistan" title="Radio Pakistan">radio</a> were the dominant media outlets until the beginning of the 21st century. Pakistan now has a large network of domestic, privately owned 24-hour <a href="/wiki/News_channels_in_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="News channels in Pakistan">news media</a> and <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Pakistan" title="Television in Pakistan">television channels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-media_599-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-media-599">[595]</a></sup> A 2016 report by the <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> ranked Pakistan 147th on the <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>, while at the same time terming the Pakistani media "among the freest in Asia when it comes to covering the squabbling among politicians."<sup id="cite_ref-600" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-600">[596]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> terms the Pakistani media "among the most outspoken in South Asia".<sup id="cite_ref-601" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-601">[597]</a></sup> Pakistani media has also played a vital role in exposing corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-i-m-s.dk_602-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-i-m-s.dk-602">[598]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Lollywood" title="Lollywood">Lollywood</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kariwood" class="mw-redirect" title="Kariwood">Kariwood</a>, Punjabi, and <a href="/wiki/Pashto_cinema" title="Pashto cinema">Pashto</a> film industry is based in Karachi, Lahore, and Peshawar. While <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" title="Bollywood">Bollywood</a> films were banned from public cinemas from 1965 until 2008, they have remained an important part of popular culture.<sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603">[599]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbcentertainment_604-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcentertainment-604">[600]</a></sup> In contrast to the ailing Pakistani film industry, Urdu <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_dramas" title="Pakistani dramas">televised dramas</a> and theatrical performances continue to be popular, as many <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Pakistan" title="Television in Pakistan">entertainment media outlets</a> air them regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-Brown_Girl_605-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brown_Girl-605">[601]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_dramas" title="Pakistani dramas">Urdu dramas</a> dominate the <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Pakistan" title="Television in Pakistan">television entertainment industry</a>, which has launched critically acclaimed <a href="/wiki/Miniseries" title="Miniseries">miniseries</a> and featured popular actors and actresses since the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_Times_2014_606-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_Times_2014-606">[602]</a></sup> In the 1960sâ1970s, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_pop_music" title="Pakistani pop music">pop music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Disco_Deewane" title="Disco Deewane">disco</a> (1970s) dominated the country's music industry. In the 1980sâ1990s, <a href="/wiki/New_wave_of_British_heavy_metal" title="New wave of British heavy metal">British influenced</a> <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_rock" title="Pakistani rock">rock music</a> appeared and jolted the country's entertainment industry.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn_News,_Nadeem_F._Paracha_607-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn_News,_Nadeem_F._Paracha-607">[603]</a></sup> In the 2000s, <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal music</a> gained popular and critical acclaim.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_Pakistan_608-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN_Pakistan-608">[604]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pakistani music ranges from diverse forms of provincial folk music and traditional styles such as <a href="/wiki/Qawwali" title="Qawwali">Qawwali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ghazal" title="Ghazal">Ghazal</a> Gayaki to modern musical forms that fuse traditional and western music.<sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609">[605]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-610" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-610">[606]</a></sup> Pakistan has many famous folk singers. The arrival of Afghan refugees in the western provinces has stimulated interest in Pashto music, although there has been intolerance of it in some places.<sup id="cite_ref-611" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-611">[607]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diaspora">Diaspora</span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Pakistani" title="Overseas Pakistani">Overseas Pakistani</a>
      </div>
      <p>According to the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Pakistan has the sixth-largest diaspora in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_541-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-541">[537]</a></sup> Statistics gathered by the Pakistani government show that there are around 7&nbsp;million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pakistan_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pakistan people (page does not exist)">Pakistanis</a> residing abroad, with the vast majority living in the Middle East, Europe, and North America.<sup id="cite_ref-612" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-612">[608]</a></sup> Pakistan ranks 10th in the world for remittances sent home.<sup id="cite_ref-overseaspakistanis1_613-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overseaspakistanis1-613">[609]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-worldbank1_614-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank1-614">[610]</a></sup> The largest inflow of remittances, as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pakistan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, is from Saudi Arabia, amounting to $5.9&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-615" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-615">[611]</a></sup> The term <i><a href="/wiki/Overseas_Pakistani" title="Overseas Pakistani">Overseas Pakistani</a></i> is officially recognised by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan" title="Government of Pakistan">Government of Pakistan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Overseas_Pakistanis" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Overseas Pakistanis">Ministry of Overseas Pakistanis</a> was established in 2008 to deal exclusively with all matters of overseas Pakistanis such as attending to their needs and problems, developing projects for their welfare, and working for resolution of their problems and issues. Overseas Pakistanis are the second-largest source of foreign exchange remittances to Pakistan after exports. Over the last several years, home remittances have maintained a steadily rising trend, with a more than 100% increase from US$8.9&nbsp;billion in 2009â10 to US$19.9&nbsp;billion in 2015â16.<sup id="cite_ref-remit_370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-remit-370">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-overseaspakistanis1_613-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overseaspakistanis1-613">[609]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-worldbank1_614-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank1-614">[610]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Overseas Pakistani Division (OPD) was created in September 2004 within the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Labour_(Pakistan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Labour (Pakistan)">Ministry of Labour</a> (MoL). It has since recognised the importance of overseas Pakistanis and their contribution to the nation's economy. Together with Community Welfare Attaches (CWAs) and the Overseas Pakistanis Foundation (OPF), the OPD is making efforts to improve the welfare of Pakistanis who reside abroad. The division aims to provide better services through improved facilities at airports, and suitable schemes for housing, education, and health care. It also facilitates the reintegration into society of returning overseas Pakistanis. Notable members of the Pakistani diaspora include <a href="/wiki/London_Mayor" class="mw-redirect" title="London Mayor">London Mayor</a> <a href="/wiki/Sadiq_Khan" title="Sadiq Khan">Sadiq Khan</a>, UK Cabinet Member <a href="/wiki/Sajid_Javid" title="Sajid Javid">Sajid Javid</a>, former <a href="/wiki/UK_Conservative_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="UK Conservative Party">UK Conservative Party</a> Chair <a href="/wiki/Sayeeda_Warsi,_Baroness_Warsi" title="Sayeeda Warsi, Baroness Warsi">Baroness Warsi</a>, singers <a href="/wiki/Zayn_Malik" title="Zayn Malik">Zayn Malik</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Ali_(singer)" title="Nadia Ali (singer)">Nadia Ali</a>, <a href="/wiki/MIT" class="mw-redirect" title="MIT">MIT</a> Physics Professor <a href="/wiki/Nergis_Mavalvala" title="Nergis Mavalvala">Dr. Nergis Mavalvala</a>, actors <a href="/wiki/Riz_Ahmed" title="Riz Ahmed">Riz Ahmed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kumail_Nanjiani" title="Kumail Nanjiani">Kumail Nanjiani</a>, businessmen <a href="/wiki/Shahid_Khan" title="Shahid Khan">Shahid Khan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sir_Anwar_Pervez" class="mw-redirect" title="Sir Anwar Pervez">Sir Anwar Pervez</a>, Boston University professors <a href="/wiki/Adil_Najam" title="Adil Najam">Adil Najam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hamid_Nawab" title="Hamid Nawab">Hamid Nawab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas_A%26M_University" title="Texas A&amp;M University">Texas A&amp;M</a> Professor <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Suhail_Zubairy" title="Muhammad Suhail Zubairy">Muhammad Suhail Zubairy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yale" class="mw-redirect" title="Yale">Yale</a> Professor <a href="/wiki/Sara_Suleri" class="mw-redirect" title="Sara Suleri">Sara Suleri</a>, <a href="/wiki/UC_San_Diego" class="mw-redirect" title="UC San Diego">UC San Diego</a> Professor <a href="/wiki/Farooq_Azam" title="Farooq Azam">Farooq Azam</a>, and historian <a href="/wiki/Ayesha_Jalal" title="Ayesha Jalal">Ayesha Jalal</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Literature_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Literature of Pakistan">Literature of Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu_poetry" title="Urdu poetry">Urdu poetry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_philosophy" title="Pakistani philosophy">Pakistani philosophy</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Iqbal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Muhammad Iqbal" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Iqbal.jpg/140px-Iqbal.jpg" decoding="async" width="140" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Iqbal.jpg/210px-Iqbal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8a/Iqbal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="227" data-file-height="300"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Iqbal.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Iqbal" title="Muhammad Iqbal">Muhammad Iqbal</a>, Pakistan's national poet who conceived the <a href="/wiki/Conception_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Conception of Pakistan">idea</a> of Pakistan
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistan has literature in <a href="/wiki/Urdu_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Urdu literature">Urdu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_literature" title="Sindhi literature">Sindhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_literature" title="Punjabi literature">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pashto_literature_and_poetry" title="Pashto literature and poetry">Pashto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balochi_Academy" title="Balochi Academy">Baluchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_English_literature" title="Pakistani English literature">English</a>, and many other languages.<sup id="cite_ref-MohanramRajan1996_616-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MohanramRajan1996-616">[612]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Academy_of_Letters" title="Pakistan Academy of Letters">Pakistan Academy of Letters</a> is a large literary community that promotes literature and poetry in Pakistan and abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-617" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-617">[613]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Pakistan" title="National Library of Pakistan">National Library</a> publishes and promotes literature in the country. Before the 19th century, Pakistani literature consisted mainly of <a href="/wiki/Lyric_poetry" title="Lyric poetry">lyric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sufi_poetry" title="Sufi poetry">religious poetry</a> and mystical and <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_folklore" title="Pakistani folklore">folkloric</a> works. During the colonial period, native literary figures were influenced by western <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">literary realism</a> and took up increasingly varied topics and narrative forms. Prose fiction is now very popular.<sup id="cite_ref-618" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-618">[614]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-granta_619-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-granta-619">[615]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg/220px-Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg/330px-Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg/440px-Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="4068"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam_Multan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Shah_Rukn-e-Alam" title="Tomb of Shah Rukn-e-Alam">Tomb of Shah Rukn-e-Alam</a> is part of Pakistan's Sufi heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620">[616]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_poets" class="mw-redirect" title="List of national poets">national poet</a> of Pakistan, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Iqbal" title="Muhammad Iqbal">Muhammad Iqbal</a>, wrote poetry in Urdu and Persian. He was a strong proponent of the political and spiritual revival of Islamic civilisation and encouraged Muslims all over the world to bring about a successful revolution.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2017)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-621" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-621">[617]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-622" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-622">[618]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-allamaiqbal.com_623-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allamaiqbal.com-623">[619]</a></sup> Well-known figures in contemporary Pakistani Urdu literature include <a href="/wiki/Josh_Malihabadi" title="Josh Malihabadi">Josh Malihabadi</a> <a href="/wiki/Faiz_Ahmed_Faiz" class="mw-redirect" title="Faiz Ahmed Faiz">Faiz Ahmed Faiz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saadat_Hasan_Manto" title="Saadat Hasan Manto">Saadat Hasan Manto</a>. <a href="/wiki/Sadequain" title="Sadequain">Sadequain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gulgee" class="mw-redirect" title="Gulgee">Gulgee</a> are known for their calligraphy and paintings.<sup id="cite_ref-granta_619-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-granta-619">[615]</a></sup> The Sufi poets <a href="/wiki/Shah_Abdul_Latif" class="mw-redirect" title="Shah Abdul Latif">Shah Abdul Latif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulleh_Shah" title="Bulleh Shah">Bulleh Shah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mian_Muhammad_Bakhsh" title="Mian Muhammad Bakhsh">Mian Muhammad Bakhsh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Khawaja_Farid" class="mw-redirect" title="Khawaja Farid">Khawaja Farid</a> enjoy considerable popularity in Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-624" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-624">[620]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Kalich_Beg" title="Mirza Kalich Beg">Mirza Kalich Beg</a> has been termed the father of modern Sindhi prose.<sup id="cite_ref-Karnani2003_625-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Karnani2003-625">[621]</a></sup> Historically, philosophical development in the country was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Iqbal" title="Muhammad Iqbal">Muhammad Iqbal</a>, Sir Syed Ahmad Khan, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Asad" title="Muhammad Asad">Muhammad Asad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Ala%27_Mawdudi" class="mw-redirect" title="Abu Ala' Mawdudi">Maududi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_Jouhar" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammad Ali Jouhar">Mohammad Ali Johar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-626" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-626">[622]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ideas from <a href="/wiki/British_philosophy" title="British philosophy">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_philosophy" title="American philosophy">American philosophy</a> greatly shaped <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_philosophy" title="Pakistani philosophy">philosophical development</a> in Pakistan. Analysts such as <a href="/wiki/M._M._Sharif" title="M. M. Sharif">M. M. Sharif</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syed_Zafarul_Hasan" title="Syed Zafarul Hasan">Zafar Hassan</a> established the first major Pakistani philosophical movement in 1947.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2017)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Work_published_by_Pakistan_Philosophical_Congress_627-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Work_published_by_Pakistan_Philosophical_Congress-627">[623]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1971" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Pakistani war of 1971">1971 war</a>, philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Jalaludin_Abdur_Rahim" title="Jalaludin Abdur Rahim">Jalaludin Abdur Rahim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sobho_Gianchandani" title="Sobho Gianchandani">Gianchandani</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malik_Meraj_Khalid" title="Malik Meraj Khalid">Malik Khalid</a> incorporated <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a> into Pakistan's philosophical thinking.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_for_Research_in_Values_and_Philosophy_628-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_for_Research_in_Values_and_Philosophy-628">[624]</a></sup> Influential work by <a href="/wiki/Manzoor_Ahmad" title="Manzoor Ahmad">Manzoor Ahmad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jon_Elia" class="mw-redirect" title="Jon Elia">Jon Elia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasan_Askari_Rizvi" title="Hasan Askari Rizvi">Hasan Askari Rizvi</a>, and Abdul Khaliq brought mainstream <a href="/wiki/Social_philosophy" title="Social philosophy">social</a>, <a href="/wiki/Political_thought" class="mw-redirect" title="Political thought">political</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Analytical_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Analytical philosophy">analytical philosophy</a> to the fore in academia.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_for_Research_in_Values_and_Philosophy_628-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_for_Research_in_Values_and_Philosophy-628">[624]</a></sup> Works by <a href="/wiki/Noam_Chomsky" title="Noam Chomsky">Noam Chomsky</a> have influenced philosophical ideas in various fields of social and political philosophy.<sup id="cite_ref-Dawn_news_election_cells_629-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dawn_news_election_cells-629">[625]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PTV_archives_630-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PTV_archives-630">[626]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_architecture" title="Pakistani architecture">Pakistani architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_and_Buddhist_architectural_heritage_of_Pakistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu and Buddhist architectural heritage of Pakistan">Hindu and Buddhist architectural heritage of Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg/220px-Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg/330px-Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg/440px-Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="618"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Minar_e_Pakistan_night_image.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Minar-e-Pakistan" title="Minar-e-Pakistan">Minar-e-Pakistan</a> is a national monument marking Pakistan's independence movement.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Four periods are recognised in Pakistani architecture: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan#Early_history" title="History of Pakistan">pre-Islamic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan#Muslim_period" title="History of Pakistan">Islamic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan#Colonial_era" title="History of Pakistan">colonial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan#Independence" title="History of Pakistan">post-colonial</a>. With the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus civilization">Indus civilization</a> around the middle of the 3rd millennium BCE,<sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631">[627]</a></sup> an advanced urban culture developed for the first time in the region, with large buildings, some of which survive to this day.<sup id="cite_ref-632" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-632">[628]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo Daro</a>, Harappa, and <a href="/wiki/Kot_Diji" title="Kot Diji">Kot Diji</a> are among the pre-Islamic settlements that are now tourist attractions.<sup id="cite_ref-mountains_193-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mountains-193">[189]</a></sup> The rise of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and the influence of <a href="/wiki/Indian_campaign_of_Alexander_the_Great" title="Indian campaign of Alexander the Great">Greek</a> civilisation led to the development of a <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhism" title="Greco-Buddhism">Greco-Buddhist</a> style,<sup id="cite_ref-633" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-633">[629]</a></sup> starting from the 1st century CE. The high point of this era was the <a href="/wiki/Gandhara#Art" title="Gandhara">Gandhara style</a>. An example of Buddhist architecture is the ruins of the Buddhist monastery <a href="/wiki/Takht_Bhai" class="mw-redirect" title="Takht Bhai">Takht-i-Bahi</a> in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa.<sup id="cite_ref-634" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-634">[630]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The arrival of Islam in what is today Pakistan meant the sudden end of Buddhist architecture in the area and a smooth transition to the predominantly pictureless <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">Islamic architecture</a>. The most important <a href="/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture" title="Indo-Islamic architecture">Indo-Islamic</a>-style building still standing is the <a href="/wiki/Rukn-e-Alam" title="Rukn-e-Alam">tomb of the Shah Rukn-i-Alam</a> in Multan. During the Mughal era, design elements of Persian-Islamic architecture were fused with and often produced playful forms of Hindustani art. Lahore, as the occasional residence of Mughal rulers, contains many important buildings from the empire. Most prominent among them are the <a href="/wiki/Badshahi_Mosque" title="Badshahi Mosque">Badshahi Mosque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lahore_Fort" title="Lahore Fort">fortress of Lahore</a> with the famous <a href="/wiki/Alamgiri_Gate" class="mw-redirect" title="Alamgiri Gate">Alamgiri Gate</a>, the colourful, <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Mughal</a>-style <a href="/wiki/Wazir_Khan_Mosque" title="Wazir Khan Mosque">Wazir Khan Mosque</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-635" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-635">[631]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Shalimar_Gardens_(Lahore)" class="mw-redirect" title="Shalimar Gardens (Lahore)">Shalimar Gardens</a> in Lahore, and the <a href="/wiki/Shahjahan_Mosque" class="mw-redirect" title="Shahjahan Mosque">Shahjahan Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Thatta" title="Thatta">Thatta</a>. In the British colonial period, predominantly functional buildings of the Indo-European representative style developed from a mixture of European and Indian-Islamic components. Post-colonial national identity is expressed in modern structures such as the <a href="/wiki/Faisal_Mosque" title="Faisal Mosque">Faisal Mosque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Minar-e-Pakistan" title="Minar-e-Pakistan">Minar-e-Pakistan</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mazar-e-Quaid" title="Mazar-e-Quaid">Mazar-e-Quaid</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-=Concept_Media_Pte_Ltd_636-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-=Concept_Media_Pte_Ltd-636">[632]</a></sup> Several examples of architectural infrastructure demonstrating the influence of <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Architecture of the United Kingdom">British design</a> can be found in <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peshawar" title="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-=Concept_Media_Pte_Ltd_636-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-=Concept_Media_Pte_Ltd-636">[632]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_and_drink">Food and drink</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_cuisine" title="Pakistani cuisine">Pakistani cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_food">Traditional food</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG/220px-Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG/330px-Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG/440px-Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Port_Grand_Karachi.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Located on the bank of <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_Grand" title="Port Grand">Port Grand</a> is one of the largest food streets of Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-637" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-637">[633]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Pakistani cuisine is similar to that of other regions of South Asia, with some of it being originated from the royal kitchens of 16th-century Mughal emperors.<sup id="cite_ref-Goodwin2002_638-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goodwin2002-638">[634]</a></sup> Most of those dishes have their roots in <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_cuisine" title="Central Asian cuisine">Central Asian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">Middle Eastern cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LeeNadeau2011_639-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LeeNadeau2011-639">[635]</a></sup> Unlike Middle Eastern cuisine, Pakistani cooking uses large quantities of spices, herbs, and seasoning. Garlic, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, red <a href="/wiki/Chili_powder" title="Chili powder">chili</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Garam_masala" title="Garam masala">garam masala</a> are used in most dishes, and home cooking regularly includes curry, <a href="/wiki/Pita_bread" class="mw-redirect" title="Pita bread"><i>roti</i></a>, a thin flatbread made from wheat, is a staple food, usually served with curry, meat, vegetables, and lentils. Rice is also common; it is served plain, fried with spices, and in sweet dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-yasmeen_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yasmeen-189">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-640" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-640">[636]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641">[637]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Lassi" title="Lassi">Lassi</a> is a traditional drink in the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a>. <a href="/wiki/Pakistani_tea_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Pakistani tea culture">Black tea with milk and sugar</a> is popular throughout Pakistan and is consumed daily by most of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-taxila_51-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taxila-51">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-642" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-642">[638]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sohan_halwa" title="Sohan halwa">Sohan halwa</a> is a popular sweet dish from the southern region of Punjab province and is enjoyed all over Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-643" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-643">[639]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Pakistan" title="Sport in Pakistan">Sport in Pakistan</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Most sports played in Pakistan originated and were substantially developed by athletes and sports fans from the United Kingdom who introduced them during the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>. <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">Field hockey</a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> of Pakistan; it has won three gold medals in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a> held in <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey_at_the_1960_Summer_Olympics" title="Field hockey at the 1960 Summer Olympics">1960</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey_at_the_1968_Summer_Olympics" title="Field hockey at the 1968 Summer Olympics">1968</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey_at_the_1984_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Field hockey at the 1984 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament">1984</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mallon_644-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mallon-644">[640]</a></sup> Pakistan has also won the <a href="/wiki/Hockey_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Hockey World Cup">Hockey World Cup</a> a record four times, held in <a href="/wiki/1971_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="1971 Men's Hockey World Cup">1971</a>, <a href="/wiki/1978_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="1978 Men's Hockey World Cup">1978</a>, <a href="/wiki/1982_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="1982 Men's Hockey World Cup">1982</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1994_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="1994 Men's Hockey World Cup">1994</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Suburaj:_Hockey_World_Champion_645-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Suburaj:_Hockey_World_Champion-645">[641]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg/220px-Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="78" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg/330px-Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg/440px-Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6774" data-file-height="2412"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Gaddafi_stadium_lahore.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Gaddafi_Stadium" title="Gaddafi Stadium">Gaddafi Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lahore" title="Lahore">Lahore</a> is the 3rd largest cricket stadium in Pakistan with a <a href="/wiki/Seating_capacity" title="Seating capacity">seating capacity</a> of 27,000 spectators.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a>, however, is the most popular game across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-646" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-646">[642]</a></sup> The country has had an array of success in the sport over the years, and has the distinct achievement of having won each of the major <a href="/wiki/International_Cricket_Council" title="International Cricket Council">ICC</a> international cricket tournaments: <a href="/wiki/ICC_Cricket_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="ICC Cricket World Cup">ICC Cricket World Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/ICC_World_Twenty20" class="mw-redirect" title="ICC World Twenty20">ICC World Twenty20</a>, and <a href="/wiki/ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="ICC Champions Trophy">ICC Champions Trophy</a>; as well as the <a href="/wiki/ICC_Test_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="ICC Test Championship">ICC Test Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-647" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-647">[643]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-648" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-648">[644]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team" title="Pakistan national cricket team">cricket team</a> (known as <a href="/wiki/Shaheen_falcon" title="Shaheen falcon"><i>Shaheen</i></a>) won the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> held in <a href="/wiki/1992_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1992 Cricket World Cup">1992</a>; it was runner-up once, in <a href="/wiki/1999_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1999 Cricket World Cup">1999</a>. Pakistan was runner-up in the inaugural <a href="/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2007 ICC World Twenty20">World Twenty20</a> (2007) in South Africa and won the <a href="/wiki/2009_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2009 ICC World Twenty20">World Twenty20</a> in England in 2009. In March 2009, militants <a href="/wiki/2009_attack_on_the_Sri_Lanka_national_cricket_team" title="2009 attack on the Sri Lanka national cricket team">attacked</a> the touring <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cricket_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Sri Lankan cricket team">Sri Lankan cricket team</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-649" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-649">[645]</a></sup> after which no international cricket was played in Pakistan until May 2015, when the <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwean_cricket_team_in_Pakistan_in_2015" title="Zimbabwean cricket team in Pakistan in 2015">Zimbabwean team agreed to a tour</a>. Pakistan also won the <a href="/wiki/2017_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2017 ICC Champions Trophy">2017 ICC Champions Trophy</a> by defeating arch-rivals <a href="/wiki/India_national_cricket_team" title="India national cricket team">India</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2017_ICC_Champions_Trophy_Final" title="2017 ICC Champions Trophy Final">final</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Super_League" title="Pakistan Super League">Pakistan Super League</a> is one of the largest cricket leagues of the world with a brand value of about <span class="nowrap"><span style="white-space: nowrap">â¨</span>32.26 billion</span> (US$200&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-650" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-650">[646]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Association_Football" class="mw-redirect" title="Association Football">Association Football</a> is the second most played sports in Pakistan and it is organised and regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Football_Federation" title="Pakistan Football Federation">Pakistan Football Federation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-651" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-651">[647]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Pakistan" title="Football in Pakistan">Football in Pakistan</a> is as old as the country itself. Shortly after the creation of Pakistan in 1947, the Pakistan Football Federation (PFF) was created, and Muhammad Ali Jinnah became its first Patron-in-Chief.<sup id="cite_ref-652" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-652">[648]</a></sup> The highest football division in Pakistan is the <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_Premier_League" title="Pakistan Premier League">Pakistan Premier League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-653" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-653">[649]</a></sup> Pakistan is known as one of the best manufacturer of the official <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> ball.<sup id="cite_ref-654" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-654">[650]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-655" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-655">[651]</a></sup> The best football players to play for Pakistan are <a href="/wiki/Kaleemullah" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaleemullah">Kaleemullah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zesh_Rehman" title="Zesh Rehman">Zesh Rehman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Essa" title="Muhammad Essa">Muhammad Essa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haroon_Yousaf" title="Haroon Yousaf">Haroon Yousaf</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Adil" title="Muhammad Adil">Muhammad Adil</a>. </p>
      <p>Pakistan has hosted or co-hosted several international sporting events: the <a href="/wiki/1989_South_Asian_Games" title="1989 South Asian Games">1989</a> and <a href="/wiki/2004_South_Asian_Games" title="2004 South Asian Games">2004 South Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1984_Men%27s_World_Open_Squash_Championship" title="1984 Men's World Open Squash Championship">1984</a>, <a href="/wiki/1993_Men%27s_World_Open_Squash_Championship" title="1993 Men's World Open Squash Championship">1993</a>, <a href="/wiki/1996_Men%27s_World_Open_Squash_Championship" title="1996 Men's World Open Squash Championship">1996</a> and <a href="/wiki/2003_Men%27s_World_Open_Squash_Championship" title="2003 Men's World Open Squash Championship">2003 World Squash Championships</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1987 Cricket World Cup">1987</a> and <a href="/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1996 Cricket World Cup">1996 Cricket World Cup</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/1990_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="1990 Men's Hockey World Cup">1990 Hockey World Cup</a>. </p>
      <p>Pakistan is set to host the <a href="/wiki/2021_South_Asian_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="2021 South Asian Games">2021 South Asian Games</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>

       </ul>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Pakistan" title="Outline of Pakistan">Outline of Pakistan</a>
        <div style="clear:both;"></div></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Includes data for Pakistani territories of Kashmir; <a href="/wiki/Azad_Kashmir" title="Azad Kashmir">Azad Kashmir</a> (13,297&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 5,134&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and <a href="/wiki/Gilgit%E2%80%93Baltistan" class="mw-redirect" title="GilgitâBaltistan">GilgitâBaltistan</a> (72,520&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> or 28,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Excluding these territories would produce an area figure of 796,095&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (307,374&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_Pakistan" title="Date and time notation in Pakistan">Date and time notation in Pakistan</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Urdu_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Urdu language">Urdu</a>: <span lang="ur" dir="rtl"><span class="Nastaliq" dir="rtl" title="Nastaliq" style="font-family: 'Jameel Noori Nastaleeq', 'Urdu Typesetting', 'Noto Nastaliq Urdu', 'Noto Nastaliq Urdu Draft', 'Hussaini Nastaleeq', 'AlQalam Taj Nastaleeq', IranNastaliq, 'Awami Nastaliq', 'Awami Nastaliq Beta3', 'Awami Nastaliq Beta2', 'Awami Nastaliq Beta1', 'Nafees Nastaleeq', 'Nafees Nastaleeq v1.01', 'Pak Nastaleeq', 'PDMS_Jauhar', 'Alvi Lahori Nastaleeq'; font-size: 110%; font-style: normal;">Ù¾Ø§Ú©ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù</span></span>â <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu" title="Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu">[ËpaËkÉªstaËn]</a></span>. Pronounced variably in English as <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px          <li id="cite_note-wb-gini-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-wb-gini_12-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.GINI?locations=PK">"GINI index (World Bank estimate)"</a>. <i>data.worldbank.org</i>. <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-UNHDR-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UNHDR_13-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr_2020_overview_english.pdf">"Human Development Report 2020"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">United Nations Development Programme</a>. 2 December 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLoureiro2005" class="citation news cs1">Loureiro, Miguel (28 July 2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120110085150/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_28-7-2005_pg3_5">"Drivingâthe good, the bad and the ugly"</a>. <i>Daily Times</i>.
