         <li id="cite_note-coningham-young-1-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-coningham-young-1_18-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFConinghamYoung2015" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Robin_Coningham" title="Robin Coningham">Coningham, Robin</a>; Young, Ruth (2015), <i>The Archaeology of South Asia: From the Indus to Asoka, c. 6500 BCE â 200 CE</i>, <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Archaeology+of+South+Asia%3A+From+the+Indus+to+Asoka%2C+c.+6500+BCE+%E2%80%93+200+CE&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.aulast=Coningham&amp;rft.aufirst=Robin&amp;rft.au=Young%2C+Ruth&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: ""Mehrgarh remains one of the key sites in South Asia because it has provided the earliest known undisputed evidence for farming and pastoral communities in the region, and its plant and animal material provide clear evidence for the ongoing manipulation, and domestication, of certain species. Perhaps most importantly in a South Asian context, the role played by zebu makes this a distinctive, localised development, with a character completely different to other parts of the world. Finally, the longevity of the site, and its articulation with the neighbouring site of Nausharo (c. 2800â2000&nbsp;BCE), provides a very clear continuity from South Asia's first farming villages to the emergence of its first cities (Jarrige, 1984)."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Wright2009-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Wright2009_19-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWright2009" class="citation cs2">Wright, Rita P. (2009), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=MG2ztAEACAAJ"><i>The Ancient Indus: Urbanism, Economy, and Society</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, pp.&nbsp;1â2, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-57219-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-57219-4"><bdi>978-0-521-57219-4</bdi></a>, <q>The Indus civilisation is one of three in the 'Ancient East' that, along with Mesopotamia and Pharaonic Egypt, was a cradle of early civilisation in the Old World (Childe, 1950). Mesopotamia and Egypt were longer lived, but coexisted with Indus civilisation during its florescence between 2600 and 1900&nbsp;B.C. Of the three, the Indus was the most expansive, extending from today's northeast Afghanistan to Pakistan and India.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Ancient+Indus%3A+Urbanism%2C+Economy%2C+and+Society&amp;rft.pages=1-2&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-57219-4&amp;rft.aulast=Wright&amp;rft.aufirst=Rita+P.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DMG2ztAEACAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-AllchinAllchin1982-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-AllchinAllchin1982_20-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAllchinAllchin1982" class="citation cs2">Allchin, Bridget; Allchin, Raymond (1982), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=r4s-YsP6vcIC&amp;pg=PA131"><i>The Rise of Civilization in India and Pakistan</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, p.&nbsp;131, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-28550-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-28550-6"><bdi>978-0-521-28550-6</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Rise+of+Civilization+in+India+and+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=131&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-28550-6&amp;rft.aulast=Allchin&amp;rft.aufirst=Bridget&amp;rft.au=Allchin%2C+Raymond&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dr4s-YsP6vcIC%26pg%3DPA131&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "During the second half of the fourth and early part of the third millennium B.C., a new development begins to become apparent in the greater Indus system, which we can now see to be a formative stage underlying the Mature Indus of the middle and late third millennium. This development seems to have involved the whole Indus system, and to a lesser extent the Indo-Iranian borderlands to its west, but largely left untouched the subcontinent east of the Indus system. (page 81)"</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:Gupta2-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:Gupta2_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWynbrandt2009" class="citation book cs1">Wynbrandt, James (2009). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/briefhistoryofpa0000wynb"><i>A Brief History of Pakistan</i></a></span>.          <li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSpuler1969" class="citation book cs1">Spuler, Bertold (1969). <i>The Muslim World: a Historical Survey</i>. Leiden: E.J. Brill. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/90-04-02104-3" title="Special:BookSources/90-04-02104-3"><bdi>90-04-02104-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Muslim+World%3A+a+Historical+Survey&amp;rft.place=Leiden&amp;rft.pub=E.J.+Brill&amp;rft.date=1969&amp;rft.isbn=90-04-02104-3&amp;rft.aulast=Spuler&amp;rft.aufirst=Bertold&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Copland2001-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Copland2001_23-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCopland2001" class="citation cs2">Copland, Ian (2001), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Dw1uAAAAMAAJ"><i>India, 1885-1947: The Unmaking of an Empire</i></a>, Seminar Studies in History, Longman, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-38173-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-582-38173-5"><bdi>978-0-582-38173-5</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India%2C+1885-1947%3A+The+Unmaking+of+an+Empire&amp;rft.series=Seminar+Studies+in+History&amp;rft.pub=Longman&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-582-38173-5&amp;rft.aulast=Copland&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DDw1uAAAAMAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "However, the real turning point for the new Muslim League came with the general election of December 1945 and January 1946. Despite facing a rejuvenated Congress, the League won four-fifths of all the Muslim-reserved seats ... The result left no one, not least the British, in doubt about where the locus of power within the Muslim community now lay (p. 71) ... In most respects, therefore, the League's success in the elections of 1945â46 can be interpreted as a clear Muslim mandate for Pakistan. (p 72)"</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2006-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2006_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2006" class="citation cs2">Metcalf, Barbara D.; Metcalf, Thomas R. (2006), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=iuESgYNYPl0C"><i>A Concise History of Modern India</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-139-45887-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-139-45887-0"><bdi>978-1-139-45887-0</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+History+of+Modern+India&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-139-45887-0&amp;rft.aulast=Metcalf&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara+D.&amp;rft.au=Metcalf%2C+Thomas+R.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DiuESgYNYPl0C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span> Quote: "The loss of life was immense, with estimates ranging from several hundred thousand up to a million. But, even for those who survived, fear generated a widespread perception that one could be safe only among members of one's own community; and this in turn helped consolidate loyalties towards the state, whether India or Pakistan, in which one might find a secure haven. This was especially important for Pakistan, where the succour it offered to Muslims gave that state for the first time a visible territorial reality. Fear too drove forward a mass migration unparalleled in the history of South Asia. ... Overall, partition uprooted some 12.5 million of undivided India's people."</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Talbot2016-1-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Talbot2016-1_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-30">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://tribune.com.pk/story/973649/pakistan-has-18th-largest-middle-class-in-the-world-report">"Pakistan has 18th largest 'middle class' in the world: report"</a>. <i>The Express Tribune</i>. 16 October 2015.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Express+Tribune&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan+has+18th+largest+%27middle+class%27+in+the+world%3A+report&amp;rft.date=2015-10-16&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ftribune.com.pk%2Fstory%2F973649%2Fpakistan-has-18th-largest-middle-class-in-the-world-report&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://data.worldbank.org/data-catalog/GDP-ranking-table">"GDP ranking | Data"</a>. <i>data.worldbank.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. V2-0030) Ø³ØªØ§Ù (Û²) Suffix meaning 'a place abounding in'. Ex. Ú¯ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù a flower or rose-garden. Syn. Ø²Ø§Ø± See Ú¯Ø§Ø²Ø§Ø± Note.          <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright2010-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWright2010_42-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWright2010">Wright 2010</a>:Quote: "The Indus civilization is one of three in the 'Ancient East' that, along with <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Pharonic Egypt</a>, was a cradle of early civilization in the Old World (Childe 1950). Mesopotamia and Egypt were longer lived, but coexisted with Indus civilization during its florescence between 2600 and 1900 B.C. Of the three, the Indus was the most expansive, extending from today's northeast Afghanistan to Pakistan and India."<span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> sfn error: no target: CITEREFWright2010 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDaniel_Lak2008" class="citation book cs1">Daniel Lak (4 March 2008). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/indiaexpressfutu0000lakd"><i>India express: the future of a new superpower</i></a></span>.          <li id="cite_note-Brookings_Institution_Press-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Brookings_Institution_Press_86-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCohen2004" class="citation book cs1">Cohen, Stephen Philip (2004). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/ideaofpakistan00cohe"><i>The idea of Pakistan</i></a></span> (1st pbk.&nbsp;ed.).          <li id="cite_note-iqbal1-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-iqbal1_87-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00islamlinks/txt_iqbal_1930.html">"Sir Muhammad Iqbal's 1930 Presidential Address"</a>. <i>Speeches, Writings, and Statements of Iqbal</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Politact-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Politact_88-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEditorial_work,_no_author.2009" class="citation web cs1">Editorial work, no author. (5 January 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150203020939/https://www.politact.com/global-security-studies/understanding-jinnahs-position-on-world-war-i-and-ii-lessons-to-be-learned.html">"Understanding Jinnah's Position on World War I and II Lessons to be learned"</a>. United Kingdom: Politact. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.politact.com/global-security-studies/understanding-jinnahs-position-on-world-war-i-and-ii-lessons-to-be-learned.html">the original</a> on 3 February 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 February</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Understanding+Jinnah%27s+Position+on+World+War+I+and+II+Lessons+to+be+learned&amp;rft.place=United+Kingdom&amp;rft.pub=Politact&amp;rft.date=2009-01-05&amp;rft.au=Editorial+work%2C+no+author.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.politact.com%2Fglobal-security-studies%2Funderstanding-jinnahs-position-on-world-war-i-and-ii-lessons-to-be-learned.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:2-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:2_89-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:2_89-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMohiuddin2007" class="citation book cs1">Mohiuddin, Yasmin Niaz (2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=OTMy0B9OZjAC&amp;pg=PA68"><i>Pakistan: A Global Studies Handbook</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p.&nbsp;70. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-801-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-801-9"><bdi>978-1-85109-801-9</bdi></a>. <q>In the elections of 1946, the Muslim League won 90 percent of the legislative seats reserved for Muslims. It was the power of the big zamindars in Punjab and Sindh behind the Muslim League candidates that led to this massive landslide victory (Alavi 2002, 14). Even Congress, which had always denied the League's claim to be the only true representative of Indian Muslims had to concede the truth of that claim. The 1946 election was, in effect, a plebiscite among Muslims on Pakistan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+A+Global+Studies+Handbook&amp;rft.pages=70&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85109-801-9&amp;rft.aulast=Mohiuddin&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin+Niaz&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DOTMy0B9OZjAC%26pg%3DPA68&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMohiuddin2007" class="citation book cs1">Mohiuddin, Yasmin Niaz (2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=OTMy0B9OZjAC&amp;pg=PA68"><i>Pakistan: A Global Studies Handbook</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p.&nbsp;71. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-801-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85109-801-9"><bdi>978-1-85109-801-9</bdi></a>. <q>Despite the League's victory in the elections, the British did not want the partition of British India. As a last attempt to avoid it, Britain put forward the Cabinet Mission Plan, according to which India would become a federation of three large, self-governing provinces and the central government would be limited to power over foreign policy and defense, implying a weak center.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+A+Global+Studies+Handbook&amp;rft.pages=71&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85109-801-9&amp;rft.aulast=Mohiuddin&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin+Niaz&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DOTMy0B9OZjAC%26pg%3DPA68&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Academia_Edu-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Academia_Edu_91-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAkram" class="citation journal cs1">Akram, Wasim. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/2146058">"Jinnah and cabinet Mission Plan"</a>. Academia Edu<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-jinnah-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-jinnah_92-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-jinnah_92-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFStanley_Wolpert2002" class="citation book cs1">Stanley Wolpert (2002). <i>Jinnah of Pakistan</i>.          <li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dawn.com/news/1169309">"Murder, rape and shattered families: 1947 Partition Archive effort underway"</a>. <i>Dawn</i>. 13 March 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

The legacy of Partition (never without a capital P) remains strong today&nbsp;...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=South+Asia%27s+Cold+War%3A+Nuclear+Weapons+and+Conflict+in+Comparative+Perspective&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-16531-5&amp;rft.aulast=Basrur&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajesh+M.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DyqAGKpOe9xMC%26pg%3DPA36&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFIsaacs1975" class="citation book cs1">Isaacs, Harold Robert (1975). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0Kne87aU7D0C&amp;q=2+000+000+killed+partition&amp;pg=PA3"><i>Idols of the Tribe: Group Identity and Political Change</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-D'Costa_2011_53-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-D'Costa_2011_53_96-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFD'Costa2011" class="citation book cs1">D'Costa, Bina (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ivzKjY5LncIC&amp;pg=PA53"><i>Nationbuilding, Gender and War Crimes in South Asia</i></a>. Today, however, it is widely accepted that nearly a million people died during Partition (Butalia, 1997).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nationbuilding%2C+Gender+and+War+Crimes+in+South+Asia&amp;rft.pages=53&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-56566-0&amp;rft.aulast=D%27Costa&amp;rft.aufirst=Bina&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DivzKjY5LncIC%26pg%3DPA53&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Butalia_2000-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Butalia_2000_97-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-98">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSikand2004" class="citation book cs1">Sikand, Yoginder (2004). <i>Muslims in India Since 1947: Islamic Perspectives on Inter-Faith Relations</i>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;5. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-37825-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-37825-8"><bdi>978-1-134-37825-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Muslims+in+India+Since+1947%3A+Islamic+Perspectives+on+Inter-Faith+Relations&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-37825-8&amp;rft.aulast=Sikand&amp;rft.aufirst=Yoginder&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBrass2003" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Paul_Brass" title="Paul Brass">Brass, Paul R.</a> (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://faculty.washington.edu/brass/Partition.pdf">"The partition of India and retributive genocide in the Punjab, 1946â47: means, methods, and purposes"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_of_Genocide_Research" title="Journal of Genocide Research">Journal of Genocide Research</a></i>. Carfax Publishing: Taylor and Francis Group. pp.&nbsp;81â82 (5(1), 71â101)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 August</span> 2014</span>. <q>In the event, largely but not exclusively as a consequence of their efforts, the entire Muslim population of the eastern Punjab districts migrated to West Punjab and the entire Sikh and Hindu populations moved to East Punjab in the midst of widespread intimidation, terror, violence, abduction, rape, and murder.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Genocide+Research&amp;rft.atitle=The+partition+of+India+and+retributive+genocide+in+the+Punjab%2C+1946%E2%80%9347%3A+means%2C+methods%2C+and+purposes&amp;rft.pages=81-82+%285%281%29%2C+71-101%29&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.aulast=Brass&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul+R.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ffaculty.washington.edu%2Fbrass%2FPartition.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/291225/20th-century-international-relations/32936/South-Asia#ref304573">"20th-century international relations (politics)&nbsp;:: South Asia"</a>. <i>EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-101">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDaiya2011" class="citation book cs1">Daiya, Kavita (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=P7a-FuiMcTYC&amp;pg=PA75"><i>Violent Belongings: Partition, Gender, and National Culture in Postcolonial India</i></a>. Temple University Press. p.&nbsp;75. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59213-744-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59213-744-2"><bdi>978-1-59213-744-2</bdi></a>. <q>The official estimate of the number of abducted women during Partition was placed at 33,000 non-Muslim (Hindu or Sikh predominantly) women in Pakistan, and 50,000 Muslim women in India.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Violent+Belongings%3A+Partition%2C+Gender%2C+and+National+Culture+in+Postcolonial+India&amp;rft.pages=75&amp;rft.pub=Temple+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59213-744-2&amp;rft.aulast=Daiya&amp;rft.aufirst=Kavita&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DP7a-FuiMcTYC%26pg%3DPA75&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-102">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSinghIyerGairola2016" class="citation book cs1">Singh, Amritjit; Iyer, Nalini; Gairola, Rahul K. (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tmA0DAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA14"><i>Revisiting India's Partition: New Essays on Memory, Culture, and Politics</i></a>. Lexington Books. p.&nbsp;14. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4985-3105-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4985-3105-4"><bdi>978-1-4985-3105-4</bdi></a>. <q>The horrific statistics that surround women refugees-between 75,000â100,000 Hindu, Muslim and Sikh women who were abducted by men of the other communities, subjected to multiple rapes, mutilations, and, for some, forced marriages and conversions-is matched by the treatment of the abducted women in the hands of the nation-state. In the Constituent Assembly in 1949 it was recorded that of the 50,000 Muslim women abducted in India, 8,000 of then were recovered, and of the 33,000 Hindu and Sikh women abducted, 12,000 were recovered.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Revisiting+India%27s+Partition%3A+New+Essays+on+Memory%2C+Culture%2C+and+Politics&amp;rft.pages=14&amp;rft.pub=Lexington+Books&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4985-3105-4&amp;rft.aulast=Singh&amp;rft.aufirst=Amritjit&amp;rft.au=Iyer%2C+Nalini&amp;rft.au=Gairola%2C+Rahul+K.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DtmA0DAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA14&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-103">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbraham2002" class="citation book cs1">Abraham, Taisha (2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=cm4PBNdaFjYC&amp;pg=PA131"><i>Women and the Politics of Violence</i></a>. Har-Anand Publications. p.&nbsp;131. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-241-0847-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-241-0847-5"><bdi>978-81-241-0847-5</bdi></a>. <q>In addition thousands of women on both sides of the newly formed borders (estimated range from 29,000 to 50,000 Muslim women and 15,000 to 35,000 Hindu and Sikh women) were abducted, raped, forced to convert, forced into marriage, forced back into what the two States defined as 'their proper homes', torn apart from their families once during partition by those who abducted them, and again, after partition, by the State which tried to 'recover' and 'rehabilitate' them.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Women+and+the+Politics+of+Violence&amp;rft.pages=131&amp;rft.pub=Har-Anand+Publications&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-241-0847-5&amp;rft.aulast=Abraham&amp;rft.aufirst=Taisha&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dcm4PBNdaFjYC%26pg%3DPA131&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=m-EYXNnvMugC&amp;pg=PA125&amp;dq=muslim,+hindu+sikh+women+recovered&amp;hl=en#v=onepage&amp;q=12000&amp;f=false">Perspectives on Modern South Asia: A Reader in Culture, History, and&nbsp;... â Kamala Visweswara</a>. nGoogle Books.in (16 May 2011).</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ECM-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ECM_105-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMcGrath1996" class="citation book cs1">McGrath, Allen (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=a0FuAAAAMAAJ"><i>The Destruction of Pakistan's Democracy</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAhmed1997" class="citation book cs1">Ahmed, Akbar S.          <li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWolpert2009" class="citation book cs1">Wolpert, Stanley (2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=uJHTif-WA6oC&amp;pg=PA163"><i>Shameful Flight: The Last Years of the British Empire in India</i></a>. Oxford University Press. p.&nbsp;163. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-974504-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-974504-3"><bdi>978-0-19-974504-3</bdi></a>. <q>Mountbatten tried to convince Jinnah of the value of accepting him, Mountbatten, as Pakistan's first governor-general, but Jinnah refused to be moved from his determination to take that job himself.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Shameful+Flight%3A+The+Last+Years+of+the+British+Empire+in+India&amp;rft.pages=163&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-974504-3&amp;rft.aulast=Wolpert&amp;rft.aufirst=Stanley&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DuJHTif-WA6oC%26pg%3DPA163&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-116">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAhmed2005" class="citation book cs1">Ahmed, Akbar (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RqyniTHXFxUC&amp;pg=PT209"><i>Jinnah, Pakistan and Islamic Identity: The Search for Saladin</i></a>. Routledge. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-75022-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-75022-1"><bdi>978-1-134-75022-1</bdi></a>. <q>When Mountbatten was asked by Collins and Lapierre if he would have sabotaged Pakistan if he had known that Jinnah was dying of tuberculosis, his answer was instructive. There was no doubt in his mind about the legality or morality of his position on Pakistan. 'Most probably,' he said (1982:39).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Jinnah%2C+Pakistan+and+Islamic+Identity%3A+The+Search+for+Saladin&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-75022-1&amp;rft.aulast=Ahmed&amp;rft.aufirst=Akbar&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DRqyniTHXFxUC%26pg%3DPT209&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHussain" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Hussain, Rizwan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0616">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World</i>. <q>MawlÄnÄ ShabbÄ«r Ahmad UsmÄnÄ«, a respected DeobandÄ« Ê¿Älim (scholar) who was appointed to the prestigious position of Shaykh al-IslÄm of Pakistan in 1949, was the first to demand that Pakistan become an Islamic state. But MawdÅ«dÄ« and his JamÄÊ¿at-i IslÄmÄ« played the central part in the demand for an Islamic constitution. MawdÅ«dÄ« demanded that the Constituent Assembly make an unequivocal declaration affirming the "supreme sovereignty of God" and the supremacy of the sharÄ«Ê¿ah as the basic law of Pakistan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Islamic+World&amp;rft.aulast=Hussain&amp;rft.aufirst=Rizwan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordislamicstudies.com%2Farticle%2Fopr%2Ft236%2Fe0616&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:13-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:13_118-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:13_118-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHussain" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Hussain, Rizwan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0616">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World</i>. <q>The first important result of the combined efforts of the JamÄÊ¿at-i IslÄmÄ« and the Ê¿ulamÄÊ¿ was the passage of the Objectives Resolution in March 1949, whose formulation reflected compromise between traditionalists and modernists. The resolution embodied "the main principles on which the constitution of Pakistan is to be based". It declared that "sovereignty over the entire universe belongs to God Almighty alone and the authority which He has delegated to the State of Pakistan through its people for being exercised within the limits prescribed by Him is a sacred trust", that "the principles of democracy, freedom, equality, tolerance and social justice, as enunciated by Islam shall be fully observed", and that "the Muslims shall be enabled to order their lives in the individual and collective spheres in accord with the teaching and requirements of Islam as set out in the Holy QurÊ¿an and Sunna". The Objectives Resolution has been reproduced as a preamble to the constitutions of 1956, 1962, and 1973.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Islamic+World&amp;rft.aulast=Hussain&amp;rft.aufirst=Rizwan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordislamicstudies.com%2Farticle%2Fopr%2Ft236%2Fe0616&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Wynbrandt2009-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Wynbrandt2009_119-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Strategic_Studies-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Strategic_Studies_131-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120314025504/http://www.iiss.org/whats-new/iiss-in-the-press/press-coverage-2007/may-2007/bhutto-was-father-of-pakistani-bomb/?locale=en">"Bhutto was father of Pakistan's Atom Bomb Programme"</a>. <i>International Institute for Strategic Studies</i>.          <li id="cite_note-:03-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:03_154-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHussain" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Hussain, Rizwan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0616">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World</i>. <q>Pakistan is unique among Muslim countries in its relationship with Islam: it is the only country to have been established in the name of Islam</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Islamic+World&amp;rft.aulast=Hussain&amp;rft.aufirst=Rizwan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordislamicstudies.com%2Farticle%2Fopr%2Ft236%2Fe0616&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:113-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:113_155-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTalbot1984" class="citation web cs1">Talbot, Ian (2 February 1984). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.historytoday.com/ian-talbot/jinnah-and-making-pakistan">"Jinnah and the Making of Pakistan"</a>. <i>History Today</i>. <q>As British rule there drew to an end, many Muslims demanded, in the name of Islam, the creation of a separate Pakistan state.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=History+Today&amp;rft.atitle=Jinnah+and+the+Making+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.date=1984-02-02&amp;rft.aulast=Talbot&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.historytoday.com%2Fian-talbot%2Fjinnah-and-making-pakistan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-156">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA496"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;496. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>The idea of Pakistan may have had its share of ambiguities, but its dismissal as a vague emotive symbol hardly illuminates the reasons as to why it received such overwhelmingly popular support among Indian Muslims, especially those in the 'minority provinces' of British India such as U.P.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=496&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA496&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-157">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA497"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;497. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>As the book has demonstrated, local ML functionaries, (U.P.) ML leadership, Muslim modernists at Aligarh, the ulama and even Jinnah at times articulated their vision of Pakistan in terms of an Islamic state.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=497&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA497&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:4-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:4_158-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA489"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;489. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>But what is undeniable is the close association he developed with the ulama, for when he died a little over a year after Pakistan was born, Maulana Shabbir Ahmad Usmani, in his funeral oration, described Jinnah as the greatest Muslim after the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=489&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA489&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-159"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-159">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA489"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;489. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>Similarly, Usmani asked Pakistanis to remember the Qaid's ceaseless message of Unity, Faith and Discipline and work to fulfil his dream to create a solid bloc of all Muslim states from Karachi to Ankara, from Pakistan to Morocco. He [Jinnah] wanted to see the Muslims of the world united under the banner of Islam as an effective check against the aggressive designs of their enemies</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=489&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA489&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2010" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Hussain (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA16"><i>Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military</i></a>. Carnegie Endowment. p.&nbsp;16. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1"><bdi>978-0-87003-285-1</bdi></a>. <q>The first formal step toward transforming Pakistan into an Islamic ideological state was taken in March 1949 when the country's first prime minister, Liaquat Ali Khan, presented the Objectives Resolution in the constituent assembly.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+Between+Mosque+and+Military&amp;rft.pages=16&amp;rft.pub=Carnegie+Endowment&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87003-285-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Hussain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnYppZ_dEjdIC%26pg%3DPA16&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-161">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA491"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;491. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>Khaliq drew a sharp distinction between this Islamic state and a Muslim state. He claimed that as of now Pakistan was only a Muslim state in view of the majority of its population being Muslim, and indeed could never be an Islamic state by itself. It could certainly fulfill its promise and destiny by bringing together all the believers of Islam into one political unit and it is only then that an Islamic state would be achieved.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=491&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA491&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-162">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2010" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Hussain (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA18"><i>Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military</i></a>. Carnegie Endowment. p.&nbsp;18. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1"><bdi>978-0-87003-285-1</bdi></a>. <q>One of the earliest Western scholars of Pakistani politics, Keith Callard, observed that Pakistanis seemed to believe in the essential unity of purpose and outlook in the Muslim world: Pakistan was founded to advance the cause of Muslims. Other Muslims might have been expected to be sympathetic, even enthusiastic. But this assumed that other Muslim states would take the same view of the relation between religion and nationality.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+Between+Mosque+and+Military&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=Carnegie+Endowment&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87003-285-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Hussain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnYppZ_dEjdIC%26pg%3DPA18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-163"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-163">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2010" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Hussain (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA18"><i>Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military</i></a>. Carnegie Endowment. p.&nbsp;18. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1"><bdi>978-0-87003-285-1</bdi></a>. <q>Pakistan's pan-Islamic aspirations, however, were neither shared nor supported by the Muslim governments of the time. Nationalism in other parts of the Muslim world was based on ethnicity, language, or territory.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+Between+Mosque+and+Military&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=Carnegie+Endowment&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87003-285-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Hussain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnYppZ_dEjdIC%26pg%3DPA18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqqani2010" class="citation book cs1">Haqqqani, Hussain (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA19"><i>Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military</i></a>. Carnegie Endowment. p.&nbsp;19. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1"><bdi>978-0-87003-285-1</bdi></a>. <q>Although Muslim governments were initially unsympathetic to Pakistan's pan-Islamic aspirations, Islamists from the world over were drawn to Pakistan. Controversial figures such as the pro-Nazi former grand mufti of Palestine, Al-Haj Amin al-Husseini, and leaders of Islamist political movements like the Arab Muslim Brotherhood became frequent visitors to the country.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+Between+Mosque+and+Military&amp;rft.pages=19&amp;rft.pub=Carnegie+Endowment&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87003-285-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Hussain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnYppZ_dEjdIC%26pg%3DPA19&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Haqqani2010-165"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Haqqani2010_165-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHusain_Haqqani2010" class="citation book cs1">Husain Haqqani (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA19"><i>Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military</i></a>. Carnegie Endowment. pp.&nbsp;19â. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87003-285-1"><bdi>978-0-87003-285-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+Between+Mosque+and+Military&amp;rft.pages=19-&amp;rft.pub=Carnegie+Endowment&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87003-285-1&amp;rft.au=Husain+Haqqani&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnYppZ_dEjdIC%26pg%3DPA19&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-166"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-166">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCochrane2009" class="citation book cs1">Cochrane, Iain (2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=X2_FAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT37"><i>The Causes of the Bangladesh War</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4452-4043-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4452-4043-5"><bdi>978-1-4452-4043-5</bdi></a>. <q>The social scientist, Nasim Ahmad Jawed has conducted a survey of nationalism in pre-divided Pakistan and identifies the links between religion, politics and nationalism in both wings of Pakistan. His findings are fascinating and go some way to explain the differing attitudes of West and East Pakistan to the relationship between Islam and Pakistani nationalism and how this affected the views of people in both wings, especially the views of the peoples of both wings towards each other. In 1969, Jawed conducted a survey on the type of national identity that was used by educated professional people. He found that just over 60% in the East wing professed to have a secular national identity. However, in the West wing, the same figure professed an Islamic and not a secular identity. Furthermore, the same figure in the East wing described their identity in terms of their ethnicity and not in terms of Islam. He found that the opposite was the case in the West wing where Islam was stated to be more important than ethnicity.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Causes+of+the+Bangladesh+War&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4452-4043-5&amp;rft.aulast=Cochrane&amp;rft.aufirst=Iain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DX2_FAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPT37&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-167"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-167">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLintner2004" class="citation web cs1">Lintner, Bertil (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://apcss.org/Publications/Edited%20Volumes/ReligiousRadicalism/PagesfromReligiousRadicalismandSecurityinSouthAsiach17.pdf">"Religious Extremism and Nationalism in Bangladesh"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. p.&nbsp;418.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Religious+Extremism+and+Nationalism+in+Bangladesh&amp;rft.pages=418&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.aulast=Lintner&amp;rft.aufirst=Bertil&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fapcss.org%2FPublications%2FEdited%2520Volumes%2FReligiousRadicalism%2FPagesfromReligiousRadicalismandSecurityinSouthAsiach17.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

In this first ever general elections&nbsp;...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Islam%2C+Law+and+Identity&amp;rft.pages=196&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-67565-2&amp;rft.aulast=Diamantides&amp;rft.aufirst=Marinos&amp;rft.au=Gearey%2C+Adam&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWG-pAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA196&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:8-169"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:8_169-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFIqbal2009" class="citation book cs1">Iqbal, Khurshid (2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1Wh8AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA189"><i>The Right to Development in International Law: The Case of Pakistan</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-:9-170"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:9_170-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Kepel-1002-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Kepel-1002_172-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Kepel-1002_172-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-174"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-174">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-HRWdouble-19-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HRWdouble-19_175-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mIUwZ4aVM8AC&amp;pg=PA17"><i>Double Jeopardy: Police Abuse of Women in Pakistan</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-United_Book_Press-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-United_Book_Press_176-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2005" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Hussain (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&amp;pg=PA132"><i>Pakistan: between mosque and military</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-wynbr-2009-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-wynbr-2009_177-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-wynbr-2009_177-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFWynbrandt2009" class="citation book cs1">Wynbrandt, James (2009). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/briefhistoryofpa0000wynb_t6l9"><i>A Brief History of Pakistan</i></a></span>. Facts on File. pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/briefhistoryofpa0000wynb_t6l9/page/216">216</a>â7. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8160-6184-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8160-6184-6"><bdi>978-0-8160-6184-6</bdi></a>. <q>Zia, however, tried to bolster the influence of Islamic parties and the ulama on government and society.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Brief+History+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=216-7&amp;rft.pub=Facts+on+File&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8160-6184-6&amp;rft.aulast=Wynbrandt&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fbriefhistoryofpa0000wynb_t6l9&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-178">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSyedPioKamranZaidi2016" class="citation book cs1">Syed, Jawad; Pio, Edwina; Kamran, Tahir; Zaidi, Abbas (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0Mx5DQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA379"><i>Faith-Based Violence and Deobandi Militancy in Pakistan</i></a>. Springer. p.&nbsp;379. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-349-94966-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-349-94966-3"><bdi>978-1-349-94966-3</bdi></a>. <q>...&nbsp;the military dictator Zia ul Haq (1977â1988) forged a strong alliance between the military and Deobani institutions and movements (e.g. the TJ).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Faith-Based+Violence+and+Deobandi+Militancy+in+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=379&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-349-94966-3&amp;rft.aulast=Syed&amp;rft.aufirst=Jawad&amp;rft.au=Pio%2C+Edwina&amp;rft.au=Kamran%2C+Tahir&amp;rft.au=Zaidi%2C+Abbas&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D0Mx5DQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA379&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-179">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCesari2014" class="citation book cs1">Cesari, Jocelyne (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WgFeAwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA135"><i>The Awakening of Muslim Democracy: Religion, Modernity, and the State</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-:10-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:10_180-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSyedPioKamranZaidi2016" class="citation book cs1">Syed, Jawad; Pio, Edwina; Kamran, Tahir; Zaidi, Abbas (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0Mx5DQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA379"><i>Faith-Based Violence and Deobandi Militancy in Pakistan</i></a>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111222051452/http://www.fao.org/nr/water/aquastat/countries_regions/pakistan/index.stm">"Pakistan"</a>. Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations. 2010.          <li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFReuters2016" class="citation web cs1">Reuters (4 August 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://asiatimes.com/article/china-joins-afghanistan-pakistan-tajikistan-in-security-alliance/">"China joins Afghanistan, Pakistan, Tajikistan in security alliance"</a>. <i>www.atimes.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-259"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-259">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPasha2005" class="citation book cs1">Pasha, Sayed Abdul Muneem (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FjJuAAAAMAAJ"><i>Islam in Pakistan's foreign policy</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-260"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-260">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPasha2005" class="citation book cs1">Pasha, Sayed Abdul Muneem (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FjJuAAAAMAAJ"><i>Islam in Pakistan's foreign policy</i></a>.
