         <li id="cite_note-261"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-261">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPasha2005" class="citation book cs1">Pasha, Sayed Abdul Muneem (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FjJuAAAAMAAJ"><i>Islam in Pakistan's foreign policy</i></a>. Global Media Publications. p.&nbsp;226. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-88869-15-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-88869-15-2"><bdi>978-81-88869-15-2</bdi></a>. <q>Following Khaliquzzaman, the Ali brothers had sought to project Pakistan, with its comparatively larger manpower and military strength, as the natural leader of the Islamic world.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Islam+in+Pakistan%27s+foreign+policy&amp;rft.pages=226&amp;rft.pub=Global+Media+Publications&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-88869-15-2&amp;rft.aulast=Pasha&amp;rft.aufirst=Sayed+Abdul+Muneem&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFjJuAAAAMAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-262">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1Z6TBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA18"><i>Creating a New Medina</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;18. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-05212-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-05212-3"><bdi>978-1-107-05212-3</bdi></a>. <q>As a top ranking ML leader Khaliquzzaman declared, 'Pakistan would bring all Muslim countries together into Islamistan&nbsp;â a pan-Islamic entity'.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-05212-3&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1Z6TBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-263">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2013" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Husain (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VNAiBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA20"><i>Magnificent Delusions: Pakistan, the United States, and an Epic History of Misunderstanding</i></a>. PublicAffairs. pp.&nbsp;20â21. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-61039-317-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-61039-317-1"><bdi>978-1-61039-317-1</bdi></a>. <q>Within a few years the president of the Muslim League, Chaudhry Khaliq-uz-Zaman, announced that Pakistan would bring all Muslim countries together into Islamistan&nbsp;â a pan-Islamic entity. None of these developments within the new country elicited approval among Americans for the idea of India's partition&nbsp;... British Prime Minister Clement Attlee voiced the international consensus at the time when he told the House of Commons of his hope that 'this severance may not endure.' He hoped that the proposed dominions of India and Pakistan would <i>in course of time, come together to form one great Member State of the British Commonwealth of Nations.</i></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Magnificent+Delusions%3A+Pakistan%2C+the+United+States%2C+and+an+Epic+History+of+Misunderstanding&amp;rft.pages=20-21&amp;rft.pub=PublicAffairs&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-61039-317-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Husain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DVNAiBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA20&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-264"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-264">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHaqqani2013" class="citation book cs1">Haqqani, Husain (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=TyIVAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA22"><i>Magnificent Delusions: Pakistan, the United States, and an Epic History of Misunderstanding</i></a>. PublicAffairs. p.&nbsp;22. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-61039-317-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-61039-317-1"><bdi>978-1-61039-317-1</bdi></a>. <q>During this time most of the Arab world was going through a nationalist awakening. Pan-Islamic dreams involving the unification of Muslim countries, possibly under Pakistani leadership, had little attraction.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Magnificent+Delusions%3A+Pakistan%2C+the+United+States%2C+and+an+Epic+History+of+Misunderstanding&amp;rft.pages=22&amp;rft.pub=PublicAffairs&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-61039-317-1&amp;rft.aulast=Haqqani&amp;rft.aufirst=Husain&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DTyIVAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA22&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-265"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-265">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRoberts2003" class="citation book cs1">Roberts, Jeffery J. (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Pj8DIT_bva0C&amp;pg=PA134"><i>The Origins of Conflict in Afghanistan</i></a>. Greenwood Publishing Group. p.&nbsp;134. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-275-97878-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-275-97878-5"><bdi>978-0-275-97878-5</bdi></a>. <q>The following year, Choudhry Khaliquzzaman toured the Middle East, pleading for the formation of an alliance or confederation of Muslim states. The Arab states, often citing Pakistan's inability to solve its problems with Muslim neighbor Afghanistan, showed little enthusiasm&nbsp;... Some saw the effort to form 'Islamistan' as a Pakistani attempt to dominate other Muslim states.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Origins+of+Conflict+in+Afghanistan&amp;rft.pages=134&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-275-97878-5&amp;rft.aulast=Roberts&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeffery+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPj8DIT_bva0C%26pg%3DPA134&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-266"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-266">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPande2011" class="citation book cs1">Pande, Aparna (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HPWrAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT178"><i>Explaining Pakistan's Foreign Policy: Escaping India</i></a>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;178. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81893-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81893-6"><bdi>978-1-136-81893-6</bdi></a>. <q>The belief that the creation of Pakistan made Pakistan the true leader of Muslim causes around the world led Pakistan's diplomats to vigorously champion the cause of self-determination for fellow Muslims at the United Nations. Pakistan's founders, including Jinnah, supported anti-colonial movements: "Our heart and soul go out in sympathy with those who are struggling for their freedom&nbsp;... If subjugation and exploitation are carried on, there will be no peace and there will be no end to wars." Pakistani efforts on behalf of Indonesia (1948), Algeria (1948â1949), Tunisia (1948â1949), Morocco (1948â1956) and Eritrea (1960â1991) were significant and initially led to close ties between these countries and Pakistan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Explaining+Pakistan%27s+Foreign+Policy%3A+Escaping+India&amp;rft.pages=178&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-81893-6&amp;rft.aulast=Pande&amp;rft.aufirst=Aparna&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DHPWrAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPT178&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-267">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNasir2015" class="citation news cs1">Nasir, Abbas (18 August 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2015/08/legacy-pakistan-loved-loathed-hamid-gul-150817114006616.html">"The legacy of Pakistan's loved and loathed Hamid Gul"</a>. <i>Al-Jazeera</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">4 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>His commitment to jihadâto an Islamic revolution transcending national boundaries, was such that he dreamed one day the "green Islamic flag" would flutter not just over Pakistan and Afghanistan, but also over territories represented by the (former Soviet Union) Central Asian republics. After the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, as the director-general of the Pakistan's intelligence organisation, Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) directorate, an impatient Gul wanted to establish a government of the so-called Mujahideen on Afghan soil. He then ordered an assault using non-state actors on Jalalabad, the first major urban centre across the Khyber Pass from Pakistan, with the aim capturing it and declaring it as the seat of the new administration.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Al-Jazeera&amp;rft.atitle=The+legacy+of+Pakistan%27s+loved+and+loathed+Hamid+Gul&amp;rft.date=2015-08-18&amp;rft.aulast=Nasir&amp;rft.aufirst=Abbas&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aljazeera.com%2Findepth%2Fopinion%2F2015%2F08%2Flegacy-pakistan-loved-loathed-hamid-gul-150817114006616.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-268">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHunter2010" class="citation book cs1">Hunter, Shireen (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=wLtA_J3VUt4C&amp;pg=PA144"><i>Iran's Foreign Policy in the Post-Soviet Era: Resisting the New International Order</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p.&nbsp;144. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-38194-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-38194-2"><bdi>978-0-313-38194-2</bdi></a>. <q>Since then, Pakistan's sectarian tensions have been a major irritant in Iranian-Pakistan relations.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Iran%27s+Foreign+Policy+in+the+Post-Soviet+Era%3A+Resisting+the+New+International+Order&amp;rft.pages=144&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-38194-2&amp;rft.aulast=Hunter&amp;rft.aufirst=Shireen&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DwLtA_J3VUt4C%26pg%3DPA144&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPande2011" class="citation book cs1">Pande, Aparna (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ceg-kSmft94C&amp;pg=PA159"><i>Explaining Pakistan's Foreign Policy: Escaping India</i></a>. Taylor &amp; Francis. p.&nbsp;159. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81894-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81894-3"><bdi>978-1-136-81894-3</bdi></a>. <q>Both Saudi Arabia and Iran used Pakistan as a battleground for their proxy war for the 'hearts and minds' of Pakistani Sunnis and Shias with the resultant rise in sectarian tensions in Pakistan. The rise of the Taliban in Afghanistan in the 1990s further strained Pakistan-Iran relations. Pakistan's support of the Sunni Pashtun organization created problems for Shia Iran for whom a Taliban-controlled Afghanistan was a nightmare.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Explaining+Pakistan%27s+Foreign+Policy%3A+Escaping+India&amp;rft.pages=159&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-81894-3&amp;rft.aulast=Pande&amp;rft.aufirst=Aparna&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dceg-kSmft94C%26pg%3DPA159&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-270">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSchmetzer1998" class="citation news cs1">Schmetzer, Uli (14 September 1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-09-14/news/9809140197_1_shiite-taliban-sunni">"Iran Raises Anti-pakistan Outcry"</a>. <i>Chicago Tribune</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>KARACHI, Pakistan&nbsp;â Iran, which has amassed 200,000 troops on the border with Afghanistan, accused Pakistan on Sunday of sending warplanes to strafe and bombard Afghanistan's last Shiite stronghold, which fell hours earlier to the Taliban, the Sunni militia now controlling the central Asian country.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;rft.atitle=Iran+Raises+Anti-pakistan+Outcry&amp;rft.date=1998-09-14&amp;rft.aulast=Schmetzer&amp;rft.aufirst=Uli&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Farticles.chicagotribune.com%2F1998-09-14%2Fnews%2F9809140197_1_shiite-taliban-sunni&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-271"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-271">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFConstable1998" class="citation news cs1">Constable, Pamela (16 September 1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1998/09/16/afghanistan-arena-for-a-new-rivalry/eeedba2f-03b7-4ed6-ba97-91e51e633e96/">"Afghanistan: Arena For a New Rivalry"</a>. <i>The Washington Post</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>Taliban officials accused Iran of providing military support to the opposition forces; Tehran radio accused Pakistan of sending its air force to bomb the city in support of the Taliban's advance and said Iran was holding Pakistan responsible for what it termed war crimes at Bamiyan. Pakistan has denied that accusation and previous allegations of direct involvement in the Afghan conflict. Also fueling the volatile situation are ethnic and religious rivalries between the Taliban, who are Sunni Muslims of Afghanistan's dominant Pashtun ethnic group, and the opposition factions, many of which represent other ethnic groups or include Shiite Muslims. Iran, a Shiite Muslim state, has a strong interest in promoting that sect; Pakistan, one of the Taliban's few international allies, is about 80 percent Sunni.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Washington+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Afghanistan%3A+Arena+For+a+New+Rivalry&amp;rft.date=1998-09-16&amp;rft.aulast=Constable&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Farchive%2Fpolitics%2F1998%2F09%2F16%2Fafghanistan-arena-for-a-new-rivalry%2Feeedba2f-03b7-4ed6-ba97-91e51e633e96%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Taylor_&amp;_Francis.-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Taylor_&amp;_Francis._272-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPande2006" class="citation book cs1">Pande, Aparna (2006). <i>Explaining Pakistan's Foreign Policy: Escaping India</i>. Taylor &amp; Francis. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81894-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-81894-3"><bdi>978-1-136-81894-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Explaining+Pakistan%27s+Foreign+Policy%3A+Escaping+India&amp;rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis.&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-81894-3&amp;rft.aulast=Pande&amp;rft.aufirst=Aparna&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-273">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Article 1(1)â2(d) of the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://pakistani.org/pakistan/constitution/part1.html">Part I: Introductory</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">Constitution of Pakistan</a></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Amita_Shastri_South_Asia-286"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Amita_Shastri_South_Asia_286-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAmita_Shastri2001" class="citation book cs1">Amita Shastri (2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=du7xvBFpbg4C&amp;pg=PA289"><i>The Post-Colonial States of South Asia: Democracy, Development and Identity</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-290"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-290">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEndrst1965" class="citation news cs1">Endrst, Jeff (8 September 1965). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&amp;dat=19650908&amp;id=9wwvAAAAIBAJ&amp;pg=7266,2323319&amp;hl=en">"Kashmir Old Headache For U.N."</a> <i>The Pittsburgh Press</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>Former Indian Defense Minister Krishna Menon who for years influenced the decisions of late Prime Minister Nehru himself a Kashmiri-put it bluntly last March in an interview with an American newsman when he said India could never agree to a U.N. sponsored plebiscite because 'Kashmir would vote to join Pakistan, and no Indian government responsible for agreeing to the plebiscite could survive.'</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Pittsburgh+Press&amp;rft.atitle=Kashmir+Old+Headache+For+U.N.&amp;rft.date=1965-09-08&amp;rft.aulast=Endrst&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeff&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.google.com%2Fnewspapers%3Fnid%3D1144%26dat%3D19650908%26id%3D9wwvAAAAIBAJ%26pg%3D7266%2C2323319%26hl%3Den&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Diane_Publishing_Co.-301"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Diane_Publishing_Co._301-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-Frankfort,_IL-302"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Frankfort,_IL_302-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSingh2008" class="citation book cs1">Singh, R.S.N.          <li id="cite_note-319"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-319">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dawn.com/news/1215166">"Pakistan's peacekeeping role highlighted"</a>. <i>Dawn</i>. 24 October 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 December</span> 2016</span>. <q>Pakistan has contributed more than 160,000 troops to-date in 41 missions spread over 23 countries in almost all continents, it said. The country has remained one of the largest troop contributing countries consistently for many years.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Dawn&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan%27s+peacekeeping+role+highlighted&amp;rft.date=2015-10-24&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dawn.com%2Fnews%2F1215166&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Cordesman:_Pakistani_Toops_at_Tabuk-320"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cordesman:_Pakistani_Toops_at_Tabuk_320-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAnthony_H._Cordesman1986" class="citation book cs1">Anthony H. Under his leadership the ISI also got involved in supporting Chinese Muslims in Xinjiang Province, rebel Muslim groups in the Philippines, and some religious groups in Central Asia.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%27s+Drift+Into+Extremism%3A+Allah%2C+the+Army%2C+and+America%27s+War+on+Terror&amp;rft.pages=148&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-46328-3&amp;rft.aulast=Abbas&amp;rft.aufirst=Hassan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFHKsBwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA148&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2012/04/30/say-hello-to-the-country%E2%80%99s-largest-flyover/amp/">"Say hello to the country's largest flyover! | Pakistan Today"</a>. <i>www.pakistantoday.com.pk</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.pakistantoday.com.pk&amp;rft.atitle=Say+hello+to+the+country%27s+largest+flyover%21+%26%23124%3B+Pakistan+Today&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.pakistantoday.com.pk%2F2012%2F04%2F30%2Fsay-hello-to-the-country%25E2%2580%2599s-largest-flyover%2Famp%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Ministry_of_Science_and_Technology-456"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ministry_of_Science_and_Technology_456-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMinistry_of_Science_and_Technology" class="citation web cs1">Ministry of Science and Technology. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://most.comsatshosting.com/%5CPolicies%5CNational%20Science,%20Technology%20and%20Innovation%20Policy%202012.pdf">"National Science, Technology and Innovation Policy 2012"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.          <li id="cite_note-SUPARCO-471"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-SUPARCO_471-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-SUPARCO_471-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080417192331/http://www.suparco.gov.pk/pages/history.asp">"History of SUPARCO"</a>. <i>SUPARCO</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 December</span> 2011</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SUPARCO&amp;rft.atitle=History+of+SUPARCO&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.suparco.gov.pk%2Fpages%2Fhistory.asp&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-472"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-472">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFLele2012" class="citation book cs1">Lele, Ajey (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=chtAqyOp9OEC&amp;pg=PA46"><i>Asian Space Race: Rhetoric or Reality?</i></a>. Springer Science &amp; Business Media. p.&nbsp;46. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-322-0733-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-322-0733-7"><bdi>978-81-322-0733-7</bdi></a>. <q>Headquartered in SUPARCO headquarters, Karachi, it has been responsible directly and indirectly for the fabrication, processing and launch of the Muslim Ummah's first experimental satellite, Badr-1. It was a historical event not only for the people of Pakistan but also for the entire Muslim Ummah as it was the first satellite built by any Islamic country based on indigenous resources and manpower.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Asian+Space+Race%3A+Rhetoric+or+Reality%3F&amp;rft.pages=46&amp;rft.pub=Springer+Science+%26+Business+Media&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-322-0733-7&amp;rft.aulast=Lele&amp;rft.aufirst=Ajey&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DchtAqyOp9OEC%26pg%3DPA46&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-476"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-476">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSayar1995" class="citation journal cs1">Sayar, M.A. (AprilâJune 1995). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160215200726/http://www.fountainmagazine.com/Issue/detail/Should-We-Exploit-The-Last-Wilderness">"Should We Exploit The Last Wilderness?"</a>. <i>The Fountain Magazine</i>.          <li id="cite_note-edu2-488"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-edu2_488-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-edu2_488-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapter_10/10_Education.pdf">"Economic Survey 2009â10"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110304130317/http://www.britishcouncil.org/pakistan-ette-english-language-report.pdf">"Teaching and Learning in Pakistan: The Role of Language in Education"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. British Council. 2010. pp.&nbsp;13, 14, 15. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britishcouncil.org/pakistan-ette-english-language-report.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 4 March 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 May</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Teaching+and+Learning+in+Pakistan%3A+The+Role+of+Language+in+Education&amp;rft.pages=13%2C+14%2C+15&amp;rft.pub=British+Council&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britishcouncil.org%2Fpakistan-ette-english-language-report.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-:72-526"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:72_526-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:72_526-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRehman2015" class="citation news cs1">Rehman, Zia Ur (18 August 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/57104-with-a-handful-of-subberstwo-newspapers-barely-keeping-gujarati-alive-in-karachi">"With a handful of subbers, two newspapers barely keeping Gujarati alive in Karachi"</a>. <i>The News International</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 January</span> 2017</span>. <q>In Pakistan, the majority of Gujarati-speaking communities are in Karachi including Dawoodi Bohras, Ismaili Khojas, Memons, Kathiawaris, Katchhis, Parsis (Zoroastrians) and Hindus, said Gul Hasan Kalmati, a researcher who authored "Karachi, Sindh Jee Marvi", a book discussing the city and its indigenous communities. Although there are no official statistics available, community leaders claim that there are three million Gujarati-speakers in Karachi&nbsp;â roughly around 15 percent of the city's entire population.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+News+International&amp;rft.atitle=With+a+handful+of+subbers%2C+two+newspapers+barely+keeping+Gujarati+alive+in+Karachi&amp;rft.date=2015-08-18&amp;rft.aulast=Rehman&amp;rft.aufirst=Zia+Ur&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thenews.com.pk%2Fprint%2F57104-with-a-handful-of-subberstwo-newspapers-barely-keeping-gujarati-alive-in-karachi&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-CP/31-527"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CP/31_527-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan" title="Constitution of Pakistan">Constitution of Pakistan</a>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pakistanconstitutionlaw.com/article-31-islamic-way-of-life"><i>Constitution of Pakistan, 1973 â Article: 31 Islamic way of life</i></a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180826122333/https://pakistanconstitutionlaw.com/article-31-islamic-way-of-life/">Archived</a> 26 August 2018 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, Article 31 No. 2, 1973, Retrieved 22 August 2018.</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-533"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-533">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://tribune.com.pk/story/347968/fringe-pakistan-bengali-speaking-pakistanis-demand-right-to-vote/">"Fringe Pakistan: Bengali-speaking Pakistanis demand right to vote"</a>. <i>Express Tribune</i>. 10 March 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 December</span> 2016</span>. <q>Shaikh Muhammad Feroze, the chairman of the committee, said during a press conference on Friday that political parties and the government should acknowledge the sacrifices of their ancestors. 'We live in Sindh and feel proud to be called Sindhis rather than Bengalis. We appeal to Sindhi nationalists and Sindhis to help us in our struggle', he added. He said that Bengali-speaking people were not given educational rights as they did not possess national identity cards. 'Our children can't get an education after matriculation because colleges ask for the identity cards but the National Database Registration Authority has never accepted us as Pakistani citizens.' Shaikh said that over three million Bengalis and Biharis were grateful to the government for accepting them as Pakistani citizens. 'We postponed a hunger strike planned for March 25 after the government made decisions', he added. 'We can go on a hunger strike, if our rights are not given.' He claimed that there were 200 settlements of Bengali-speaking people across the country, including 132 in Karachi. They populate different parts of Pakistan, including Thatta, Badin, Hyderabad, Tando Adam and Lahore.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Express+Tribune&amp;rft.atitle=Fringe+Pakistan%3A+Bengali-speaking+Pakistanis+demand+right+to+vote&amp;rft.date=2012-03-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ftribune.com.pk%2Fstory%2F347968%2Ffringe-pakistan-bengali-speaking-pakistanis-demand-right-to-vote%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-534"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-534">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-536"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-536">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJaffrey2015" class="citation news cs1">Jaffrey, Shumaila (12 August 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-33775646">"How the Uighurs keep their culture alive in Pakistan"</a>. <i>BBC</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Some left Xinjiang and the thriving trading town of Kashgar in 1949, while others are later arrivals. All say they were forced to leave as they were the victims of cultural and religious oppression in China.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=BBC&amp;rft.atitle=How+the+Uighurs+keep+their+culture+alive+in+Pakistan&amp;rft.date=2015-08-12&amp;rft.aulast=Jaffrey&amp;rft.aufirst=Shumaila&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fworld-asia-33775646&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-538"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-538">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbbas2002" class="citation news cs1">Abbas, Zaffar (13 March 2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1869876.stm">"Pakistan's Sidi keep heritage alive"</a>. BBC News<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 December</span> 2016</span>. <q>One of the Pakistan's smallest ethnic communities is made up of people of African origin, known as Sidi. The African-Pakistanis live in Karachi and other parts of the Sindh and Baluchistan provinces in abject poverty, but they rarely complain of discrimination. Although this small Muslim community is not on the verge of extinction, their growing concern is how to maintain their distinct African identity in the midst of the dominating South Asian cultures.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan%27s+Sidi+keep+heritage+alive&amp;rft.date=2002-03-13&amp;rft.aulast=Abbas&amp;rft.aufirst=Zaffar&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Fsouth_asia%2F1869876.stm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-:3-541"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:3_541-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:3_541-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/india-has-largest-diaspora-population-in-world-un/183731.html">"India has largest diaspora population in world: UN"</a>. <i>The Tribune</i>. 15 January 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Clark-542"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Clark_542-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Clark_542-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Clark_542-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Clark_542-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFClark2006" class="citation book cs1">Clark, David (2006). <i>The Elgar Companion to Development Studies</i>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2122.html?countryName=Pakistan&amp;countryCode=pk&amp;regionCode=sas&amp;#pk">"Religions: Muslim 96.4% (Sunni 75%, Shia 20%), other"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 August</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft.atitle=Field+Listing+%3A+Religions&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Flibrary%2Fpublications%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Ffields%2F2122.html%3FcountryName%3DPakistan%26countryCode%3Dpk%26regionCode%3Dsas%26%23pk&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-564"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-564">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFQureshi2019" class="citation web cs1">Qureshi, Ammar Ali (10 November 2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.dawn.com/news/1515823">"Non-fiction: Pakistan's Shia dynamics"</a>. <i>Dawn</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Dawn&amp;rft.atitle=Non-fiction%3A+Pakistan%27s+Shia+dynamics&amp;rft.date=2019-11-10&amp;rft.aulast=Qureshi&amp;rft.aufirst=Ammar+Ali&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dawn.com%2Fnews%2F1515823&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-565"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-565">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKhan2016" class="citation book cs1">Khan, Nichola (2016). <i>Cityscapes of Violence in Karachi: Publics and Counterpublics</i>. Oxford University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-086978-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-086978-6"><bdi>978-0-19-086978-6</bdi></a>. <q>... With a population of over 23 million Karachi is also the world's largest Muslim city, the world's seventh largest conurbation ...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Cityscapes+of+Violence+in+Karachi%3A+Publics+and+Counterpublics&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-086978-6&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Nichola&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ahmadi-566"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ahmadi_566-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 1998 Pakistani census states that there are 291,000 (0.22%) Ahmadis in Pakistan. However, the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community has boycotted the census since 1974 which renders official Pakistani figures to be inaccurate. Independent groups have estimated the Pakistani Ahmadiyya population to be somewhere between 2 million and 5 million Ahmadis. However, the 4 million figure is the most quoted figure and is approximately 2.2% of the country. See: 
           <ul>
            <li>over 2 million: 
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFImmigration_and_Refugee_Board_of_Canada2008" class="citation web cs1">Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (4 December 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/49913b5f2c.html">"Pakistan: The situation of Ahmadis, including legal status and political, education and employment rights; societal attitudes toward Ahmadis (2006 â Nov. 2008)"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 June</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Pakistan%3A+The+situation+of+Ahmadis%2C+including+legal+status+and+political%2C+education+and+employment+rights%3B+societal+attitudes+toward+Ahmadis+%282006+%E2%80%93+Nov.+2008%29&amp;rft.date=2008-12-04&amp;rft.au=Immigration+and+Refugee+Board+of+Canada&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.unhcr.org%2Frefworld%2Fdocid%2F49913b5f2c.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></li> 
            <li>3 million: International Federation for Human Rights: <i>International Fact-Finding Mission. Freedoms of Expression, of Association and of Assembly in Pakistan.</i> Ausgabe 408/2, January 2005, S. 61 (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/pk408a-2.pdf">PDF</a>)</li> 
            <li>3â4 million: Commission on International Religious Freedom: <i>Annual Report of the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom.</i> 2005, S. 130</li> 
            <li>4.910.000: James Minahan: Encyclopedia of the stateless nations. Ethnic and national groups around the world. Greenwood Press. Westport 2002, p. 52</li> 
            <li>
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=country&amp;category=&amp;publisher=IRBC&amp;type=QUERYRESPONSE&amp;coi=PAK&amp;rid=&amp;docid=45f1478f20&amp;skip=0">"Pakistan: Situation of members of the Lahori Ahmadiyya Movement in Pakistan"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-573"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-573">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFarooq_Soomro2014" class="citation web cs1">Farooq Soomro (10 October 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.dawn.com/news/1136858">"Sehwan: The undisputed throne of Lal Shahbaz Qalandar"</a>. <i>dawn.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 January</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=dawn.com&amp;rft.atitle=Sehwan%3A+The+undisputed+throne+of+Lal+Shahbaz+Qalandar&amp;rft.date=2014-10-10&amp;rft.au=Farooq+Soomro&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dawn.com%2Fnews%2F1136858&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-574"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-574">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHussain" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Hussain, Rizwan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0616">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World</i>. <q>SÅ«fÄ« Islam in Pakistan is represented at two levels. The first is the populist Sufism of the rural masses, associated with unorthodox religious rituals and practices, belief in the intercessory powers of saints, pilgrimage and veneration at their shrines, and a binding spiritual relationship between the shaykh or pir (master) and murÄ«d (disciple). Many Muslims in rural areas of Pakistan, where orthodox Islam has yet to penetrate effectively, identify themselves with some pir, living or dead, and seek his intercession for the solution of their worldly problems and for salvation in the hereafter.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Islamic+World&amp;rft.aulast=Hussain&amp;rft.aufirst=Rizwan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordislamicstudies.com%2Farticle%2Fopr%2Ft236%2Fe0616&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-575"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-575">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHussain" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Hussain, Rizwan. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0616">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World</i>. <q>The other strain is that of scholastic or intellectual Sufism, a recent phenomenon based in urban areas and becoming increasingly popular in educated circles. Influenced by the writings of the medieval theologian al-GhazÄlÄ« (d.&nbsp;1111), the SÅ«fÄ« reformer Shaykh Aá¸¥mad SirhindÄ« (d.&nbsp;1624), and ShÄh WalÄ« AllÄh (d.&nbsp;1762), and by the spiritual experiences of the masters of the SuhrawardÄ« and NaqshbandÄ« orders, these modern SÅ«fÄ«s are rearticulating Islamic metaphysics as an answer to Western materialism.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Encyclopedia+of+the+Islamic+World&amp;rft.aulast=Hussain&amp;rft.aufirst=Rizwan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxfordislamicstudies.com%2Farticle%2Fopr%2Ft236%2Fe0616&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ethnologue.com/country/PK/languages">"Pakistan"</a>. <i>Ethnologue</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Ethnologue&amp;rft.atitle=Pakistan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ethnologue.com%2Fcountry%2FPK%2Flanguages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-581"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-581">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFZamindar2010" class="citation book cs1">Zamindar, Vazira Fazila-Yacoobali (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=n5c9ta97GeoC&amp;pg=PA72"><i>The Long Partition and the Making of Modern South Asia: Refugees, Boundaries, Histories</i></a>. Columbia University Press. p.&nbsp;72. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-13847-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-13847-5"><bdi>978-0-231-13847-5</bdi></a>. <q>The logic of the <i>hostage theory</i> tied the treatment of Muslim minorities in India to the treatment meted out to Hindus in Pakistan.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Long+Partition+and+the+Making+of+Modern+South+Asia%3A+Refugees%2C+Boundaries%2C+Histories&amp;rft.pages=72&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-13847-5&amp;rft.aulast=Zamindar&amp;rft.aufirst=Vazira+Fazila-Yacoobali&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dn5c9ta97GeoC%26pg%3DPA72&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-582"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-582">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFDhulipala2015" class="citation book cs1">Dhulipala, Venkat (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PrqLBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA19"><i>Creating a New Medina: State Power, Islam, and the Quest for Pakistan in Late Colonial North India</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&nbsp;19. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-316-25838-5"><bdi>978-1-316-25838-5</bdi></a>. <q>Within the subcontinent, ML propaganda claimed that besides liberating the 'majority provinces' Muslims it would guarantee protection for Muslims who would be left behind in Hindu India. In this regard, it repeatedly stressed the hostage population theory that held that 'hostage' Hindu and Sikh minorities inside Pakistan would guarantee Hindu India's good behaviour towards its own Muslim minority.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Creating+a+New+Medina%3A+State+Power%2C+Islam%2C+and+the+Quest+for+Pakistan+in+Late+Colonial+North+India&amp;rft.pages=19&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-316-25838-5&amp;rft.aulast=Dhulipala&amp;rft.aufirst=Venkat&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPrqLBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA19&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-583"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-583">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFQasmi2015" class="citation book cs1">Qasmi, Ali Usman (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=n7u2BgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA149"><i>The Ahmadis and the Politics of Religious Exclusion in Pakistan</i></a>. Anthem Press. p.&nbsp;149. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-78308-425-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-78308-425-8"><bdi>978-1-78308-425-8</bdi></a>. <q>Nazim-ud-Din favored an Islamic state not just out of political expediency but also because of his deep religious belief in its efficacy and practicality&nbsp;... Nazim-ud-Din commented:'I do not agree that religion is a private affair of the individual nor do I agree that in an Islamic state every citizen has identical rights, no matter what his caste, creed or faith be'.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Ahmadis+and+the+Politics+of+Religious+Exclusion+in+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=149&amp;rft.pub=Anthem+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-78308-425-8&amp;rft.aulast=Qasmi&amp;rft.aufirst=Ali+Usman&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dn7u2BgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA149&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APakistan" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-bbc200703022-584"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-bbc200703022_584-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSohail2007" class="citation news cs1">Sohail, Riaz (2 March 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6367773.stm">"Hindus feel the heat in Pakistan"</a>. <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-Books.google.com-597"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Books.google.com_597-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Books.google.com_597-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFStephanie_KoernerIan_Russell2010" class="citation book cs1">Stephanie Koerner; Ian Russell (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=7li2jpQgYvAC&amp;pg=PA382"><i>Unquiet Pasts: Risk Society, Lived Cultural Heritage, Re-designing Reflexivity</i></a>.                       </ul></li>

                 <div>

                   <li><img alt="Category" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/16px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Category" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/23px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/31px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="185"> <a href="/wiki/Category:Districts_of_Pakistan" title="Category:Districts of Pakistan"><span style="color:white">Category</span></a></li> 
                   <li><img alt="Portal" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/16px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Portal" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/23px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/31px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="185"> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Pakistan" title="Portal:Pakistan"><span style="color:white">Portal</span></a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                   <li>&nbsp;<span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Pakistan</a></li> 
                   <li>&nbsp;<span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Tajikistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a></li> 
                   <li>&nbsp;<span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/23px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/35px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Flag_of_Turkey.svg/45px-Flag_of_Turkey.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a></li> 
                   <li>&nbsp;<span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Turkmenistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a></li> 
                   <li>&nbsp;<span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Uzbekistan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="500">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
